The literature clariﬁes general best practices for the development
of DT, but no one developmental approachﬁts all cases as the spe-
ciﬁc functionality of each DT can vary widely between applications.
In addition to this, the software tools used to create DT vary wildly,
although simulation tools such as Maya Simulation Framework and
Simulink are commonly used [41,42].
5 Digital Twin Applications
DTs are gaining popularity within the systems engineering com-
munity, especially within the domain of MBSE [43]. DTs offer a
unique approach to system conceptualization, model veriﬁcation,
and enhanced validation and evaluation [ 43]. Within systems
engineering, for example, new methodologies for enhanced system
deﬁnition such as data element mapping and analysis (DEMA)
could be used to aid in the development of DTs of complex
systems [44].

or enhanced system
deﬁnition such as data element mapping and analysis (DEMA)
could be used to aid in the development of DTs of complex
systems [44]. DTs also set the stage for real-time systems evalua-
tions. This is especially critical during and after disturbances [45].
System resilience requires survival and recovery in the face of dis-
ruptions [46], a critical consideration for the future of human
systems as large-scale disasters become more commonplace [47].
Historically, quantifying the resilience of human systems requires
detailed performance evaluations under any disruption of interest.
Although strides are being made in creating computationally
cheaper techniques Refs. [ 48–50], benchmarking metrics with
lower data requirements can be used earlier in the design process
and cover a broad range of disturbances [45]. The design and mon-
itoring of resilience in human systems with these types of metrics is
one area where DTs may have the largest impact as they provide
near-conti

d mon-
itoring of resilience in human systems with these types of metrics is
one area where DTs may have the largest impact as they provide
near-continuous information for benchmarking metrics that can
give decision-makers critical alerts that their system has, or is
about to, fall out of acceptable bounds of operations. Many of the
applications outlined in the sections following highlight the use
of DT to support systems’monitoring and response to disturbances.
Advances in the design of physical power grids for resilience
require information about powerﬂows at key system actors [51],
and this information could be provided in real time by power
system DTs to constantly check the status of a grid’s N-1 contingen-
cies (more examples of applications within the energy sector follow
in Sec.5.1.1). The information from DTs can also guide decision-
makers as to the most favorable next steps to take in such situations.
The signiﬁcant historical data can be used to better guide the devel-

ion-
makers as to the most favorable next steps to take in such situations.
The signiﬁcant historical data can be used to better guide the devel-
opment of new human systems, for example, the inclusion of
renewables in an existing system [52] or the creation of a more gen-
erally resilient system of systems [53]. For example, engineering
makerspaces are a student–tool interaction network that has very
little quantitative data guiding their development. A makerspace
DT could revolutionize the recognition of both intended and unin-
tended policy consequences preventing certain student groups from
using the space [54,55].

on the uses of DT for manufacturing and the product lifecycle, the

ave been many publications
on the uses of DT for manufacturing and the product lifecycle, the

nd a majority of DT appli-

5.1.1 The Energy Sector. While most DT development has
been done by academic institutions and individuals, a number of
companies have started offering DT-related products and solutions
for customers in the energy sector [60]. Siemens has integrated DT
into a number of their products for PLM and Design [61] although
the exact nature of the DT products they offer remains unclear. GE
has a number of DT software options available for jet engines, wind
turbines, and a variety of other energy generation/manipulation
equipment. GE claims a 93 –99% increase in reliability and
$1.6BN customer savings through using DTs [58,62].
A team at Stanford University built and implemented a DT
framework for modeling and controlling the on campus electrical
bus network. While this work does not exactlyﬁt the deﬁnition of
a full microgrid (MG) DT, it has a high degree of practical
overlap. The DT created uses forecasting of solar emissions, bus
schedules, bus energy states, and other

d (MG) DT, it has a high degree of practical
overlap. The DT created uses forecasting of solar emissions, bus
schedules, bus energy states, and other relevant parameters as
inputs to an optimization model, which is then used to create new
bus schedules optimized for more efﬁcient operation and utilization
of renewable energy sources [63]. This work displayed a high
degree of practical beneﬁts if the proposed model was to be imple-
mented, although real-world results are pending a pilot study with
the Stanford Marguerite Shuttle.
The subsequent paragraphs in this subsection diverge from

These DTs are more similar to the“prototype” type of DT, rather
than the “instance” type, as deﬁned by Grieves. Nevertheless, we
feel it is useful that the reader be aware of the below efforts
because of the rapid march toward DT deployment in the energy
sector.

Park et al. address DT-based cost estimation and energy storage

AI-based approaches to predict cost savings from running and an
energy storage system (ESS) tied to the grid, where the optimal
scheduling of the ESS is known as a control. Within the case
study, the driver tree model was the most accurate in predicting
scheduling and cost savings, with an average root-mean-square
error of 7.33. The article by Park et al. represents an interesting
approach to predicting energy costs and scheduling and shows
some success with that limiting context, but does not attempt to
create a true DT of a MG, rather it creates a limited black-box rep-

Korean energy grid. Despite its deviation from focusing on true
DTs for MGs, the Park’s article prese

of energy scheduling connected to the main South

propose a true MG DT, and while no real-world example is built
or demonstrated, the DT proposed would likely be highly effective

Perhaps the most relevant MG DT example is of a nanogrid
(a small MG) that was designed using commercial off-the-shelf
equipment, and a companion DT for the battery energy storage
system voltage source converter that was constructed and used to
generate error vectors accurately reﬂect the state of the physical
twin [68]. While the work demonstrated is primarily done in
MATLAB, the DT developed can be run on hardware in the loop, pos-
sibly coupled with AI, to predict and react to system faults.
While few DTs have been demonstrated for full MG twinning, a
number of papers explore DT of isolated electronic components,
which might be combined to create an MG DT, such as power con-
verters [68–71]; battery systems [72–75]; renewable energy sources
such as wind, geothermal, wave, and solar [76–81]; and other com-
ponents. One approach to creating an MG DT would be to fuse
together component DTs, such as

wind, geothermal, wave, and solar [76–81]; and other com-
ponents. One approach to creating an MG DT would be to fuse
together component DTs, such as power converters and ESS, to
create a more encompassing MG DT. It is unclear how difﬁcult
combining disparate DT instances together might be, as there
may be issues with computing power for real-time simulation and
communication between the many component DTs. This may be
an area where MBSE tools become useful.
The bridge between a virtual prototype and the hardware proto-
type has been recently offered by control-hardware-in-the-loop
(CHiL) testing, in which the controller designed and simulated
for a system is implemented on the control hardware, which will
be later used to drive the hardware prototype. For example, after
the physics-based model of a power converter is used to satisfacto-
rily simulate the system performance, the power converter control
system is programmed into a digital signal processor (DSP),ﬁeld
programmable gate a

rily simulate the system performance, the power converter control
system is programmed into a digital signal processor (DSP),ﬁeld
programmable gate array (FPGA), or other control hardware, and
run in real time to verify its functionality [68,69].
The process of creating CHiL tests for risk reduction is the pre-
cursor of DT, as the physics-based model of the system is simulated
in the control hardware in real time, effectively creating a DT of the
hardware that is later built. Once the hardware prototype is built, the
DT is usually set aside; however, its existence creates an opportu-
nity to further the reach of digital engineering within the lifetime
of the ﬁnal product. The DT can continue to run in real time, on
the same platform as the control system for the hardware prototype,
with the addition of feedback signals from the hardware, i.e., cur-
rents and voltages, which the DT can use to update its physics-based
model and to support the physical twin (hardware prototype) by
makin

, i.e., cur-
rents and voltages, which the DT can use to update its physics-based
model and to support the physical twin (hardware prototype) by
making decisions under fault conditions. A diagram of a laboratory
DT setup is shown in Fig.2 for a power electronic system, with the
physical system shown on the left-hand side and the DT depicted on
the right-hand side, inside the digital control hardware, where the
controller for the physical system is implemented. Two control
systems effectively run on the same platform (FPGA, DSP, or
other) with the same clock, and while the physical system runs on
hardware, the DT runs in the control hardware, receiving real-time
data from the physical twin.
Experimental data are the key to distinguish DT from CHiL
testing, and it is used in different ways to strengthen the virtual twin:
(a) historical data can be used to train an intelligent agent [68],
acting within the DT, to learn the functionality of the physical
system it is twinning, and (b) real-

can be used to train an intelligent agent [68],
acting within the DT, to learn the functionality of the physical
system it is twinning, and (b) real-time data acquired from the phys-
ical twin can be used by the DT to update its model and make deci-
sions regarding faults or maintenance, as examples [82]. Extensive
literature has been recently generated with a focus on energy
systems and, within this area, energy systems based on the Internet
of things (IoTs) are a particularly attractive application for DT as
reported in Ref. [83]. IoT devices can provide real-time data to
DT, accelerating its applicability and productivity to boost reliabil-
ity, efﬁciency, and other key performance parameters.

5.1.2 The Space and Aerospace Sector. Since the concept of
DT originated at NASA, it should not be surprising that it gained
popularity in the aerospace industryﬁrst. DTs have long been pro-
posed for spacecraft and are in use by NASA and others [85], with
special interest in uses for airframe health monitoring [86–88]. DTs
have also been widely studied for PHM, remaining us

by NASA and others [85], with
special interest in uses for airframe health monitoring [86–88]. DTs
have also been widely studied for PHM, remaining useful life esti-
mations, and related purposes for aircraft [2,89–95].
Aerospace manufacturing requires highly precise and reliable
manufacturing, both because of narrow weight margins and high
part performance and because reliability and predictability must
also be very high. For these reasons, DTs have been developed
for the production of aircraft parts to closely predict and manage
machining processes [96]. For example, Shahpar and Rolls-Royce
created AI-based DTs to accurately import and model real parts
into physics models for aviation components such as Jet engine
bypass outlet [97].
A DT technology for electric space propulsion (EP) has been pro-
posed. This technology is capable of providing an accurate virtual
representation of a physical asset and is a game-changing concept
that catalyzes the transcendence of the EP industry past

oviding an accurate virtual
representation of a physical asset and is a game-changing concept
that catalyzes the transcendence of the EP industry past the pressing
challenges it is facing today [98]. In a similar vein, a DT for space-
craft was recently proposed [99].
5.1.3 The Manufacturing Sector. While the concept of DT
originates with NASA and aviation, it has been embraced by the
manufacturing industry as well. Working as part of Industry 4.0,
and the so-called“smart manufacturing,”much has been published,
and DTs have been adopted by industry in recent years, with large
companies such as GE and Siemens, both developing DT products
[100–102]. Microsoft also offers DT options through Azure, which
appear to be focused on manufacturing, although the maturity of
these offerings remains unclear [103]. DTs are also beginning to
ﬁnd their way into semiconductor manufacturing [104] and even
furniture and garment manufacturing among other manufacturing
sectors [105–108].

5.1.4 The Construction Sector. DTs are being proposed for use
in construction as part of the Industry 4.0 Paradigm and in compar-
ison with the construction industry’s building information modeling
(BIM) [19,109]. DTs are able to enable more effective decision-
making for building sites by using highly accurate data being

[110,111]. DTs can also be used for condition-based maintenance
and predicting the lifecycle of speciﬁ
c facilities [112], although
its largest use case in construction appears to be real-time data visu-
alization [113].
5.1.5 The Geosciences Sector. The proliferation of Low Earth
Orbit imaging satellites, enabled by advances in small satellite and
launch vehicle technologies, has led to an unprecedented amount of
data available about the Earth’s land, oceans, and atmospheres.

Complementing the capabilities of the dozens of larger satellites

One such revolutionary capability is the development of a DT of
Earth [114], in which data from orbiting satellites can be assimilated
in near real time into weather models. A DT of Earth allows us to
answer not only What now questions (what is the current state of
the Earth system?) but also What next (forecasting) and What if
questions (sensitivity analysis and optimization

stions (what is the current state of

NASA is also investing heavily in DTs through their Advanced

uses of DTs [12,122] and in shipbuilding [12

acturing, and other naval applications
[89,117–121]. There has also been interest more widely in maritime

USS Harpers Ferry (LSD 49) [124]. DTs have also been developed

5.1.8 Research and Education. Many research laboratories
worldwide are working on the development of DT for various appli-
cations. Although different technical areas focus on various applica-
tions, most laboratories are adopting the process of designing virtual
twins through modeling, make them interact with the hardware
physical twins through data exchange, and then produce tangible
results in terms of reliability, health monitoring, fault recovery,
etc. [143,144]. This extends into digital engineering, which has
been extensively used for the past 30 years to assist in the design
of complex engineering systems and for risk reduction activities,
to reduce the cos

een extensively used for the past 30 years to assist in the design
of complex engineering systems and for risk reduction activities,
to reduce the cost of product development [28,145]. In digital engi-
neering, physics-based models are developed and implemented in
appropriate software platforms to run multiple simulations before
a hardware prototype is built in the laboratory [146], which is
similar to DT. We observe that many research laboratories have
switched from digital engineering to DT development with virtual
systems as part of their research methodologies. Modeling and sim-
ulations have reduced the cost of product development by limiting
the amount of time engineers spend in the laboratory [147]. Testing

6 Future Digital Twin Research Directions
This section discusses our views on the future directions that
research must take to realize the 13 areas that the RFI [8] identiﬁed
as being crucial to the National DTs R&D Strategic Plan and a 14th
area we recently identiﬁed. This section includes text from our RFI
submission and has been expanded with the additional content. We
believe that the research and industry communities should pursue
the development of DT as described below. The subsequent subsec-
tions in Sec. 6 are organized to (1) provide the original RFI’s
request for comment on a speciﬁc topic and our interpretation of
that request, (2) discuss the importance of the topic, (3) provide
background on the current state of the topic, (4) discuss challenges
that the research and industrial communities face in the topic, (5)
review pote

e
background on the current state of the topic, (4) discuss challenges
that the research and industrial communities face in the topic, (5)
review potential solutions to the challenges, and (6) provide direc-
tion to the research community on how to shape our collective
research to realize solutions.
6.1 Arti ﬁcial Intelligence. The RFI-speciﬁed areas of focus
for potential AI DT research including“integration of DTs with
AI; leverage generative AI for DT modeling and simulation with
the consideration of the potential impact on a DTs’physical coun-
terpart” [8]. We interpreted the RFI AI topic to include both AI
within the DT and also AI-enabled physical twins.
6.1.1 Topic Importance. AI, including generative AI, is a key
enabling technology for DT. AI can be used in DT to (1) develop
robust models of the state of the DT and the world, and these
models can in turn provide a more accurate representation of the
current state of the physical twin and its operational environment;
(2) genera

these
models can in turn provide a more accurate representation of the
current state of the physical twin and its operational environment;
(2) generate datasets to train those models; (3) develop predictive
models of the future state of the DT and thus inform decision-
making; (4) quantify uncertainty in the predictions of those
models; and (5) retrieve and process data from different data
sources and turn data into insights. Some of these applications
have already been demonstrated, while others remain largely
conceptual.
A different aspect of the intersection between AI and DT is when
the SOI is an AI-enabled system. In this case, the AI is a source of
challenges related to the stochasticity of system behavior.
6.1.2 Current State of the Topic.Current emphasis in AI both
in general and in DTs in particular has largely been around gener-
ative AI. Generative AI refers to AI systems capable of creating
new content, such as text, images, music, or videos, based on the
patterns they hav

-
ative AI. Generative AI refers to AI systems capable of creating
new content, such as text, images, music, or videos, based on the
patterns they have learned from the existing data. It can capture
the distribution of data and generate new samples from that distribu-
tion. The past few years have seen tremendous advancement in gen-
erative AI and its success in many engineering domains. Prior
works on DTs have incorporated generative models, including gen-
erative adversarial networks [ 153], variational autoencoders
(VAEs) [154], diffusion models [155], invertible neural networks
[156–158], and transformer-based models [159,160]. These works
mainly focus on the following functionalities:
(1) Generating data: Generative AI can support DTs by generat-
ing highly realistic and diverse synthetic data. This can
augment the existing data and signiﬁcantly reduce the time
for data acquisition [161]. Past works have also employed
generative AI to emulate the environment and generate
data of v

signiﬁcantly reduce the time
for data acquisition [161]. Past works have also employed
generative AI to emulate the environment and generate
data of virtual scenarios (e.g., the network trafﬁc in commu-
nication networks [162,163
]), which the simulator can use to
predict the system’s behavior under the generated scenarios.
(2) Accommodating uncertainty: Generative AI can model
various uncertainties (e.g., sensor measurement uncertainty)
presented in the modeling procedure [164] and solve the cal-
ibration problem of physics-based models by producing a
full distribution of calibration solutions [165], due to the
inherent ability of generative models to learn the underlying
distribution from data.
(3) Abstracting features: We can leverage generative AI to
improve the efﬁciency of DTs by learning a low-dimensional
representation (i.e., abstracted features) to capture the high-
dimensional data of system status [163,166]. Such feature
abstraction capability also leads to more efﬁcient dat

racted features) to capture the high-
dimensional data of system status [163,166]. Such feature
abstraction capability also leads to more efﬁcient data trans-
mission— by extracting the hidden semantics from source
data, only low-dimensional semantic information needs to
be transmitted between physical and virtual systems [167].
(4) Predicting dynamic behavior: Generative AI can predict the
future state of the system based on data distribution to
assist decision-making [161,166,168].
In addition to specialized generative models, general-purpose
large language models (LLMs) were also integrated into DTs.
These LLMs can address multimodal data and enhance human–
computer interaction [169]. The prior work also used LLMs to
generate natural language explanations of the system’s decision-
making [170]. We can create multiagent systems, containing
multiple LLM agents, either to enable the integration of multidi-
mensional, heterogeneous information in the DT [171] or to com-
plete different

ing
multiple LLM agents, either to enable the integration of multidi-
mensional, heterogeneous information in the DT [171] or to com-
plete different tasks such as observation, reasoning, decision-
making, and summarization [172].
An interesting new approach that DT enables is based on AI and
machine learning harnessing the power of plasma chemistry as a
programmable intelligent material with a new concept of a
chemical-based algorithm [173]. By treating plasma reactions as
analogous to neural networks, it is possible to control and manipu-
late chemical processes in real time, effectively programming the
plasma at the molecular level to behave as a sophisticated compu-
tational system.
6.1.3 Challenges. Despite playing a key role as an enabling
technology for DT, AI also brings important challenges, in particu-
lar those related to the use of generative AI and LLMs. For example,
LLMs can be slower than traditional question answering (QA)
systems, in part because of the latency of the

se of generative AI and LLMs. For example,
LLMs can be slower than traditional question answering (QA)
systems, in part because of the latency of the request to the applica-
tion programming interface (API). Moreover, organizations have
expressed concerns about the security of their data; if any dialogues
between users of the QA system and the tool go through the servers
of the organization providing that API service, that undermines the
conﬁdential nature of the data, especially if the API service provider
uses that data to train their models. Finally, for some applications,

ments. Many of the more powerful LLMs are based on APIs that
require an Internet connection. Some models exist that can be
hosted locally, but they are less powerful. One can also train
smaller language models for a particular task, but that may
require access to signiﬁcant computing infrastructure. More gener-
ally, when generative AI is integrated into DTs, we need to ensure
that the trustworthiness is not hindered by black-box deep genera-
tive models, especially when DTs need to make real-time decisions.
Additional challenges related to the use of AI in DTs include
(1) the lack of data to train a high-ﬁdelity generative model and
to update the model in real time and (2) the model’s generalization
ability to unusual or extreme conditions.

6.1.4 Potential Solutions. A potential solution to the challenge
of retrieving and processing data from different datasets is the user
of AI agents combining natural language interfaces with machine
learning back-end services. AI agents (also known as cognitive
assistants) can assist the user to seamlessly and quickly retrieve
information from different sources, which can be applied through-
out the system’s lifecycle, from design [174] to operations [175].
For example, QA systems allow for information retrieval from
multiple data sources in natural language. However, traditional
QA systems based on question intent classi ﬁcation, parameter
extraction, and predeﬁned queries and answer templates lack scal-
ability and ﬂexibility. LLMs have been recently used to signiﬁ-
cantly expand the capabilities of information retrieval and QA
systems. LLM-based systems can now be

ibility. LLMs have been recently used to signiﬁ-
cantly expand the capabilities of information retrieval and QA
systems. LLM-based systems can now be integrated into AI
agents to interpret natural language questions, retrieve the relevant
information from an information space, and generate natural lan-
guage answers, without the need for prespecifying a set of known
question types [176].
More generally, despite the black-box nature of deep generative
models, their unique capability of learning complex, high-
dimensional data distributions can help ensure the robustness and
reliability of DTs’decisions. For example, we can leverage gener-
ative models to learn the high-dimensional geometric uncertainties
of fabricated parts [177] or uncertainties of the physical twin’s
future state [161,166] and consider these uncertainties during the
decision-making process. This will allow more robust and reliable
control of the physical twin’s outcomes.
6.1.5 Proposed Research Directions. Although th

sion-making process. This will allow more robust and reliable
control of the physical twin’s outcomes.
6.1.5 Proposed Research Directions. Although the role of AI
in the context of DTs has been recognized [178], there has been
limited focus on how DTs can generate sufﬁciently large training
datasets to enhance AI training and testing. Speciﬁcally in military
and mission scenarios, DT models can impact mission scenarios by
accelerating the development process and reducing the time and
cost required for AI training [179].
Further research is required on the integration of DTs with AI to
allow the development of predictive capabilities by DTs. One of the
strongest advantages of using DT is cases when the physical system
is not accessible. An example of such an application might be space
systems.
While DT research has made signiﬁcant strides in areas like mod-
eling, control, and predictive AI techniques, the full potential of
generative AI in DTs is yet to be exploited. Besides integratin

in areas like mod-
eling, control, and predictive AI techniques, the full potential of
generative AI in DTs is yet to be exploited. Besides integrating
existing generative models, more fundamental research is required
to ensure the accuracy, efﬁciency, and reliability of these models,
especially in complex, real-time environments. Moreover, as the
ﬁeld of generative AI continues to evolve rapidly, the DT commu-
nity must stay abreast of these advancements to fully leverage their
capabilities.
6.2 Business Case Analysis. The business case analysis topic
in the RFI stated that comments should focus on“foundational
research cost; evaluate value/return on investment (ROI); cost and
time to implement”[8]. We interpreted this topic to focus on the sig-
niﬁcant barriers, particularly regarding business case development,
implementation challenges, and conceptual misunderstandings that
prevent small and medium manufacturers (SMMs) to realize the full
potential of DTs and Industry 4.0 solutions.

, and conceptual misunderstandings that
prevent small and medium manufacturers (SMMs) to realize the full
potential of DTs and Industry 4.0 solutions. This includes under-
standing the ROI of DT from a business perspective.
6.2.1 Topic Importance. Despite the advantages of DT and
Industry 4.0, SMMs face low Industry 4.0 readiness [180] due to
challenges in understanding how DTs optimize operations,
enhance product development, and improve maintenance processes.
This is compounded by a lack of business case analysis studies
demonstrating ROI, difﬁculties in identifying suitable applications,
and issues with compatible software solutions. Furthermore, SMMs
often lack clarity on where to begin, what steps are involved, and
what resources are needed, which stalls progress and deters manu-
facturers from pursuing DT initiatives. A higher understanding of
business cases for using Industry 4.0 solutions, ROI, cost, and
implementation timeline is essential to prepare SMMs for investing
in such

standing of
business cases for using Industry 4.0 solutions, ROI, cost, and
implementation timeline is essential to prepare SMMs for investing
in such capabilities [181]. As purpose-driven systems, DTs must
align with theﬁdelity, frequency, and scope needed to solve speciﬁc
problems. Excessive detail or overly broad boundaries can unneces-
sarily increase costs and complexity, delaying value realization.
SMMs need accessible tools and frameworks to evaluate whether
DT adoption isﬁnancially and operationally justiﬁed. Addressing
these business case gaps is critical to improving Industry 4.0
readiness.

share the same capability to replicate physical systems in virtual

labeling of simulation models as DTs and vice versa [184]. Unlike

the disparate models of the system. Ideally, a DT would be a part
of the digital engineering infrastructure. Embedding DTs within

6.2.3 Challenges. The barriers to DT adoption for SMMs are
multifaceted. One major challenge is the lack of robust business
case analyses that demonstrate ROI, identify suitable applications,
and outline cost–beneﬁt metrics. Without clear economic justif-
ication, SMMs remain hesitant to invest in DT capabilities.
Additionally, SMMs often lack structured implementation path-
ways. The absence of clear guidance regarding initial steps, neces-
sary resources, and incremental milestones leads to confusion and
delays. Further complicating this issue is the challenge of balancing

steps, neces-
sary resources, and incremental milestones leads to confusion and
delays. Further complicating this issue is the challenge of balancing
ﬁdelity, update frequency, and scope— factors that, when mis-
aligned, introduce unnecessary costs and complexity. The skills
gap among IT/OT professionals also presents a signiﬁcant hurdle.
It is often a struggle to estimate the labor, expertise, and resources
required to develop and deploy DTs. Without realistic expectations,
projects may face delays, inefﬁciencies, or failure. Finally, the per-
sistent confusion between simulations and DTs exacerbates these
issues, creating a conceptual barrier that limits the proper imple-
mentation and utilization of DT technologies.

SMMs in adopting DTs, potential solutions could include the devel-
opment of decision-making frameworks, such as decision trees, to

6.3 Data. The data topic in the RFI requested comments on
“encourage[ing] adoption of data management best practices” [8]
and further suggested focusing on“governance methods for da

RFI requested comments on
“encourage[ing] adoption of data management best practices” [8]
and further suggested focusing on“governance methods for data
collection, curation, sharing and usage; shared public datasets and
repositories; real-time data integration” [8]. We interpreted this to
mean establishing the relationships between the DT and the
digital thread across a digital engineering ecosystem, and how to
ensure interoperability between data sets and data sources.
6.3.1 Topic Importance. The ultimate goal of digital transfor-
mation is to have the right data, in the right place, at the right
time, and in the right form to make the best decision [189]. It is
often taken for granted that data and informationﬂows are at the
heart of all digitalization efforts [190]. Therefore, proper data man-
agement practices and governance methods as related to DTs are
essential to ensure that the beneﬁts of DTs are reaped not only at
a subsystem level but at an enterprise and system-of-system l

as related to DTs are
essential to ensure that the beneﬁts of DTs are reaped not only at
a subsystem level but at an enterprise and system-of-system level
as part of a digital engineering ecosystem.
6.3.2 Current State of the Topic. Research has shown that
within enterprises, over 90% of data exchanges are not governed
and around 90% of data element exchanges lack digital connectivity
[190,191]. Additionally, key vessels of data such as models and
documents are often spread across dozens or hundreds of disparate
storage locations for stand-alone efforts [192]. Often academic liter-
ature related to DT primarily focus on DT development without
considering how itﬁts into a complete digital engineering ecosys-
tem. Therefore, a primary hurdle that must be overcome for success-
ful DT development and implementation is the adoption of data
management best practices that enable the realization of the
digital thread across a digital engineering ecosystem.
6.3.3 Challenges. The barriers to goo

agement best practices that enable the realization of the
digital thread across a digital engineering ecosystem.
6.3.3 Challenges. The barriers to good data management and
governance primarily exist around how data are collected, curated,
stored, shared, and integrated into DTs not only of the speciﬁc phys-
ical twin but also across multiple levels of DTs and physical twins
(e.g., systems of systems and system-of-systems DTs (SoSDTs)).
Data collection methods are diverse, and ensuring the“right data”
are collected at the“right time” to meet the requirements of the
DT or SoSDT without being unreasonably expensive to collect is
challenging [144,193–195]. Curating the data before being piped
to a DT may be necessary due to data throughput issues between
the data collection devices (e.g., sensors, prognostics subsystems)
and the hardware the DT runs on or to reduce the amount of data
that DT must process in a resource constrained environment
among other reasons [196]. Sharing data between

DT runs on or to reduce the amount of data
that DT must process in a resource constrained environment
among other reasons [196]. Sharing data between DTs and/or
SoSDTs and using data among DTs and/or SoSDTs can be prob-
lematic especially if a common ontology or an ontological conver-
sion schema has not been established [197]. Making datasets from
physical twins available to the public in repositories is another chal-
lenge due in part to the potential sensitivity of the data among other
reasons [198,199].
6.3.4 Potential Solutions. When determining what data will be
used to create the DT, a potential solution is to categorize the data as
being related to four different phases of DT implementation as
deﬁned in the 4Rs framework: representation, replication, reality,
and relational [150]. Prior to realization of the DT, it is advisable
to deploy a methodology to identify disparate and ungoverned ele-
ments of data within the system of interest. Once the elements of
data are identiﬁed,

deploy a methodology to identify disparate and ungoverned ele-
ments of data within the system of interest. Once the elements of
data are identiﬁed, they can be systematically categorized as relating
to the representation, replication, reality, and relational phases of the
DT, and consequently, the digital thread will be enabled alongside
the DT. DEMA is a methodology that could be used to identify and
visually map the data elements that make up the different phases of
the DT [190].
6.3.5 Proposed Research Directions. Future research with
case studies is needed to investigate the relationship between solu-
tions such as the 4Rs framework and DEMA in the development of
DTs within a wholistic digital engineering ecosystem. Methodolo-
gies and analytical tools beyond the 4R framework and DEMA
are also needed to address other questions related to DT data
usage. Overall, the academic literature concerning the relationship
between DT, data management, and data governance is in its
infancy,

ed to DT data
usage. Overall, the academic literature concerning the relationship
between DT, data management, and data governance is in its
infancy, and a great deal of work is needed to progress this research

6.4 National Digital Twin Research and Development
Ecosystem. The RFI called out the need for “establish[ing] a
national DT R&D ecosystem” with potential focus areas including
“collaborations across agencies to identify and address foundational
research gaps and opportunities that spans areas such as biomedical
sciences [… ] smart and connected communities, scientiﬁc discov-
ery, agriculture, military & mission planning, as well as common
mathematical, statistical, and computational foundations” [8]. We
interpreted this to mean the strategic utilization and synthesis of
the outputs of various DT R&D efforts across industry, academia,
and government for the beneﬁt of the nation as a whole.
6.4.1 Topic Impor

ynthesis of
the outputs of various DT R&D efforts across industry, academia,
and government for the beneﬁt of the nation as a whole.
6.4.1 Topic Importance. Establishing a national DT R&D eco-
system is important to ensure that R&D efforts are not duplicative,
are interoperable, and address important research gaps within and
between research communities. The literature has many examples
of DT R&D efforts funded by different agencies or even the same
agency that largely come up with the same results. While replication
studies can be useful to ensure that initial results of a DT R&D
effort are repeatable and not an anomaly, conducting the same
research from scratch is often not productive and can take resources
away from novel DT R&D efforts. Many different DT R&D chal-
lenges exist, as was listed in the RFI [8] and throughout the litera-
ture [200–206], but collaboration across funding agencies, across
government agencies and departments, and across industries is
still in its infancy. A

ure [200–206], but collaboration across funding agencies, across
government agencies and departments, and across industries is
still in its infancy. A well-organized national DT R&D ecosystem
may help to alleviate such issues, speed DT advancement, and
hasten DT adoption across many industries with the goal of realiz-
ing promised DT beneﬁts.
6.4.2 Current State of the Topic.Research and development in
the ﬁ
eld of DT are being conducted across industry, academia, and
government. The RFI [8] speciﬁcally called out the need for a
national DT R&D ecosystem to ensure that work being done
across various agencies can be reused and shared efﬁciently. The
reuse of DT R&D across agencies would result in faster adoption
of DT across the nation.
For military and mission planning to make signiﬁcant advances, a
national DT R&D ecosystem must be established both for military
and defense systems and for the industrial and commercial systems
that support them. Mission engineering [207], planning, ope

lished both for military
and defense systems and for the industrial and commercial systems
that support them. Mission engineering [207], planning, operations
and maintenance, and many other activities will be enhanced with
better DT development and implementation [38]. Already, some
work has pointed toward the effectiveness of DTs in improving out-
comes for route planning [39], maintenance, and so on. Further,

tries, government agencies, and

6.4.3 Challenges. A signiﬁcant challenge that faces the estab-
lishment of a national DT R&D ecosystem is the cultural and tech-
nical divides between different industries. Even the deﬁnition of a
DT can change from industry to industry or research group to
research group [15,31,210]. Shared data ontologies and DT ontolo-
gies are needed to better interoperate between disparate communi-
ties [211]. An improved model for the Digital Twin Consortium
[29] with a signiﬁcantly reduced ﬁnancial barrier to entry for
researchers and nonproﬁts is needed if the Digital Twin Consortium
is to live up to its promise of being the single hub of DT research.
6.4.4 Potential Solutions. A diverse R&D ecosystem can facil-
itate the ﬂow of ideas and expertise toward relevant research and
technology to address energy use and more sustainable systems.
AI and DTs can add to the R&D ecosystem through identifying
and quantifying the sources of energy and amount

energy use and more sustainable systems.
AI and DTs can add to the R&D ecosystem through identifying
and quantifying the sources of energy and amount of energy used
along with advancing monitoring and efﬁcient data collection and
analysis [212]. A DT an allow for better models that simultaneously
produce interactive information for energy demand, source and use
solutions [213].
From an organizational perspective, various collaborations have
formed and are being formed to facilitate the strategic utilization
and synthesis of the outputs of various DT R&D efforts across
industry, academia, and government. The Digital Twin Consortium
is a partnership between industry, academia, and government to
drive the direction of DTs within digital engineering adoption [29].
The Manufacturing U.S.A. Institutes were established in 2014 to be
the National Network for Manufacturing Innovation across acade-
mia, industry, and government [214], and various works have
been conducted at the Manufacturing U.

Network for Manufacturing Innovation across acade-
mia, industry, and government [214], and various works have
been conducted at the Manufacturing U.S.A institute for digital
manufacturing, MxD, to enable DT adoption across the manufactur-
ing industry as a whole [215]. In November 2024, it was announced
that a new institute would be created speciﬁcally for DT use in the
semiconductor industry [214].
For cross-cutting funding, a national clearinghouse of DT
research is needed to ensure that different federal agencies or
even within the same federal agency duplicative DT R&D efforts
are not undertaken and results of novel work are shared broadly.
Based upon our ownﬁrst-hand knowledge, already some efforts
within certain funding agencies such as the Of ﬁce of Naval
Research (ONR) are underway to coordinate DT R&D funding.
More coordination and sharing of R&D efforts will only beneﬁt
the greater DT community.

and sharing of R&D efforts will only beneﬁt
the greater DT community.
6.4.5 Proposed Research Directions. Greater synthesis across
national organizations in promoting the standardized exchange of
DT R&D knowledge is needed to accelerate the broad adoption
of DT. Future research could utilize text mining across academic lit-
erature databases to draw recurring topics and themes from an
aggregate analysis of DT subject matter experts. Previous work
has shown that such a methodology would be beneﬁcial in inform-
ing national industrial policy [214], and with the advent of genera-
tive AI, this process could be automated so that an application could
be developed to track DT developments across publicly available
literature and articles. The results of this aggregate analysis could
be made available to the public to ensure a democratization of
DT knowledge.

6.5 Digital Twin Behavior Modeling. While the RFI did not
include a topic about DT behavior modeling, we felt it was impor-
tant to include this as a separate topic area because DT behavior
modeling is a challenging area of system modeling. The accurate
representation of a system, by deﬁnition, includes the system’s
behavior. Thus, we believe that DT behavior modeling is a
worthy topic of further research.
6.5.1 Topic Importance. DT technology requires the digital
model to be structurally, logically, and behaviorally representative
of the physical system. Modeling the system behavior is a key com-
ponent of the representation of a physical system in a digital con-
struct [216]. System behavior brings in the functions of the
system in order to provide the capabilities intended for the system
to perform. System behavior is challenging to model as this
involves the logical and physical functions of the system, including
hardware, software, and operators/user interactions [

hallenging to model as this
involves the logical and physical functions of the system, including
hardware, software, and operators/user interactions [ 217,218].
Incorporating system behavior as part of the DT makes the DT
truly representative of the physical/logical system.
6.5.2 Current State of the Topic.A DT contains the structural
and the behavioral elements of the systems. System behavior
involves the full interactions of the system hardware, software,
environments, and humans [216]. System behavior is generally
time dependent, which brings in simulation to accurately represent
the system behavior in a DT. There are a number of methods that
provide some level of system behavior.
SysML provides models with state diagrams and activity dia-
grams that show the relationship of the activities and the transitions
between the activities. The time domain representation is supported
in a simple fashion, but complex system behaviors are not well sim-
ulated in SysML [219,220].
Multidiscipli

e time domain representation is supported
in a simple fashion, but complex system behaviors are not well sim-
ulated in SysML [219,220].
Multidisciplinary design optimization (MDO) [221–223] offers
an advancement in representing the system interactions in a
partial differential equation (PDE) basis. This provides some
insight into model behavior based on parameter changes. Program-
ming time transitions are possible in these models, but it is difﬁcult
when solving multiple PDEs. There are various vendor tools that
offer this capability more as an equation integration approach
than as a system behavior representation.
Discrete event simulation (DES) is another approach that brings
in Monte Carlo analysis [224,225]. These simulations have a time
basis, focusing on the processﬂow in the system. They are really
good with the statistics on theseﬂows but not necessarily on the
full scope of system behavior as they focus on theﬂow and tend
to simplify the subsystem functionality.
System dynam

seﬂows but not necessarily on the
full scope of system behavior as they focus on theﬂow and tend
to simplify the subsystem functionality.
System dynamics is a modeling approach that focuses on theﬂow
of commodities (i.e., stocks andﬂ
ows) between nodes [226–228].
This representation has good results in modeling social systems,
supply chain management, and so on. These models capture the
network of interactions between nodes but not necessarily the
logic within a node. Expanding these networks out to fully represent
all possible system responses with a full system dynamics represen-
tation within each node (multiple nested nodes) is a challenge to the
system behavior representation.
State analysis modeling (SAM) provides a solution to fully model
the system behavior through a system state variable solution. SAM
represents the systems as a set of state models. These models
include hardware state models of all subsystems of the system,
the software algorithms for the subsystems, and the e

set of state models. These models
include hardware state models of all subsystems of the system,
the software algorithms for the subsystems, and the event timeline
for system execution. The SAM is an executable model, i.e., a
simulation, of the system capturing the full scope of system beha-
vior. Hardware and software state transitions are all fully repre-
sented. Human interactions can be represented as requests from
the simulation to the model user or as state models in the system.
These fully executable models provide the ability to run against a
deﬁned timeline in faster than real-time mode. This provides for
the representation of complex state transitions with multiple scenar-
ios possible depending on a variety of systems states. Multiple exe-
cutions of the system can be run to explore numerous system state

6.5.3 Challenges. Accurate modeling of system behavior
requires an comprehensive knowledge of the system in an extensive
set of operational scenarios. These scenarios are often nuanced with
numerous subtle differences that can have large variations in system
performance. The operational contexts may not be fully understood
until after the system is put into operation, also limiting the knowl-
edge needed for comprehensive system behavior modeling. In addi-
tion, system behavior is generally understood through a limited set
of test data that does not fully represent the operational context. This
understanding is limited by operational environments not fully
present in testing along with tim

oes not fully represent the operational context. This
understanding is limited by operational environments not fully
present in testing along with time and budget generally not available
to fully test and evaluate the system in all possible variations of
behavior to numerous different stimuli. These tests can provide
some basic model validation, but not extensive behavior modeling
validation. Depending on the system, heritage data may be available
from previous versions though understanding all the variations of
previous system performance requires new test and evaluation
subject to the limits just described. Analysis of physical or logical
characteristics is also a source of system knowledge, though
limited in the application to system behavior since the analysis is
typically not of the full system. Several modeling approaches
become computationally expensive or impractical in the representa-
tion of system behavior as the number of equations to solve, inter-
actions to capture, incre

putationally expensive or impractical in the representa-
tion of system behavior as the number of equations to solve, inter-
actions to capture, increase substantially.
6.5.4 Potential Solutions. Investigation into the system beha-
vior may be constructed as a set of PDEs representing the system
functionality. Mathematical category theory provides a construct
to identify and deﬁne a complete set of system functionality equa-
tions. Completeness is a key to properly representing system beha-
vior. The absence of a function, even a minor function, and the
associations interactions can dramatically change the system beha-
vior. The ability to deﬁne PDEs to represent the calculus of system
behavior is needed to advance this solution space area.
DES shows a good representation of the processﬂow, commod-
ity interactions, between system subsystems or functions. The rep-
resentations do not include the internal functionality and so do not
fully represent the system behavior. Expanding DES to

ems or functions. The rep-
resentations do not include the internal functionality and so do not
fully represent the system behavior. Expanding DES to fully repre-
sent the internal functions would provide a solution in the statistical
analysis of the solution space.
System dynamics that model theﬂow of commodities is another
modeling approach that may be expanded to model system behavior
more comprehensively. These models would require some exten-
sive modeling of the interactions within the functions as well as
between system functions and the environment. All of these solu-
tion sets, MDO, DES, and system dynamics, would require simula-
tion engines that can handle solving large set of equations in a
timely manner. Solution sets that take weeks to solve may not be
practical in the modeling of system behavior.
The most promising approach to modeling system behavior is the
SAM. The modeling of system behavior involves the identiﬁcation
and use of system state variables in the construct

to modeling system behavior is the
SAM. The modeling of system behavior involves the identiﬁcation
and use of system state variables in the construct and execution of
the DT. SAM is an emerging system state variable modeling
approach that provides a digital representation of the system beha-
vior in an interactive simulation [213]. SAM includes the software
algorithm, hardware state machines, and mission/ﬂight timelines
representing the integrated system behavior in an accurate represen-
tation of the physical system. Operator/user input can be supported
in the execution of this DT model providing interaction with the
user input as well as software to fully encompass DT behavior of
the system. These models capture the hardware and software
states providing the only current solution that is computationally
efﬁcient.

that show promise in more comprehensive modeling of system

The DT of the system behavior based on SAM has been applied
in a few examples. This provides a limited set of data on applica-

construction of accurate hardware state machines is essential in the
model achieving DT behavior representation. Operator/user interac-

DT technology is in an emergent state, and there are likely other
methods that have yet to be deﬁned. Research into the behavioral
characteristics of systems in speciﬁc domains may lead to other

6.6 International. The international topic in the RFI asked for
comment on “international collaborations on DT” [8] and speciﬁ-
cally suggested focusing on “global scale DTs across foreign
markets; global issues and DT development consensus standards;
opportunities for international collaboration (e.g., European Union’s
Horizon 2020 program funding DT projects)” [8]. The perspective
of the RFI is distinctly United States centric, and thus, we inter-
preted this topic as loo

n 2020 program funding DT projects)” [8]. The perspective
of the RFI is distinctly United States centric, and thus, we inter-
preted this topic as looking at bridging between USA DT research-
ers and industry, and partners outside of the United States.
6.6.1 Topic Importance. International DT collaboration is crit-
ical to both improving DT implementation and results for industry,
and for national and multinational security. While there may be
some divergence between different countries or economic blocs
in how DT is being implemented, and while diversity is often ben-
eﬁcial to larger R&D efforts, it is important that DTs be interoper-
able across global markets and to allow unfettered international
collaboration. Some US funding sources such as ONR Global
have recognized the importance of international collaboration and
are beginning to fund researchers in several countries on DT topics.
The utility DTs offer for operations support is widely described
throughout this document, but fr

fund researchers in several countries on DT topics.
The utility DTs offer for operations support is widely described
throughout this document, but from an international partnership
perspective, there is a signiﬁcant need for a shared operational
picture and maintaining transparency across stakeholders. When
considering the operational picture, different stakeholders may
have different assets and resources available to create international
solutions to local problems. DTs that monitor the use of assets in the
ﬁeld and provide contextual awareness of functionality to those
partners will signiﬁcantly speed up response times and improve efﬁ-
ciencies of those operations by eliminating the need to regularly
communicate status and request support. In effect, a DT–physical
asset pair allows people on the periphery of direct operations to
act autonomously in their support to the activity. From a

6.6.3 Challenges. Several signiﬁcant challenges to interna-
tional DT collaboration exist. Chief among them is poor multina-
tional funding models that bridge between the EC/EU, the United
States, and other countries. While Horizon 2020 funded DT devel-
opment in Europe, and organizations like ONR Global are begin-
ning to fund researchers to work on DT projects in several
countries in different parts of the world, we are unaware of any sys-
tematic large-scale DT R&D funding schemes that bridg

Another challenge is the nature of DTs created by multinational
industries. While both Boeing and Airbus are developing DTs
[270], it is unlikely that they will share DT advances with compet-
itors such as Embraer S.A. (a Brazilian multinational aerospace
company), the Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China, Ltd.
(Comac), or the PJSC United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) (a
Russian aerospace conglomerate). International standardization
efforts such as those driven by ISO, IEC, and others are useful to
set the groundwork for DT development and the National Institute
of Standards and Technology (NIST) (a US standards organization)
efforts for manufacturing DTs are building upon international stan-
dards development [276,
277]. However, our observations of indus-
trial DT efforts indicate that many companies are forging ahead
with th

277]. However, our observations of indus-

Historically, defense systems have struggled to balance security,
standards, and proprietary equipment. As a result, defense
equipment often does not fully leverage international integration
standards. The result of this coupled with different international
languages, units of measure, and other factors can result in interop-
erability issues. The end result can drive increased costs and com-
plexity of development, test and evaluation, training, and failure
to maintain a shared operational picture and full transparency
across international partners [278]. While DT efforts driven by
NATO and national defense organizations are underway, much
remains to be done to realize the beneﬁt of DTs on an international
level in defense applications.

6.6.4 Potential Solutions. Several potential solutions exist, and
some are already well established although not yet widely adopted.
For instance, the Digital Twin Consortium [29] is intended to be a
clearing house and a driver of interoperability of DTs between
researchers, companies, and countries. The standardization efforts
by ISO and others are slowly driving more DT developers to imple-
ment standards to allow for easier interoperability. From our obser-
vations and professional experience, researchers from different
countries gathering together at conferences and workshops
focused on DT, which is a large driver of international cooperation
and collaboration in DT development and implementation.

Research is needed in new and innovative ways to spur interna-

6.7.1 Topic Importance. Long-term development of DT assets
is foundational for the development of future SoS tradespace design
and exploration tools. The tradespace is formulated as an objective
space representation of the capabilities of various conceptual design
concepts. Each concept is formulated upon the basis of a DT asset of
potential and existing technologies. DTs informed by their physical
asset counterparts enable real-world input into this analysis and can
support digital agents that can explore and exploit the tradespace to
provide informed decision-making [283]. Providing accurate trade-
space exploration and exploitation capabilities is essential for many
mission-level programmatic decisions [284–286].
DT test environments that

trade-

DT test environments that can be repeatedly used for many
decades are needed to have reliable benchmark systems that DT per-
formance can be tested against. While many research groups devel-
oping DT technologies and producing DT innovations use custom
simulations as stand-ins for physical systems and some have real
physical twins that are used to develop and test DTs [287], a
systematic, rigorous, and repeatable DT development and test
environment used across many test groups that currently do not
exist. Benchmarking is common in other disciplines [288–292]
but has not yet been widely standardized and adopted for DTs.

6.7.3 Challenges. Since its inception, DT has always been
intended to exist in all four phases of the product lifecycle:
create, build, operate and sustain, and dispose [1]. However, there
is a common misconception that DTs can only be created once a
physical twin exists [38]. This belief is understandable, given that
most discussions and applications of DTs occur when there is a tan-
gible system to work with. However, a DT exists from the begin-
ning of a product’s development and, in fact, should precede the
physical twin, and it is a false notion to claim otherwise. The
essence of a true DT lies in its ability to represent something that
is intended to exist physically. A long-term view of DT versus phys-
ical twin is needed to ensure that DT

in its ability to represent something that
is intended to exist physically. A long-term view of DT versus phys-
ical twin is needed to ensure that DTs are being developed through-
out the product lifecycle.
Many current DT testbeds and benchmarks focus on only one
physical twin or one industry. There is a need to have standardized
testbeds and benchmarks for speciﬁc industries and between indus-
tries, but a signiﬁcant challenge is what physical twins those test-
beds should be developed around and what sensors and other data
are needed from the testbeds to ensure that the testbeds remain
useful for decades to come. Some early testbed efforts now
appear to be too simplistic for modern complex DTs.
6.7.4 Potential Solutions. DT development methods such as
Bickford et al.’s efforts [38] are needed to ensure that DTs are
developed in tandem with physical twins. While some methods
have been proposed, method reﬁnement and expansion is needed.
Further, validation of the methods is necessary

with physical twins. While some methods
have been proposed, method reﬁnement and expansion is needed.
Further, validation of the methods is necessary to demonstrate
ROI so that a business case can be made for adoption of this
approach. Then a battery of case studies should be curated to aid
in convincing management that this approach is a soundﬁnancial
decision for companies to adopt.
Standardized and repeatable DT testbeds and benchmarks should
be developed based on common systems in speciﬁc industries. For
instance, a standard 100 kW diesel generator may serve as a good
physical twin testbed to develop, test, and benchmark DTs meant
for use with reciprocating engine generators. However, speciﬁc
industries will need to collectively make decisions on what physical
twins should become the testbeds and what benchmarks should be
established.

tional model early in development, capturing the product concept
for further reﬁnement. As the project progresses, the DT incorpo-
rates design speciﬁcations and performance data. During operation
and sustainment, it serves as a tool for real-time monitoring and
optimization of the ongoing performance of the product [101].
When considering the journey of a DT throughout a product’s life-
cycle, it is essential to understand its evolution and adaptability.
Research is needed to show how DTs evolve with the product
throughout its lifecycle, highlighting their adaptability and utility
from conception to disposal. Furthermore, the value of having a
DT before the physical entity exists should be illustrated.
DT testbed and benchmark committees should be established in
various professional societies across many different industries to
help select physical twins that will serve as the testbed systems.
Research is needed to determi

ssional societies across many different industries to
help select physical twins that will serve as the testbed systems.
Research is needed to determine what benchmarks are appropriate,
what sensors should be placed and where on testbed physical twins,
and how data should be captured, stored, and delivered to DTs
under testing. Standardization efforts such as those discussed in
Secs. 6.6 and 6.10 must also include DT testbed and benchmarking
standards. Additionally, standards being developed for DTs should
be implemented into testbeds, but research will be needed to convert
existing testbeds to new standards so thatﬁelded DTs validated on
testbeds using old standards can retain their validated status when
testbeds are upgraded to new standards.

advances much faster than legal or regulatory frameworks, even
when there is pressure for such frameworks. For example, in the
United States, “national-level actions on AI regulation in the U.S.
have come exclusively from the executive branch” [317]. Even
though bipartisan bills on AI have been proposed, the lack of Con-
gressional action leaves such technology subject to a lack of clarity
and legal challenges. Especially following the US Supreme Court’s
overturning of the Chevron doctrine in 2024 and reducing the def-

strategies from the creation of previous regulatory regimes and

social circumstances with various public agencies having overlap-
ping authority”[323]. Fortunately, there are international examples
that may pave the way, such as the European Union’s AI Act [324]
and U.S. government recommendations for federal regulation over
emerging technologies [325].
Even without a regulatory framework speciﬁc to DTs, DTs are
subject to the regulatory regime that applies to the sector in

be aware of a variety of issues including data ownership, causation,
and liability [
327] and especially so where General Data Protection

particular, a regulatory framework must consider cybersecurity,

risk, and external requirements such as responsibility for data
quality and effective function [ 330–332]. Privacy and other
ethical concerns arise if a DT uses human data or characteristics
and the economic costs may mean that DTs are only used by pros-
perous companies or governments, which can lead to inherent ineq-
uities [315,333]. Thus, “if [organizations] want to build trust and

uities [315,333]. Thus, “if [organizations] want to build trust and

In the absence and awaiting of legal frameworks to be put in
place, some argue that the establishment of industry standards
and best practices may offer quality assurance. These standards
and best practices become increasingly important in applications
such as critical infrastructure and other areas where DTs are being
applied [335–337]. The risks posed by DTs differ depending on
the nature of the DT and the complexity of the system it is twinning;
a regulatory regime will need to take such differences into account,
while also facilitating the growth of sustainable DTs [338].

6.9 Promote Responsible Development and Use of Digital
Twins. The RFI asked for comment on“ethical use of [DTs]; iden-
tifying ethical issues, mitigating and biases with respect to data
ownership, intellectual property and privacy” [8]. We interpreted
this to mean research is needed on how to ethically use DTs from
the perspectives of data ownership, intellectual property, and also
compliance and responsibility.
6.9.1 Topic Importance. Responsibility is a core component of
DT implementation and use [3

6.9.1 Topic Importance. Responsibility is a core component of
DT implementation and use [340–342]. DT developers must ensure
that DTs are applied by ethically and securely and that any potential
ethical and security issues are mitigated [200,343]. This includes
both a focus on the functionality of the end system, which the DT
is used responsibly and with care to the impact of how the informa-
tion is applied, as well as to source information such as intellectual
property, data ownership, and privacy [314,332]. As a DT can
model both proprietary system components and highly sensitive
ones, careless or unethical creation, protection, or application of a
DT can expose private information or mischaracterize a system
leading to faulty decisions [ 332,344]. While responsible and
ethical data use and privacy are a core topic in many domains,
limited research has focused on it within the DT context
[334
,345,346].

6.9.2 Current State of the Topic.Some DT deployments have
made efforts to ensure they are responsibly and ethically used. It
should be noted that the physical twin has a signiﬁcant impact on
what “responsible” and “ethical” means for the DT. A DT of a
Navy ship for maintenance purposes appears to have different
responsible and ethical requirements than a DT of a human for a
healthcare setting. Depending upon the industry and the purpose
of the DT, some discussions have appeared in the literature
around responsible and ethical use of DTs. However, the ethics
and responsible use discussion is still in its infancy.
One example of a DT that has responsibility as part of its core
development and is the US Navy’s Smart Ship Systems Design
(S3D) platform. This DT uses Formal Object Classiﬁcation for
Understanding Ships (FOCUS) and is an example of efforts

In the healthcare ﬁeld, signiﬁcant and ongoing work has been
conducted in developing ethical DTs to reduce bias and keep
patient data safe and secure. For instance, the“personal”DT is envi-
sioned as being safe and secure [346]. DTs of individual patients
hold the promise of making healthcare more data-driven and

6.9.3 Challenges. What makes responsible implementation
and use of DT challenging is the variability of application uses
and therefore the ambiguity of what responsibility means. Depend-
ing on data sensitivity and privacy in creating the DT and system
sensitivity in application, responsibility can mean protection of pro-
prietary information used to create the DT, ethical creation of the
DT that mitigates bias in design, storage and protection of the DT
itself, use of the DT that ensures correct interpretation, use of the
DT that ensures secure interpretation that does not introduce vulner-
abilities to the system, ethical use of the DT that anticipates and
accounts for bias in the application of the DT, ethical use of the
DT that protects privacy of the input data, or ethical use of the
DT that provides adequate protection of privacy for individuals
and systems. Many other such interpretati

acy of the input data, or ethical use of the
DT that provides adequate protection of privacy for individuals
and systems. Many other such interpretations also fall under respon-
sibility with DTs, and many of these categories constitute spectrums
of actual need. Thus, responsibility in DT implementation and use
lacks well-deﬁned guidance that is widely applicable across differ-
ent DT use cases [200,313,340–343,345,352–356].
6.9.4 Potential Solutions. Frameworks for speciﬁc industries
and use cases and that bridge between many industries and use
cases are needed to develop repeatable methods that result in
responsible DTs. These frameworks must help to guide DT devel-
opers through ethical and bias quagmires efﬁciently and within
accepted ethical standards and boundaries. DT developers as a
whole cannot be expected to become experts on the ethics of
responsible DT development, but the greater community can ask
DT developers to use frameworks that will help them to ensure
compliance wit

e ethics of
responsible DT development, but the greater community can ask
DT developers to use frameworks that will help them to ensure
compliance with ethical norms.
6.9.5 Proposed Research Directions. One aspect of responsi-
ble and ethical DT development and use especially for DTs destined
for use with engineered systems as the physical twins that appears
to be underexplored in the literature is engaging ethicists and
psychologists to work with engineers and other DT developers in
producing frameworks and methods to guide DT development
and use from a responsible and ethical perspective. Efforts in
other ﬁelds that have brought ethicist, psychologists, and engineers
together such as human–machine teaming have resulted in useful
advances [360–363]. More formal engagement with ethicists and
psychologists on responsible and ethical DTs is likely to be
productive.

development around ethical and responsible DTs. There is cur

6.10.1 Topic Importance. The sudden proliferation of publica-
tions on DTs could be counterproductive to the advancement of
the state of the art in anyﬁeld of application for DTs due in part
to the lack of standardization. The term“DT” is sometimes used
to replace the terms“modeling and simulation,” and the objectives
and functionalities of the published DTs are often unclear [185].
Naturally, this points to a need area for standardization, which
can also contribute to the guidance needs pointed out throughout
Sec. 6. Standardization can span terminology, responsible design,
and application, just as examples. Further, within a system, each
subsystem or component could have a DT developed by different
manufacturers, so clear and detailed standards will ensure that all
DTs can be connected together to form a larger system in a reliable,
secure, and res

nufacturers, so clear and detailed standards will ensure that all
DTs can be connected together to form a larger system in a reliable,
secure, and responsible way [364–370]. Such a concept is similar
to other areas of engineering such as power electronics-based
power distribution systems, like microgrids or transportation power
systems, where power converters from different manufacturers
work together to form the power system [371,372]. As compilation
is a common norm and can be expected in the case of DTs, account-
ing and planning for it through standardization is critical.
6.10.2 Current State of the Topic. The recently published
DoDI 5000.97 [28] clearly places DTs within the larger digital engi-
neering ecosystem, providing theﬁrst, basic DOD standard on this
topic. NIST has been investigating DTs for several years [276] and
recently launched a study to support DT ecosystems with new stan-
dards [277]. ISO has also put out a DT standard for manufacturing
[234], and a variety of ot

launched a study to support DT ecosystems with new stan-
dards [277]. ISO has also put out a DT standard for manufacturing
[234], and a variety of other standards discussed in Sec.6.6.2 can be
used for DT development [233,235–237]. Others have proposed
various frameworks and standards for a variety of industries in
the academic literature although true standardization has not yet
taken place [235,364,373]. Speciﬁc aspects of standardization that
DTs can use such as cryptographic and encryption standards
already exist more generally [374,375], but standardized adoption
in DTs has not yet happened. These various efforts show concrete
steps for standardization, although unifying the outputs and insights
of such efforts is critical to achieving actual standardization in
practice.
6.10.3 Challenges. A signiﬁcant challenge facing the standar-
dization of DTs is successfully convincing the broader DT commu-
nity to accept the proposed standards. While ISO and other
international organization

dization of DTs is successfully convincing the broader DT commu-

international organizations have advanced standards [ 234,237],
and NIST and other national standards governmental organizations
are actively working to develop new standards for speciﬁc indus-
tries [277], the broader DT community has not yet embraced any
existing or proposed standard [376]. In some cases, multiple DT
standards exist and overlap one another which increases confusion
[377]. Many DT papers recently published in the literature includ-
ing some of our own works do not acknowledge or make passing
reference to the standardization efforts that are underway
[38,39,378].
DT standards developers face the challenge of making standards
that both are applicable to wide swaths of industry and are speciﬁc
enough to be useful in practice. While some have found existing
standards from different standards organizations and focused on dif-
ferent use cases (not nec

o be useful in practice. While some have found existing
standards from different standards organizations and focused on dif-
ferent use cases (not necessarily speciﬁc to DTs) can be used to
develop DTs [233], there are not yet widely accepted standards
that work well for DTs in aerospace, healthcare, rail transportation,
energy systems, and so on. Some speciﬁc industries such as health-
care have started to coalesce around best practices, but other indus-

DT standards and should continue. International standards organi-

and have more in development. Additional efforts in developing

6.10.5 Proposed Research Directions. Future standards should
focus on the interoperability of DTs, with clear deﬁnitions of inputs
and outputs, connections, communication, and data exchange [379].
This should also cover responsibility where it can be concretely
deﬁned, such as in intellectual property and sensitivity tracking as
well as data sources. Furthermore, standardization must cover

6.11.1 Topic Importance. Sustainability has been a broadly
important topic in the mainstream literature for well over 50 years
with origins tracing back centuries [380–383]. Sustainability from
a DT pers

oadly
important topic in the mainstream literature for well over 50 years
with origins tracing back centuries [380–383]. Sustainability from
a DT perspective can be broadly grouped into two categories:
DTs that are used to drive sustainability goals of speciﬁc physical
twins or in speciﬁc industries, and making DTs themselves more
sustainable [384,385]. Both are important to the broader DT com-
munity because many industries and countries have sustainability
goals or requirements that DTs can help to achieve, and because
DTs may be a source of issues for sustainability.
6.11.2 Current State of the Topic. A search on IEEE Xplore
using the keywords“digital twin” and “sustainability” returns 374
papers, while using“digital twin” and “sustainable” 799 papers is
found as of December 8, 2024. The majority of the published
literature addresses different aspects of using DT to improve
sustainability in various ﬁ
elds including consumer electronics,
engineering management, agriculture, transpor

ifferent aspects of using DT to improve
sustainability in various ﬁ
elds including consumer electronics,
engineering management, agriculture, transportation, urban plan-
ning, industry applications, and more [2,141,341,384,386–398].
As sustainability has become an important topic in many technical
ﬁelds, DT technology is considered a potential ally in reaching rel-
evant goals set by governments and organizations around the world.
In addition to DT for sustainability, some works have been pub-
lished on the sustainability of the DT, such as Ref. [385] where the
authors proposed a taxonomy for the DT evolution, which draws
attention to how the development of DT technology itself can
become more energy efﬁcient. Others have approached DT sustain-

cally sustainable [385] or improving the sustainability of DT data
collection [399] among others [400]. However, limited literature
exists on making DTs themselves sustainable.
