Design Solution Definition Process: A process that translates the outputs of the Logical 
Decomposition Process into a design solution definition that is in a form consistent with the 
product life-cycle phase and product layer location in the system structure and that will satisfy 
phase success criteria. (Sources: NPR 7123.1 and NASA/SP-2016-6105, Revision 2). 
 
Logical Decomposition Process: A process used to improve understanding of the defined 
technical requirements and the relationships among the requirements (e.g., functional, 
behavioral, performance, and temporal) and to transform the defined set of technical 
requirements into a set of logical decomposition models and their associated set of derived 
technical requirements for lower levels of the system and for input to the Design Solution 
Process. (Sources: NPR 7123.1 and NASA/SP-2016-6105, Revision 2)

Solution

Measure of Effectiveness (MOE): A measure by which a stakeholder's expectations are judged 
in assessing satisfaction with products or systems produced and delivered in accordance with the 
associated technical effort, deemed critical to both acceptability of product by stakeholder and 
operational/mission usage, typically quantitative in nature or not able to be used directly as a 
design-to requirement. (Source: NPR 7123.1)

Measure of Performance (MOP): A quantitative measure that, when met by the design 
solution, will help ensure that an MOE for a product or system will be satisfied. MOPs are given 
special attention during design to ensure that the MOEs with which they are associated are met. 
There are generally two or more measures of performance for each MOE. (Source: NPR 7123.1) 
 
Metamodel: A model of a model that describes the concepts in the modeling language, their 
characteristics, and interrelationships. (Source: Friedenthal, S.; Moore, A.; and Steiner, R. 
(2014). “A Practical Guide to SysML: The Systems Modeling Language,” 3rd ed. Boston: 
Morgan Kaufmann.)

Model: A description or representation of a system, entity, phenomena, or process. (Note: A 
model may be constructed from multiple sub-models; the sub-models and the integrated sub-
models are all considered models. Likewise, any data that go into a model are considered part of 
the model.) (Source: NASA-HDBK-7009) 
 
Model-Based Systems Engineering (MBSE): The formalized application of modeling to 
support system requirements, design, analysis, verification, and validation activities beginning in 
the conceptual design phase and continuing throughout development and later life-cycle phases.

Stakeholder: A group or individual who is affected by or has an interest or stake in a program or

System: The combination of elements that function together to produce the capability required to 
meet a need. The elements include all hardware, software, equipment, facilities, personnel, 
processes, and procedures needed for this purpose. (Sources: NPR 7123.1) 
 
Systems Engineering (SE): NASA SE is a logical systems approach performed by 
multidisciplinary teams to engineer and integrate NASA’s systems to ensure NASA products 
meet the customer’s needs. Implementation of this systems approach will enhance NASA’s core 
engineering capabilities while improving safety, mission success, and affordability. This systems 
approach is applied to all elements of a system (i.e., hardware, software, and human) and all 
hierarchical levels of a system over the complete program/project life cycle. (Source: 
NPR 7123.1)

Technical Performance Measures (TPM): A set of performance measures that are monitored 
by comparing the current actual achievement of the parameters with that anticipated at the 
current time and on future dates. (Source: NPR 7123.1) 
 
Technical Requirements: The requirements that capture the characteristics, features, functions, 
and performance that the end product will have to meet stakeholder expectations. (Source: NPR 
7123.1) 
 
Technical Requirements Definition Process: A process used to transform the stakeholder 
expectations into a complete set of validated technical requirements expressed as "shall" 
statements that can be used for defining a design solution for the product breakdown structure 
(PBS) model and related enabling products. (Sources: NPR 7123.1 and NASA/SP-2016-6105, 
Revision 2)

-6105,

determined by a combination of test, analysis, demonstration, and inspection. (Source: NPR 
7123.1) 
 
Verification (of a Product): Proof of compliance with requirements/specifications. (Source: 
NPR 7123.1)

Terminology 
• Model: 
– A simplified version of a concept, phenomenon, relationship, 
structure or system 
– A graphical, mathematical or physical representation 
– An abstraction of reality by eliminating unnecessary components 
– The objectives of a model include; 
• to facilitate understanding 
• to aid in decision making, examine 'what if' scenarios 
• to explain, control, and predict events 
“Model-Based Engineering (MBE): An approach to engineering that uses models as 
an integral part of the technical baseline that includes the requirements, analysis, 
design, implementation, and verification of a capability, system, and/or product 
throughout the acquisition life cycle.”

System Model 
• Requirements 
– What are the stakeholder goals, purposes, and success conditions for the system 
– Specification of black box behavior and characteristics 
• Behavior 
– What the system has to do to meet the requirements 
– Transformations of inputs to outputs (functional/activity models) 
– State/Mode-based behavioral differences (state models) 
– Responses to incoming requests for services (message models) 
• Structure 
– The parts that exhibit the behavior 
– The component hierarchy, elements, and stores 
• Properties 
– The performance, physical characteristics and governing rules that constrain the structure and behavior 
• Interconnections 
– The way the structural elements arrange and communicate to achieve the required behavior 
under the given constraints

What is SysML? 
• A graphical modelling language in response to the UML for Systems 
Engineering RFP developed by the OMG, INCOSE, and AP233 
– a UML Profile that represents a subset of UML 2 
with extensions 
 
• Supports the specification, analysis, design, verification, and validation 
of systems that include hardware, software, data, personnel, 
procedures, and facilities 
 
• Supports model and data interchange via XML Metadata Interchange 
(XMI®) and the evolving AP233 standard (in-process)

3.3 Application of data element mapping and analysis for sys-
tem definition to enable model-based systems engineering
Summary: A 2025 paper on using data mapping for MBSE system definition. Link:
Wiley Link
421

tem definition to enable model-based systems engineering
Summary: A 2025 paper on using data mapping for MBSE system definition. Link:
Wiley Link
421

Received: 23 July 2023 Revised: 7 June 2024 Accepted: 23 July 2024
DOI: 10.1002/sys.21776
REGULAR ARTICLE
Application of data element mapping and analysis for system
definition to enable model-based systems engineering
Allison Ledford Gregory Harris Susan Askew Gregory Purdy
Industrial and Systems Engineering, Auburn
University, Auburn, Alabama, USA
Correspondence
Allison Ledford, Industrial and Systems
Engineering, Auburn University, 357–359 W
Magnolia Ave, Auburn, AL, USA.
Email: anb0051@auburn.edu
Abstract
In the connected age of the model-based enterprise and model-based systems engi-
neering (MBSE), new systems engineering tools are needed to move from a functional,
document-centric, hierarchical view of data and information to the individual units
of data or data element level view. Data element mapping and analysis (DEMA) is a
te

hierarchical view of data and information to the individual units
of data or data element level view. Data element mapping and analysis (DEMA) is a
technology-agnostic analytical methodology that combines traditional functional anal-
ysis techniques, systems engineering elicitation practices, and novel data mapping
techniques to provide a holistic view of a system’s data and information flows at the
individual units of data (data element level). In this research, DEMA was utilized to
enable an enhanced system definition for the development of a verification and valida-
tion process as applied to a modeling and simulation environment. DEMA uncovered
and visually mapped the hidden flow of approximately 1600 data vessel occurrences
as inputs or outputs to 79 functional activities in 23 disparate storage locations. The
results reveal that DEMA is a practical tool for both improving existing systems and
defining new systems. The data element level view captured by DEMA can be used to
define

A is a practical tool for both improving existing systems and
defining new systems. The data element level view captured by DEMA can be used to
define the interconnections between the system elements that are input to systems
modeling language (SysML) models. Therefore, DEMA is a necessary and novel tool
that can be used to enable system digitalization.
KEYWORDS
data element mapping and analysis (DEMA), digital engineering, digital thread, functional analysis,
model-based systems engineering, testing and evaluation, verification and validation
1 INTRODUCTION
Within the realm of digital engineering, two common topics are model-
based enterprise (MBE) and digital thread. The MBE is an organization
that utilizes modeling and simulation technologies to integrate and
manage technical and business processes.1 The digital thread is the
connection of data and information flows over time throughout a sys-
tem’s lifecycle.2–5 The digital thread enables the capture of lifecycle
data and allows fo

n of data and information flows over time throughout a sys-
tem’s lifecycle.2–5 The digital thread enables the capture of lifecycle
data and allows for its use and maturation at the appropriate time by
the users of the system.6 Although the digital thread and the MBE can
both be considered under the umbrella of digitalization, they are two
distinct but related concepts. Whereas the digital thread is the connec-
tion of all phases of the lifecycle data for proper access, transmission,
and storage by users, the MBE specifically uses models to manage
data.2,5
Therefore, MBE approaches may assist in enacting the digital thread
by modeling data in a digital form that is suitable for connecting to
the digital thread, but the MBE does not systematically connect all
relevant lifecycle data. The interest in digital thread and MBE is not
unfounded. Estimates indicate digital transformation will create value
in the trillions of dollars.7,8 The United States Department of Defense
has recognized di

Estimates indicate digital transformation will create value
in the trillions of dollars.7,8 The United States Department of Defense
has recognized digital engineering as necessary to achieve greater
performance, improve response time, reduce costs, and increase ven-
dor engagement within the United States military.9 The DoD has also
identified digital modernization as an essential strategy to enable
mission success.10 Germany, China, and many other governments in
Systems Engineering.2025;28:15–28. © 2024 Wiley Periodicals LLC. 15wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/sys

10 Germany, China, and many other governments in
Systems Engineering.2025;28:15–28. © 2024 Wiley Periodicals LLC. 15wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/sys

16 LEDFORD ET AL.
addition to the United States have also recognized the importance of
digitalization.11,12
Various societies and governing bodies are also leading the way in
defining standards, assembling working groups, and establishing rec-
ommended practices to enable the digital thread and the MBE. The
American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) formed the MBE
Standards Committee to oversee the development of rules, guidance,
and use cases related to the MBE, and they have various working
groups under its authority.13 ASTM International provided practical
advice for industry by stating that value stream mapping across indus-
tries is necessary to identify the key components of the digital thread
within an additive manufacturing context.14 Within the MBE, model-
based systems engineering (MBSE) has grown in popularity across
man

digital thread
within an additive manufacturing context.14 Within the MBE, model-
based systems engineering (MBSE) has grown in popularity across
many industries,15 thus, digitalization is becoming ubiquitous in the
systems engineering community. Data and information flows are at
the heart of all digital systems. Therefore, novel systems engineering
tools are needed for the design, analysis, and improvement of sys-
tems that utilize digital technologies.16 Until recently, a significant
research gap existed as no suitable tools were available to accomplish
this in a way that systematically uncovered and isolated threads of
data to the data element level.16 Data element mapping and analysis
(DEMA) was developed to fill this gap as part of a recent digital thread
effort whose results are published in IEEE Open Journal of Systems
Engineering.16
In this research, DEMA is utilized in a new system engineering con-
text to enable the definition and development of a verification and
validation

.16
In this research, DEMA is utilized in a new system engineering con-
text to enable the definition and development of a verification and
validation (V&V) process for a system operational environment while
capturing the process’s data and information flows to a level of fidelity
necessary to enable the creation of an MBSE architecture. The remain-
der of this paper is structured according to the following. In Section2,
background information and a summary of the review of literature is
provided. Section3 describes the methodology of DEMA. In Section4,
information is provided on the application of DEMA to the V&V process
of an operational environment. In Section5, the results are presented.
Section 6 discusses the results, and Section 7 presents concluding
thoughts.
2 BACKGROUND
Overall, the review of the literature reveals there is a growing recog-
nition that a systems engineering philosophy is essential to the real-
ization of digitalization efforts.2,3,5,17 The decomposition of co

owing recog-
nition that a systems engineering philosophy is essential to the real-
ization of digitalization efforts.2,3,5,17 The decomposition of complex
systems into smaller groups is very useful in managing complexity
and promoting system understanding.18 Unique systems engineering
tools are needed to holistically capture and understand the complex
data and information flows to be architected into digital systems.
In the remainder of this section, the strengths of past digital sys-
tems engineering research are presented, and the research gaps
are identified. Section 2.1 overviews research conducted in MBSE,
and Section 2.2 presents the current state of systems engineering
V&V.
SIGNIFICANCE AND PRACTITIONER POINTS
Data element mapping and analysis (DEMA) is a new systems
engineering (SE) tool for the standardized capture, mapping,
and analysis of data flows at the data element level view
for digital system understanding and architecture. DEMA is
the first approach that enables the

analysis of data flows at the data element level view
for digital system understanding and architecture. DEMA is
the first approach that enables the identification and iso-
lation of the individual units of data that will make up the
digital thread or the model-based enterprise. This research
presents an initial use of DEMA for the enhanced defini-
tion of a new system while enabling model-based systems
engineering.
2.1 MBSE
Within the MBE, MBSE has captured the attention of diverse sectors
of industries.15 MBSE is different from the traditional, document-
centric system engineering approach in that it utilizes system models
to capture work products, relationships, and understanding across the
system lifecycle.19 The traditional document based approach exacer-
bates system failures caused by a lack of mechanisms for enforcing
consistency between SE artifacts and communications across the
lifecycle.19
A systematic literature review (SLR) was conducted by Sandia
National Laboratories to

between SE artifacts and communications across the
lifecycle.19
A systematic literature review (SLR) was conducted by Sandia
National Laboratories to search for industry case studies that could
support the business case for MBSE implementation.20 The results of
this review found over 88 studies that reported improvements from an
MBSE approach across various use cases, such as defense, space, and
commercial systems, with the major findings including the improve-
ments MBSE approaches have on requirements engineering and defect
prevention strategies.20 Another SLR by Henderson and Salado cap-
tured 360 papers with an aggregated count of 1233 individually stated
benefits from MBSE, with the most common perceived benefits being
better communication/information sharing, increased traceability, and
the ability to better manage complexity.21 However, despite the poten-
tial benefits of MBSE, it has not been generally adopted,19 and this is at
least partially because past MBSE publications ha

wever, despite the poten-
tial benefits of MBSE, it has not been generally adopted,19 and this is at
least partially because past MBSE publications have focused on qual-
itative benefits rather than quantitative proof of improvements.20,22
Another reason may be that the benefits of MBSE are often
portrayed in a way that overshadows its real-world barriers to
entry.22
Therefore, more research is needed to develop tools, methods, and
quantifiable business cases to enable the adoption of MBSE and reduce
potential pitfalls. Systems modeling language (SysML) is a leading stan-
dard language for implementing MBSE.23 There are various diagrams
in SysML to create system models that define and show the inter-
connections between elements of a system.24 SysML can serve as the
mechanism for demonstrating connections in the digital thread and
creating the MBE, but by itself, it does not provide methods for system-
atically capturing hidden processes and data and information flows.

(FFD), functional flow block diagrams (FFBD), business process mod-

as an object that
could be used for mapping actors that access data. The criteria of
column C3 is that the mapping makes data element thread identifica-
tion both possible and practical. The criteria for column C4 is that the
technique has a systematic method for holistically uncovering hidden
processes, data, and information flows that are found in actual real-life
systems.
Overall, the results shown in Table1 reveal that past mapping
techniques are suitable for evaluating functional, document-based,
hierarchical, and software-centric views of data and information. These
methods do not consider the individual units of data or data ele-
ments that are contained within documents. The functional perspec-
tives make it difficult or impossible to identify and isolate individual
threads of data across the lifecycle. The methods also do not pro-
vide approaches for systematically discovering and uncovering hidden
processes and data and information flows.
DEMA was developed to bridge this gap

-
vide approaches for systematically discovering and uncovering hidden
processes and data and information flows.
DEMA was developed to bridge this gap16 and meet all four criteria
in Table1. DEMA is an approach that combines traditional functional
analysis techniques, systems engineering elicitation methodologies,
and novel data mapping techniques to provide a holistic view of the
current state of data and information flows.16 Like traditional map-
ping techniques, DEMA begins with a functional level view of a system.
DEMA then utilizes an interview-based technique to identify data ves-
sels (i.e., documents and any other possible container of data) as they
flow throughout the system functions. Once the flow of data vessels
is identified, the data elements (individual units of data) within the
vessels are isolated. Isolated data threads can be analyzed to iden-
tify inefficiencies in the flow of data elements. Once inefficiencies
are identified, a rearchitected flow can be created with

an be analyzed to iden-
tify inefficiencies in the flow of data elements. Once inefficiencies
are identified, a rearchitected flow can be created with inefficiencies
removed.
Previous research applied DEMA to a prototyping system to enable
the digital thread.16 Based on the review of literature, it was deter-
mined that DEMA can be used to enable MBSE by defining the
interconnections between the system elements that will be inputted
into the SysML models (or any other modeling tool). Therefore, MBSE
models can serve as the mechanism to demonstrate connections and
deploy SE artifacts across the lifecycle. DEMA offers the means by
which the data elements and interconnections that will go into the
models are identified and defined so that MBSE models can be created
and deployed across the lifecycle in a systematic, timely, and verifiable
manner.

2.2 System V&V
V&V are two essential SE processes in the development of systems.25
Although V&V may be similar in nature, their objectives are fundamen-
tally different.26 As defined in IEEE Standard 15288-2023, verification
is “a set of activities that compares a system or system element against
the required characteristics” and may include requirements, design,
and the system itself.27 Validation, however, is “a set of activities ensur-
ing and gaining confidence that a system” does what is intended in an
environment.27 V&V in various applications are governed by standards
including but not limited to: AS9100 for aerospace quality,26 MIL-STD
3022 for United States Department of Defense verification, valida-
tion, and accreditation of models and simulations,28 and IEEE Standard
1012–2026 for system, software, and hard

tment of Defense verification, valida-
tion, and accreditation of models and simulations,28 and IEEE Standard
1012–2026 for system, software, and hardware V&V. Given the diver-
sity and number of potential applications and standards for V&V, it is
reasonable to assume that confusion may arise as to what V&V entails.
Another potential area for confusion comes from the fact that V&V
are not simply one-time events. For example, IEEE STD 1220–2005
Systems Engineering – Application and Management of the Systems
Engineering Process defines the main steps of the systems engineering
process as being requirements analysis, requirements validation, func-
tional analysis, functional verification, synthesis, design verification,
systems analysis, and control with various tools and methods pre-
scribed at each step.29 The recommended practices guide for MIL-STD
3022 also outlines multiple V&V activities in their framework, includ-
ing conceptual model validation, verification, data V&V, and results

or MIL-STD
3022 also outlines multiple V&V activities in their framework, includ-
ing conceptual model validation, verification, data V&V, and results
validation.30
Despite the complexities and potential pitfalls of V&V, the literature
is clear that V&V is necessary for timely completion and success in sys-
tem development as a lack of V&V can result in increases to cost and
schedule as a result of latent defects causing scrapped materials and
rework.31 In terms of MBSE, research has shown that the use of author-
itative system models can theoretically be used to reduce lifecycle cost
and enable enhanced V&V.20,31
As digitalization enables more complex and software-centric sys-
tems, there is an increasing need for rigorous V&V of critical systems.31
NASA estimates that the cost of verifying the software of complex
systems may cost 75–88 percent of the total cost for developing the
software.31,32 Research conducted by Campo et al. found that one of
the most positively perceived attribu

percent of the total cost for developing the
software.31,32 Research conducted by Campo et al. found that one of
the most positively perceived attributes of MBSE to be its V&V capa-
bility, but they also found that many of claims made about MBSE in the
papers identified were based on author opinions and not supported by
metrics.22 Therefore, more research is needed into methods that can
be used to quantitatively define the impact of MBSE on system V&V.
3 METHODOLOGY
DEMA is a technology agnostic analytical approach that can be applied
to any system with data to enable digital transformation. DEMA uncov-
ers a system’s data and information flows even if they are hidden,
non-standardized, and unstructured. DEMA accomplishes this by cap-
turing the flow of data elements as they are handled and transformed
by actors in the system, and thus the results of DEMA can be used
to architect digital systems, with the data elements serving as the
connectors of the digital system.16
The DEMA approac

e results of DEMA can be used
to architect digital systems, with the data elements serving as the
connectors of the digital system.16
The DEMA approach is a tool that can be applied for defining a new
system (a V&V process for a system environment) while also enabling
MBSE. DEMA has three steps: Functional level mapping and analy-
sis, data vessel level mapping and analysis, and data element level
mapping and analysis. Different views of the system with increasing
levels of complexity and detail are revealed at each step of DEMA
(Figure 1). Four terms that are routinely used with the DEMA process
are functional area, functional activity, data vessel, and data element.
Functional areas represent the highest level in which actions take place
within a system. Functional activities are the operations within the
functional areas that transform data vessel inputs into outputs. A data
vessel is any container used to transport data elements, and examples
of this would be emails, personal notes

data vessel inputs into outputs. A data
vessel is any container used to transport data elements, and examples
of this would be emails, personal notes, MBSE files, word documents,
and software files. Finally, data elements are the individual units of
data contained within data vessels such as document titles, dimen-
sions, software file inputs, individual requirements, and due dates. The
remainder of this section outlines the methodology and steps of the
DEMA process. One possible limitation of the DEMA methodology
is interviewing a limited sample size of system actors. Therefore, if
possible, it is recommended that all system actors be interviewed. If
interviewing all system stakeholders is not feasible, the risk of inter-
viewee bias in the DEMA mappings can be overcome by having all or
a statistically significant number of system stakeholders participate in
verification of the DEMA mappings.
3.1 Functional level mapping and analysis
In the first step of DEMA, the high-level function

holders participate in
verification of the DEMA mappings.
3.1 Functional level mapping and analysis
In the first step of DEMA, the high-level functional areas and func-
tional activities of the system to be developed are defined and visually
mapped as functional block and functional flow block diagrams. Begin-
ning with the DEMA functional level view is critical so all data vessels
and elements identified in the next steps can be traced back to the func-
tions and so that the functions can be traced to system requirements.
The functional areas are defined first along with any sub-functional
areas, and then the functional activities (the functions within the func-
tional areas that transform data vessel inputs into outputs) are defined
(Figure 2).16
The functions can be defined using various tools. If the system is
well-defined, then program management data and work procedures
can be used to identify the functions and then verified using elicita-
tion techniques and round table discussi

am management data and work procedures
can be used to identify the functions and then verified using elicita-
tion techniques and round table discussions with system stakeholders.
One hesitation to using DEMA may be that the system is not very well
understood with clearly defined processes.16 However, this issue is
easily overcome by stakeholder elicitation. If the system is not well-
defined or is being newly developed, the Functional Level Mapping and
Analysis will require iterative discussions with system stakeholders to
define them and ensure the functions meet system requirements.

3.2 Data vessel level mapping and analysis
The functions identified in Step 1 of DEMA are used as the foun-
dation for the data vessels that are identified and visually mapped
in Step 2. At the beginning of Step 2, representatives from each
of the Functional Areas are presented the Functional Level Map-
pings from Step 1, and they are asked to identify the activi-
ties in which they were involved. The interviewer goes through
each functional activity that the interviewee identifies and asks
a set of standardized questions related to the data vessel inputs
and outputs for that activity.16 Examples of the questions asked
include:
∙ What activities are you involved in?
∙ Please provide a description of the ac

outputs for that activity.16 Examples of the questions asked
include:
∙ What activities are you involved in?
∙ Please provide a description of the activity.
∙ Under what conditions does this activity occur?
∙ Please provide an estimate of the min, max, and typical time this
activity takes.
∙ What activities precede and follow this activity?
∙ What data vessels are involved?
Once the interviews are completed the results are mapped using a
technique derived from an integration of IDEF0 and DeMarco’s data
flow diagrams.16 The syntax for this mapping is shown in Figure3.
To account for system variability, if the data vessels identified could
come from multiple sources under various conditions, these are also
recorded in the template. If the activity is iterative in nature and
has clear exit criteria that must be met, this is also recorded next
to the name of each data vessel in brackets “[]”. If different intervie-
wees describe different ways of accomplishing the same functional
activity

wees describe different ways of accomplishing the same functional
activity, then a separate mapping is created for each interviewee that
reveals a potential need for standardization in how that activity is
conducted.16 Figure 4 shows how the responses of a specific func-

4 RESULTS
The DEMA methodology provided comprehensive visibility into the
definition of the V&V process of a modeling and simulation environ-
ment with four functional areas and 79 functional activities identified
and visually mapped. In terms of data and information flows, the DEMA
methodology holistically captured how the system’s data and informa-
tion flows would occur given the current data infrastructure of the
organization. Over 95% of data handling by the system actors were not

standardized in any official documentation of the system processes,
and over 50% of data vessel inputs and outputs were unstructured
(in a format not ready for digital connection). Also, around 90% of
data element handling was performed by the actors manually execut-
ing the flow of data by means such as email or conversation. The results
from this application are consistent with a previous DEMA application
where the digital thread in a process was enabled.
Various terminology disconnects were also uncovered between
actors concerning V&V terms, places of storage, data vessels, activities,
and roles. The presence of terminology disconnects revealed activities
in which the actors in the system would waste time making mistakes
due to incorrect interpretation of communications by other system
actors. The DEMA application a

due to incorrect interpretation of communications by other system
actors. The DEMA application also revealed 23 disparate data vessel
storage locations in the system as well as which data vessels were
located in each place of storage and during which activity. Previously,
this knowledge of the system was divided among the system actors and
had never been combined, documented, or understood.
Therefore, the DEMA results brought comprehensive visibility to
the system whose function and data flows were previously unde-
fined while also enabling a data element level view of the system.

4.1 Definition of system functional architecture
The functional level view analysis defined the system functional archi-
tecture of the V&V process of the modeling and simulation (M&S)
environment. In DEMA the functional level view analysis is iterative. In
this application the stakeholders were in the process of developing the
V&V system so the definition of functional areas and activities required
multiple round-table discussion with system stakeholders to ensure
the architecture met system requirements. In the end, four func-
tional areas, 15 sub-functional areas, and 79 functional activities were
defined. The functional areas were defined first: (1) Management of
environment development, integration, and V & V; (2) Development of
environment components; (3) Integration of environme

ined first: (1) Management of
environment development, integration, and V & V; (2) Development of
environment components; (3) Integration of environment components;
and (4) V & V; of the environment (Figure6). Discussions continued
with stakeholders to determine what functional activities would fall
under each functional area. While doing this, several sub-functional
areas were designated to group related functional activities.
Within management of environment development, integration, and
V & V, the sub-functional areas were 1.10 Project Management, 1.20

1, and 2.30 Component Development Part 2. Within Integration of
Environment Components, the sub-functional areas were 3.10 Pre-
Integration and 3.20 Environment Integration. Within V & V of the
Environment, the sub-functional areas were 4.10 Initial V

ional areas were 3.10 Pre-
Integration and 3.20 Environment Integration. Within V & V of the

Execution. The visual mapping of the sub-functional areas within the

The 79 functional activities were then determined (Figure8). The
activities are labeled with numbers instead of names to protect the pri-
vacy of the organization that owns the system. Although this DEMA
functional mapping was made for a specific V & V process of a modeling
and simulation environment, the functional architecture was created
as agnostic as possible. This enabled the organization to use and edit
the architecture as needed for reuse in the future development of V
& V processes for operational simulation e

nabled the organization to use and edit
the architecture as needed for reuse in the future development of V
& V processes for operational simulation environments. During round
table discussions, notes were also captured describing the nature of
individual activities. During the system development the system ter-
minology was being created. Therefore, whenever the stakeholders
elucidated on the nature of an activity, their thoughts were captured
and detailed descriptions of each activity and the identification of the
actors being interviewed that were participating in those activities
were systematically captured in Step 2 of DEMA.
4.2 Definition of data vessels and data elements
for model-based definition
The data vessel level view was created by conducting standardized
interviews with the actors who were developing and managing the
system. The representatives were from both engineering and man-
agement. There were six interviewees: the environment software
developer, the project lead

m. The representatives were from both engineering and man-
agement. There were six interviewees: the environment software
developer, the project lead representing Organization A, the project
lead representing Organization B, the operational coordinator, and a
subject matter expert with knowledge of the systems that would later
be using the completed simulation environment. Over 1600 data ves-
sel occurrences were identified as either inputs or outputs to the 79
functions, and over 23 storage locations were identified as being used
throughout the system to store these data vessels. Of the approxi-
mately 1600 data vessels inputs and outputs, 61% were determined to
be unique vessels, indicating process complexity and a lack of standard-
ization across the total set of vessels. The high number of unique data
vessels is from the high level of correspondences such as emails, con-
versations, and personal notes that had to occur to develop the system.

FIGURE 9 Data vessel mapping of activity 1.113.
Past system analysis techniques such as value steam mapping,
IDEF0, business process modeling notation, and SysML diagrams do
not offer a way to systematically uncover hidden activities while
enabling a view of individual data elements. Therefore, the DEMA
methodology is novel in its ability to uncover hidden activities and
data elements and threads, and it aggregates tribal knowledge that
reveals opportunities for improving the system. For the activities
that did have owners, the interviewee’s responses were recorded
in the interview templates. The interviewee was asked for each of
their activities to provide a high-level summary of the activity; to
identify which personnel were involved with the activity; to iden-
tify if any V & V decisions were made in the activity an

ummary of the activity; to
identify which personnel were involved with the activity; to iden-
tify if any V & V decisions were made in the activity and if so,
what data vessels were associated with those decisions; to pro-
vide estimates for the minimum, max, and most likely calendar time
associated with the activity; to identify the directly proceeding and
succeeding activities; and to identify the data vessel inputs and
outputs.
If the activity was iterative in nature, the decision criteria to exit the
activity was also recorded. The place of storage, personnel who han-
dled the data, data format, tools used to handle the data, personnel
the data vessel was sent to, and means of transfer were also recorded
for the data vessels. The recorded results from the interviews were
mapped to create the data vessel level view mappings. An example of
the mapping of an activity from Functional Area 1 is shown in Figure9.
The data vessel inputs are listed on the left side of the function box that

of
the mapping of an activity from Functional Area 1 is shown in Figure9.
The data vessel inputs are listed on the left side of the function box that
identifies the activities as 1.113, and the data vessel outputs are listed
coming out of the right side of the box.
Normally, the text describing the data vessel inputs and outputs are
more descriptive than shown in Figure9 but for the sake of the exam-
ple they were shortened and generalized. The personnel who were
involved in the activity are listed on arrows on the top and bottom of
the function boxes. The cylindrical boxes represent the places of stor-
age the data vessels were retrieved from and stored. If the data vessels
could come from different places of storage “OR” nodes are used to
indicate this condition. The data vessels that iterate back into the activ-
ity are connected by arrows back into the left side of the function box.
The condition(s) for exiting the iterative activity are written in brackets
“[]” next to the data v

rrows back into the left side of the function box.
The condition(s) for exiting the iterative activity are written in brackets
“[]” next to the data vessels. The data vessel outputs that are connected
to an “X” indicate that the data vessel was not stored anywhere for
reuse. The remainder of the activities were also mapped using this
methodology.
Once the mappings of the data vessels as they flow through-
out the system architecture are documented, the data elements
within each of the data vessels can be identified and documented.
The flow of the data elements can be tracked, and individual
threads of data isolated using the data element standardized table
described in Section 3.3. From there, the data elements that are
inputs into MBSE models can be identified and an MBSE framework
can be created that meets the requirements of the overall system
architecture.

holders were captured. During the round-table discussions to define

ers regarding where systems engineering would fit into the functional
decomposition. Some suggested that systems engineering should have
its own functional area, and others suggested that systems engineering
was intrinsic to the activities within the functional areas.
Additionally, during the initial data vessel interview process, each
interviewee was asked how they would define V & V to ensure that
everyone was following the same understanding of the systems engi-
neering terminology. The result of this discussion was the realization
that many stakeholders were not on the same page about systems
engineering terms and activities. This finding is consistent with the
research of Kasser33 and Rousseau34 that show the need for unified
systems engineering sc

ng terms and activities. This finding is consistent with the
research of Kasser33 and Rousseau34 that show the need for unified
systems engineering scientific principles, terminology, and activities.
These results also demonstrate that DEMA can be used to uncover
specific systems engineering terminology disconnects within an
organization.
As each interviewee studied the visual mapping developed in the
functional level view analysis, several questions arose regarding the
nature of various activities. Altogether, there was confusion as to what
approximately 30% of the functional activities entailed. The intervie-
wees often initially struggled to understand that the functional analysis
being conducted was specific to the development and V & V of an
operational environment and not a specific system under test (SUT).
Overall, it seemed that interviewees also struggled in understanding
the system view of the V & V environment and that V & V must be
conducted not only on the SUTs that would

nterviewees also struggled in understanding
the system view of the V & V environment and that V & V must be
conducted not only on the SUTs that would later utilize the opera-
tional environment but that the environment itself must be verified and
validated. This is not surprising in light of the review of literature in Sec-
tion 2.2 that showed the opportunities for confusion surrounding V &
V execution.
Interviewees also used many different names to describe the oper-
ational environment. Some referred to it by the name of specific
software used to conduct the operation. Other called it as the “M&S”,
the “simulation”, the “wrap around simulation”, the “wrap around
operational environment”, and the “operational environment,” often
with a very ambiguous use of the word “model”. There was also
confusion about who performed what roles in the system. From a
data vessel perspective, the interviewees used different words to
mean the same thing for places of storage. For example, various
team

system. From a
data vessel perspective, the interviewees used different words to
mean the same thing for places of storage. For example, various
team drives were referred to using different names, and the soft-
ware developers were sometimes confused with other engineering
roles.
Therefore, a better understanding of the terminology surround-
ing the system will facilitate practices happening more efficiently
with less opportunities for mistakes in the system. The application
of DEMA to the V & V process of the operational environment
showed that DEMA is effective in uncovering terminology discon-
nects in systems engineering, functional execution, and data vessel
usage. Once terminology disconnects are uncovered using DEMA,
training materials and work procedures can be developed to gov-
ern system terminology and level the knowledge of the actors in the
system.

5 DISCUSSION
5.1 Enabling MBSE
The review of literature showed that past attempts to determine the
necessary data for model-based definition and the MBE were narra-
tive in nature16 and relied on methods such as surveys,35 workshops,36
and comparison studies.37 This resulted in a significant research gap as
no methods were discovered to holistically uncover the data and infor-
mation flows of real-life systems down to the data element level view
necessary for model-based definition.
In this research, DEMA was successfully applied to enable the defi-
nition of a new system as it was being developed while simultaneously
setting up the foundation for full traceability from the high-level sys-
tem functions to the flow of data elements so that the elements can
then be architected into an MBSE framework. In previous research
DEMA was proven successful in capturing the data element level in
a well-defined process to enable the digital thread.16 Therefore, the
DEMA me

search
DEMA was proven successful in capturing the data element level in
a well-defined process to enable the digital thread.16 Therefore, the
DEMA methodology offers a novel approach by which the data ele-
ments and interconnections that enable MBSE models and the digital
thread can be identified and defined.
Some data elements in a system will not be repeatedly used
throughout the system lifecycle or required for additional data ves-
sel applications. For example, the date of a one-time organizational
meeting may be only applicable to one functional activity, and thus
the organization may choose to keep meeting dates in an email data
vessel. Another example would be data vessel within a PDF form that
the organization is required by a governing organization to maintain.
Therefore, even an organization that has a fully developed and imple-
mented an MBSE framework will likely have both MBSE data vessels
and non-MBSE data vessels.
Research conducted by Campo et al. found that some of th

-
mented an MBSE framework will likely have both MBSE data vessels
and non-MBSE data vessels.
Research conducted by Campo et al. found that some of the negative
aspects of MBSE were the perceived time commitment and high cost of
implementation.22 Therefore, a continuous improvement approach is
recommended for MBSE implementation to reduce the cost and com-
plexity of the MBSE system and to encourage a gradual move to MBSE
rather than one that takes years for initial deployment. Because DEMA
captures three levels of system complexity, continuous improvement
is enabled at the functional level view, data vessel level view, and data
element level view.
The functional level view can be analyzed to make sure that system
requirements are met from a functional perspective, and adjustments
can be made to the system architecture if necessary. Improvements can
be identified at the data vessel level view where short-term opportu-
nities for improving information disconnects and unnecessary manual

vements can
be identified at the data vessel level view where short-term opportu-
nities for improving information disconnects and unnecessary manual
data handling can be identified. This identification is achieved by stake-
holders reviewing the data vessel level mappings and identifying areas
for improvement.
For example, if an activity has correspondences (emails, conversa-
tions, and/or personal notes) that are not contained in official data
vessels, then the reviewers could consider whether a new, standard-
ized data vessel could be introduced that would allow the people in

throughout the development or sustainment lifecycle. This would elim-
inate opportunities for data elements to be lost, incorrect, and/or hard
to find. Another example would be an activity that has data vessels
being stored in disparate places (especially personal drives). Then the
reviewers could create a standard procedure that the data vessels
be stored in a specific shared drive that is accessible to the relevant

The data element level view can be used to identify data that can be
contained in MBSE models to eliminate information disconnects and
manual handling. From there, an MBSE architecture can be created.
Then, standards can be created that guide system personnel through
the activities and data vessel handling (both MBSE and non-MBSE

ure can be created.
Then, standards can be created that guide system personnel through
the activities and data vessel handling (both MBSE and non-MBSE data
vessels). This would be accomplished by documenting the terminol-
ogy, ensuring common understanding, and guides the user through the
functional level mapping and data vessel level mappings, after being
updated with the improved data flows.
5.2 An e wa g ef o rV&Va n ds y s t e md e v e l o p m e n t
This application showed that DEMA can be used to identify the knowl-
edge and terminology disconnects related to the V & V of a system.
Disconnects related to both systems engineering terminology, termi-
nology for the specific system under development, and undocumented
activities were identified. Therefore, the terminology disconnects,
functional level mappings, and data vessel level mappings could be used
as a foundation for creating training materials for the V & V of future
systems.
The review of literature found that that one of th

ings could be used
as a foundation for creating training materials for the V & V of future
systems.
The review of literature found that that one of the most positively
perceived attributes of MBSE is its potential for enhanced V & V.22
However, many of the claims made about the benefits of MBSE are
based on author opinions and not supported by metrics.22 This applica-
tion of DEMA enabled V & V to a new level of fidelity by capturing views
of the system down to the data element level view. Therefore, V & V
activities no longer must be viewed as only discrete events with spe-
cific documentation. By using DEMA to capture the inner workings of
a system down to the individual flows of data elements, V & V can hap-
pen throughout the entire lifecycle because the system is holistically
captured and V & V can be continuous.
MBSE can be used as the mechanism to manage and model the life-
cycle data flows that will be used in the enhanced V & V. Also, the
Hawthorne effect shows that people who

the mechanism to manage and model the life-
cycle data flows that will be used in the enhanced V & V. Also, the
Hawthorne effect shows that people who are subject to experiments
or studies are inclined to modify their behavior because they are being
observed.38 Therefore, it is possible that the actors in a system where
DEMA and MBSE have been used to enable full system visibility may be
more inclined to conform to V & V guidelines.
6 CONCLUSION
DEMA can be used to enable enhanced system definition while captur-
ing a data element level view that can be used for MBSE architecture.
This research also showed that DEMA revealed various terminol-
ogy disconnects and misunderstandings related to the V & V of an
operational environment along with undocumented sub-functions and
activities. Therefore, the test and evaluation and systems engineer-
ing community at large can utilize DEMA to identify opportunities to
reduce system engineering risks and failures.
Various future work can be conduct

ing community at large can utilize DEMA to identify opportunities to
reduce system engineering risks and failures.
Various future work can be conducted to further this research.
The three pillars of MBSE are modeling languages, modeling meth-
ods, and modeling tools.39 SysML is a commonly used MBSE modeling
language, and there are various modeling tools available for use such
as Cameo Systems Modeler, Rhapsody, and UModel.39 A modeling
method is the method for adding elements and defining the ele-
ment’s relationships into a system model, and common MBSE modeling
methods include INCOSE object-oriented systems engineering and
Weilkiens system modeling method.39 Future work could investigate
utilizing DEMA alongside modeling methods such as INCOSE object-
oriented systems engineering and Weilkiens system modeling method
to ensure the created models accurately capture a system down to
a data element level view. Also, a systematic method needs to be
developed to determine which data eleme

ed models accurately capture a system down to
a data element level view. Also, a systematic method needs to be
developed to determine which data elements are the most critical to
include in MBSE models. Machine learning techniques combined with
stakeholder analysis could be evaluated for such as method. The devel-
opment of DEMA software that automates the interview process could
be made to reduce the mental and time loads of the interviews in the
future.
Given that most MBSE literature has focused on anecdotal rather
than quantifiable benefits of MBSE,20–22 the business case for imple-
menting MBSE would be strengthened by the development of a
method for calculating empirical benefits of MBSE implementation.
DEMA captures the current state of a system down to a data ele-
ment level view, and therefore if metrics can be associated with
the reduction of data element instances and manual handling, then
a quantifiable business case for MBSE could be made by com-
paring the data element me

e reduction of data element instances and manual handling, then
a quantifiable business case for MBSE could be made by com-
paring the data element metrics of a pre-MBSE and post-MBSE
system.
To realize the advantages of MBSE, systems engineering tools are
needed to move from a functional, hierarchical, document-centric view
of data and information to a data element level view. This research has
shown that DEMA is a new system engineering tool that accomplishes
this need. The results also showed that DEMA can be used for both
improving existing systems and defining new systems, and the data ele-
ment level-view can be used to define the interconnections between
the system elements that will be inputs to SysML models. Therefore,
DEMA is a novel tool that can be used to enable MBSE implementation
and enhanced system V & V.

4
Eurostep Defines the Digital Thread
A digital thread is the communication framework that provides a connected 
data flow and integrated view of the product’s data throughout its lifecycle, 
connecting the many digital twins. Data should be reusable and flow both 
downstream and upstream through feedback loops. Considering the data 
applications outside of the data generating domain, all the data in a digital 
thread must be clear, concise, and validated. 
Traditionally, a digital thread spans siloed functional perspectives, but for 
value networks, which include suppliers, partners and customers, it needs to 
also extend outside of an organization’s border.
Digital Thread’s Rise to Prominence 
The concept of a digital thread providing automated linkage of 
multiple representations of a product, each tuned to the needs of 
various crea

nence 
The concept of a digital thread providing automated linkage of 
multiple representations of a product, each tuned to the needs of 
various creators and consumers along the lifecycle, is very 
powerful. Until recently, tracing these linkages has been primarily 
a manual process, extracting product information from myriad 
heterogeneous systems and relating them in ad hoc reports. But 
now, with recent advances in commercial PLM solutions, the 
digital thread, with automated linkages and traceability, has 
become a practical possibility, even for industries with complex 
products, such as aerospace & defense.
In response, industry leaders have implemented targeted digital 
thread solutions and envision expanding these solutions 
throughout the product lifecycle. With the newness of this 
approach there is not much available in the way of lessons 
learned or value achieved. This lack of real data is a barrier to 
broader investment within industry. On the solution side, 
providers

y of lessons 
learned or value achieved. This lack of real data is a barrier to 
broader investment within industry. On the solution side, 
providers are constantly seeking additional insight into 
investment drivers within industry.
Recent research by CIMdata on behalf of the Aerospace and 
Defense PLM Action Group (AD PAG) in collaboration with 
Eurostep has provided critical insights, which inform the content 
that follows. Information was gathered through thought leader 
interviews and responses to an online survey. The majority of 
respondents were from A&D, but the results are relevant across 
all industries with complex and regulated products.

The conceptual understanding of digital 
thread within industry is very immature. 
Nearly half of the companies surveyed do not 
have a commonly accepted definition of 
digital thread. Less than 10% use a published 
definition. Interviews with 10 industry leaders 
yielded 10 definitions. Some were long, 
others brief. Only two were based on 
definitions published by respected external 
authorities.
Though there may not be a consistent and 
widely accepted definition of digital thread, 
there is a broadly shared perception of what 
a digital thread does and what a digital 
thread is.
Combining the most prominent 
characteristics of what a digital thread does
yields a reasonable definition of digital 
thread, i.e., “Establishes traceability of 
product information across multiple domains 
in the lifecycle (m

ields a reasonable definition of digital 
thread, i.e., “Establishes traceability of 
product information across multiple domains 
in the lifecycle (mechanical, E/E, software, and 
firmware) to provide meaningful relationship 
connections between a product’s digital 
assets.”

Eurostep’s Perspective
Eurostep sees a digital thread as a coherent set of 
integrated product information that is enriched by 
integrating data from a disparate set of domains and 
disciplines from across the value network of suppliers, 
partners, and customers throughout the life cycle of a 
product. For a digital thread to be resilient it must be 
designed with links and relationships that can be 
managed and changed over time. A digital thread 
based on these principles enables agile product 
development with, continuous feedback loops at all 
stages of the product lifecycle.

among specialists in industry of the required

The Digital Thread Value Footprint—Use Cases
Our survey results highlight an inconsistency 
between the importance of the digital thread to 
our respondents and their progress to date. The 
importance assigned to digital thread use cases 
is surprisingly broad and high. The prevalence of 
current digital thread use case implementations 
is surprisingly low. The most striking indicator 
that digital thread investment is in very early 
days is the contrast between importance 
assigned to digital thread use cases and the 
prevalence of current implementations. For 
example, lifecycle BOM management is 
considered essential by 62% and important by 
26% of respondents but is currently 
implemented within only 25% of respondents’ 
companies.

Digital Thread Realization
The digital thread is commonly presented as a 
sequential flow mapped to the product lifecycle. 
On the left in Figure 9 we show the four principal 
product structure configurations in lifecycle 
sequence. In this representation, threads would 
run left to right between the objects in one 
structure to the next in line. But if we look at the 
derivative relationships between these structures 
as shown on the right, we see that the 
dependencies are not sequential.
There are many other views of product structure 
that are relevant to various communities as they 
contribute their efforts throughout the product 
lifecycle. CIMdata believes that these product 
structure configurations are best depicted as a 
web.
As with all major endeavors, the key to success is 
to think big but focus o

that these product 
structure configurations are best depicted as a 
web.
As with all major endeavors, the key to success is 
to think big but focus on pieces of the total 
picture. Use cases are the pieces. They define 
scope and business value. Pick the piece, or use 
case, to work on next based on business 
problems to be solved or opportunities to be 
captured. And as you build out piece by piece, 
keep in view that bigger landscape so that the 
pieces fit together.

Case Study—Heavy Equipment Manufacturer
CIMdata has assisted industrial clients from multiple industries in 
their journey to build out a digital thread, and we believe the 
following case study provides a good example of a use case with 
clearly defined scope and business value.
In this case study, the company engineers and manufactures 
heavy equipment. An order may be for moderate to large 
volumes of these items which may be of multiple configurations, 
and since the equipment is expensive and lasts for a long time, 
they also sell complex support packages. Preparing proposals 
was very slow, error prone, and with a high dependence on tribal 
knowledge. Also, they were leaving money on the table due to 
their inability to provide a proposal in a timely manner.
The focus for the initiative was the proposal BOM, but root cause 
ana

on the table due to 
their inability to provide a proposal in a timely manner.
The focus for the initiative was the proposal BOM, but root cause 
analysis quickly focused attention on the engineering bill of 
material (eBOM). Proposal information came from many 
disconnected, redundant, and non-synchronized sources. But the 
eBOM was the original source from which all of the other views 
were derived. In the original state, the eBOM, manufacturing 
BOM (mBOM) and service BOM (sBOM) were in separate 
systems. Make/buy and costing were in spreadsheets.
In step 1 of the transformation, the eBOM, mBOM and sBOM 
were moved to a single PLM solution, using multi-view BOM 
capability for automated reconciliation and synchronization. 
In step 2, make/buy, costing and proposals are generated on a 
low-code platform. The Consolidated BOM and the Proposal 
BOM are no longer Excel spreadsheets, but information mashups 
stored in the PLM.
Some business benefits identified from this transformation w

oposal 
BOM are no longer Excel spreadsheets, but information mashups 
stored in the PLM.
Some business benefits identified from this transformation were:
• Reduced turnaround and increased accuracy of proposals
• Reduced level of effort and disruption of normal staff activity 
to verify product configurations for proposal pricing 
• Ability to define service configurations more quickly and 
accurately
By focusing on a real business need, this company achieved 
significant payback and is now well positioned to build out more 
of their Digital Thread.

Case Studies—Digital Thread Implementation with 
ShareAspace
Eurostep has several case studies implementing parts of a 
Digital Thread with the client implementing a solution to a 
specific business issue or opportunity. The client is at the same 
time adopting ShareAspace with the vision to grow the solution 
to a larger scope as needs arise.
Case 1—Ship Digital Thread Backbone 
One such case is with a European ship and submarine 
manufacturer that is using ShareAspace as the Digital Thread 
backbone, integrating many software applications from 
different solution providers. These software applications include 
systems primarily addressing design and manufacturing like 
mechanical and electrical CAD, ship CAD, PLM systems, ERP, 
welding applications, etc. ShareAspace has the role of 
integrating information from these applications,

electrical CAD, ship CAD, PLM systems, ERP, 
welding applications, etc. ShareAspace has the role of 
integrating information from these applications, consolidating 
this data and making sure changes are impacting the relevant 
processes on time and without delays.
All processes are using up to date information. Change impact 
analyses can be performed, and all changes are traced in an 
audit trail.
The same client is using ShareAspace to hold the configuration 
of individual ships on a ship class and ship individual basis. In 
this application ShareAspace acts as the overall configuration 
engine, provides reporting on the consolidated data set, and 
integrates with different editing tools including local team data 
management tools.

Future Digital Thread Investment Priorities
Looking to the future, industry leaders are taking a broader view 
of the digital thread’s value potential, with more investment in 
production and service use cases. They view the next stage as 
more complex and transformative to their companies. 
Fortunately, several have been successful in establishing 
programs that enjoy strong support from a well-informed and 
motivated senior management. However, many others have not.
All Top 5 pain points being targeted in future implementations 
relate to accessibility and traceability across data elements, 
especially traceability of requirements throughout the product 
lifecycle. Systems engineering is featured prominently in many 
responses, including ranking as the top new value opportunity 
being targeted in future digital thread implementatio

is featured prominently in many 
responses, including ranking as the top new value opportunity 
being targeted in future digital thread implementations, which 
aligns with CIMdata’s view that systems engineering is a 
principal driver of the digital thread.

14
Strategies for Success
An area of divergence between industry leaders is in the focus of their implementations. For some, the focus is providing interfaces 
to source applications to extract and associate product data artifacts and attributes. For others, the key is the association and 
traceability of dependencies between artifacts in support of a use case. And for a few, the focus is on data governance, which they 
believe is foundational for enabling a richer and more extensive set of product lifecycle use cases.
The number 1 inhibitor to formulating and executing a digital thread strategy is “lack of interoperability between different vendors’ 
tools and systems.” The number 1 proposed means for mitigation is to “increase support of standards.”

Solution Technologies
Key Technical Considerations
Core to the value of digital thread is traceability across source 
and derivative product-related artifacts along the product 
lifecycle and throughout the extended enterprise.
The digital thread value landscape is distributed across a 
heterogeneous value chain from customer to OEM to partners 
and multiple tiers of suppliers. This reality drives the need for 
data interoperability and elevates the importance of standards 
and openness of enabling solution architectures.
Proven technical solutions exist for enabling the digital thread, 
and leading solution providers are investing heavily in research-
guided strategies and roadmaps to further strengthen their 
offerings.
Data is the foundation of the digital thread. This reality elevates 
the importance of sound data governance and

further strengthen their 
offerings.
Data is the foundation of the digital thread. This reality elevates 
the importance of sound data governance and a cleansed 
repository, especially as use case implementations proliferate 
and must be interlinked into an extended thread.
Technologies in Use Today
The technologies used to link product lifecycle data segregate 
into three tiers as shown in Figure 15. The top tier, which has the 
longest history, includes PLM and PDM, followed by ERP, and 
custom applications. The middle tier consists of application and 
data integration tools. These are followed by the third tier of
newer specialty technologies for combining data from multiple 
sources and establishing linkages and traceability. We can 
expect the ranking of these specialty technologies to rise 
significantly over the next few years.
Solution Capability and Provider Alignment
Attitudes on the topic of solution capability and provider 
alignment are mixed. Some industry leaders are qui

ution Capability and Provider Alignment
Attitudes on the topic of solution capability and provider 
alignment are mixed. Some industry leaders are quite critical, 
especially regarding data model accessibility and flexibility to 
comply with a corporate data governance strategy. Other 
interviewees are somewhat neutral or slightly positive. They feel 
that some providers are moving in the right direction; some are 
not. Several feel that solution capabilities have improved 
significantly overall in the last 5-10 years and that, despite some 
remaining gaps, are now fully capable. Some express satisfaction 
that “good partnering” is happening.

Since our inception in 1994, we have been passionate about 
enabling our customers to exploit and share their product data 
by implementing standards-based product data collaboration 
solutions. Our vision is to empower people and businesses by 
game-changing product data collaboration. We are focused on 
enabling product data collaboration within an enterprise, across 
value networks, and throughout a product and systems lifecycle.
To this aim Eurostep developed the ShareAspace Server—in 
production use for more than 20 years—designed to manage a 
digital thread across a product life cycle with data integrated 
from myriad different systems and disciplines.
At the core of ShareAspace is an information model for 
managing a digital thread that is derived from the ISO 10303 
STEP standard, in particular ISO 10303-239 (Product Lifecyle

s an information model for 
managing a digital thread that is derived from the ISO 10303 
STEP standard, in particular ISO 10303-239 (Product Lifecyle 
support - PLCS)—a standard that Eurostep significantly 
contributed to and was explicitly designed for representing 
digital twins and digital threads, despite the terms digital twins 
and digital threads not existing when the standards and 
ShareAspace were developed.
As well as managing the relationships between the data in the 
quadrants ShareAspace maintains a history of the product data 
as it evolves—a historical digital thread. This enables valuable 
insights into the historical performance of the product and its 
configuration that leads to better-informed design changes.
In keeping with Eurostep's core value that information is owned 
by the customer and should not be locked into a proprietary 
system, ShareAspace provides an open REST API enabling easy 
access to and sharing of the digital thread. ShareAspace is 
implemented o

a proprietary 
system, ShareAspace provides an open REST API enabling easy

implemented on Microsoft technologies. The product is

implementing the network model based on ISO STEP AP239

ShareAspace is battle proven software that has been in use for

About the Aerospace & Defense PLM Action Group
The Aerospace & Defense PLM Action Group is an association of aerospace OEMs and aircraft engine providers 
within CIMdata’s globally recognized PLM Community Program, which functions as a PLM advocacy group to:
• Set the direction for the aerospace & defense industry on PLM-related topics that matter to members
• Promote common industry PLM processes and practices 
• Define requirements for common interest PLM-related capabilities
• Communicate with a unified voice to PLM solution providers
• Sponsor collaborative PLM research on prioritized industry and technology topi

bilities
• Communicate with a unified voice to PLM solution providers
• Sponsor collaborative PLM research on prioritized industry and technology topics
CIMdata administers Group operations, coordinates research, and manages the progression of policy 
formulation.
About Eurostep
Eurostep delivers software and services for product lifecycle management with a particular focus on controlled 
data sharing within and between enterprises. Services range from pre-studies to the implementation and 
support of systems. Eurostep has blue-chip and SME customers in a variety of industries including automotive, 
aerospace, defense, energy, high tech, AEC, and plant. The Eurostep product suite consists of:
• ShareAspace Server—A configurable tool for secure PLM collaboration across enterprises and domains.
• ShareAspace Design to Manufacturing—Streamline contract manufacturing processes and protect 
intellectual property. 
• ShareAspace iAIM—Lifecycle asset information management for digital twins a

ne contract manufacturing processes and protect 
intellectual property. 
• ShareAspace iAIM—Lifecycle asset information management for digital twins and the digital thread.
• ShareAspace Export Control—A secure data sharing tool for export and import compliance.

ABSTRACT
The accelerating digital transformation in the aerospace and defense sectors underlines a
pressing need for reﬁned, standardized methodologies for integrating digital tools into mis-
sion engineering (ME). Existing literature reveals a distinct gap in the practical application
of Digital Engineering (DE) and Model-Based Systems Engineering (MBSE) within ME,
particularly due to the lack of clear guidelines for implementation. Recognizing DE and
MBSE’s potential to manage complex systems, this thesis puts forth a novel DE framework
speciﬁcally designed for ME to streamline digital tool integration.
The research approach includes a thorough literature review, the development and appli-
cation of a unique framework for an active debris remediation mission, and the examination
of case studies. The ﬁndings inform the ongoing digital

i-
cation of a unique framework for an active debris remediation mission, and the examination
of case studies. The ﬁndings inform the ongoing digital transformation eﬀorts in the defense
and aerospace sectors, oﬀering valuable insights into the real-world application of DE and
MBSE within ME. This study focuses on the early-stage, holistic-view design processes of
mission and system-of-systems, aiming to establish a robust foundation for detailed lower-
level engineering design.
By exploring how to leverage current practices to develop a framework that supports
digital artifacts and tools, assessing the framework’s improvements, and exploring possible
quantiﬁcation of its impact, this thesis charts a path toward the successful execution of
complex mission objectives in the digital era.

1. INTRODUCTION
1.1 The Digital Age for Aerospace and Defense Missions
As the aerospace and defense sectors hurtle into the digital era, the necessity to reshape
existing mission engineering (ME) practices to accommodate the rapidly expanding ﬁeld of
digital engineering (DE) has become more critical. The current state of mission engineering
is hindered by ambiguous guidelines that provide little support or direction for the incor-
poration of integrated digital tools, thereby demanding the formulation of more explicit,
standardized methodologies. Considerable progress has been made in transitioning from
document-centric to model-based digital activities utilizing Model-Based Systems Engineer-
ing (MBSE); however, these eﬀorts have primarily focused on system and sub-system level
modeling in the early stages of conceptual studies. A thor

er-
ing (MBSE); however, these eﬀorts have primarily focused on system and sub-system level
modeling in the early stages of conceptual studies. A thorough literature review on the ap-
plication of MBSE in mission engineering predominantly reveals a focus on the modeling of
speciﬁc space systems like propulsion systems or sensor technology. However, there is a con-
spicuous absence of eﬀorts dedicated to constructing a comprehensive, holistic perspective
of a mission, emphasizing the urgent need for a revised approach.
The integration of DE and MBSE presents substantial beneﬁts for managing complex
systems, particularly within ME processes. By providing an authoritative repository for
data and facilitating the reconﬁguration of models, DE expedites the mission engineering
process while reducing errors and iterations, thereby enhancing eﬃciency and reliability
[ 1 ]. While such digital tools and processes are gaining traction in designing, building, and
operating intricate engineering sy

operating intricate engineering systems, there’s a notable gap in their direct application to
confront existing problems. As of this research, eﬀorts to address these issues remain limited,
despite the pressing need for their resolution.
Both government and industry have recognized the mounting importance of DE, with
entities such as the Department of Defense (DoD), NASA, and aerospace companies such as
Boeing, Lockheed Marin, and Northrup Grumman prioritizing digital engineering and digital
transformation initiatives [ 2 ]–[ 4 ]. These eﬀorts aim to enhance the eﬃciency, eﬀectiveness,
design, and manufacturing processes of their missions, but despite this drive, standardized
best practices for DE and MBSE are ambiguous [ 5 ]. Existing DE practice standards fall short

1.2 Research Questions
Given the need to address the pressing issues in mission engineering (ME) methodology
and its alignment with the evolving digital engineering (DE) practices, it becomes imperative
to undertake a thorough examination of the current state of ME processes. The goal is to
identify areas for improvement and integration with DE strategies, in light of the ongoing
digital transformation within the aerospace and defense industry. The stakeholders involved,
including mission engineers, researchers, and other relevant parties, require a collaborative,
eﬃcient, integrated and user-friendly mission engineering process, e

sion engineers, researchers, and other relevant parties, require a collaborative,
eﬃcient, integrated and user-friendly mission engineering process, ensuring secure data man-
agement and fostering a comprehensive understanding through digital means.
The alignment of DE and ME can yield substantial beneﬁts by harnessing the strengths
of both disciplines. DE leverages digital tools to enhance traceability, eﬃciency, accuracy,
collaboration, accessibility of information, error reduction, communication, and complexity
management in engineering processes [ 17 ]. On the other hand, ME provides a systematic
methodology to plan, organize, and architect complex missions and systems-of-systems, fo-
cusing on achieving desired mission eﬀects [ 13 ]. Thus, the merging of DE and ME could
potentially lead to utilizing advanced digital tools to their fullest potential at each step
within the ME process.

1. How can we leverage existing mission engineering practices to develop a framework
that supports digital artifacts and tools?
2. What impact does the application of a digitally-enabled mission engineering framework
bring, and how can we quantify this impact considering the predominantly qualitative
nature of current digital engineering metrics?
