3. How does the practical implementation of a digital engineering (DE) and Model-Based
Systems Engineering (MBSE) integrated mission engineering process compare with
current practices?
In order to establish standardized practices for Mission Engineering (ME) in light of
digital transformation trends, a general framework is proposed in this paper. This frame-
work builds on existing guidelines and aims to better organize and facilitate the digital
mission engineering process. The framework is structured into multiple abstraction levels to
demonstrate the existing layers of information produced and identify relevant stakeholder
viewpoints of data to improve communication and collaboration.
1.3 Objectives, Assumptions, and Limitations
The objective of this thesis is to investigate the process of developing a comprehensive
guide for mission

.3 Objectives, Assumptions, and Limitations
The objective of this thesis is to investigate the process of developing a comprehensive
guide for mission engineering using current practices such as [ 13 ] while leveraging digital tools
and digital engineering developments conducted by the Systems Engineering Research Center
(SERC) [ 5 ], [ 18 ], [ 19 ]. In this thesis, it is hypothesized that signiﬁcant contributions to the
practical implementation of digital-enabled mission engineering in both academic research
and real-world projects can be made by establishing and aligning digital models with mission-
centric processes and guidelines, as outlined by the research questions. Speciﬁcally, the focus
is on the early-level mission and system-of-systems design process, including stakeholder
needs and objectives, requirements engineering, systems-of-systems and systems architecture,
mission threads, stakeholder networks, and systems engineering and integration, as outlined
in the Pre-Phase A a

-of-systems and systems architecture,
mission threads, stakeholder networks, and systems engineering and integration, as outlined
in the Pre-Phase A and Phase A of the NASA systems engineering process [ 20 ].
The present study is based on certain assumptions. Firstly, it should be noted that
the concept of mission engineering, as well as the term "mission," is typically associated
with military contexts, as practiced by the United States Department of Defense (US DoD).
Consequently, many of the references utilized in this thesis are from works authored by
the US DoD. Nonetheless, it is important to acknowledge that the term "mission" can also
have broader applications [ 21 ]. The focus will be on space exploration as a speciﬁc type of
14

rtant to acknowledge that the term "mission" can also
have broader applications [ 21 ]. The focus will be on space exploration as a speciﬁc type of

mission, rather than a military scenario of defense and security. Therefore, the framework
and applications presented in this study will reﬂect this speciﬁc focus.
This thesis operates under the premise that mission engineering is intrinsically linked with
systems of systems (SoS), given that most missions are achieved through the coordination and
interoperability of numerous systems. However, it’s important to clarify the speciﬁc scope
of mission engineering addressed here. This work zeroes in on certain aspects of mission
engineering rather than attempting to cover its entire, extensive breadth. The attention is
primarily directed toward high-level modeling, laying the groundwork for detailed engineering

1.4 Thesis Overview
The subsequent sections of this thesis are arranged as follows: Section 2 provides back-
ground information and a literature review on Digital Engineering, Mission Engineering, and
Model-based Systems Engineering. Section 3 delineates the research pipeline, introducing the
construction of a digital mission engineering framework. Section 4 then applies this nascent
framework to two distinctive space mission scenarios. The ﬁrst mission serves as a pilot im-
plementation, facilitating the identiﬁcation of necessary steps and potential SysML digital
artifacts within the mission engineering process; its objective is to construct a reusable cislu-
nar system of systems. The second mission, aiming to es

ifacts within the mission engineering process; its objective is to construct a reusable cislu-
nar system of systems. The second mission, aiming to establish an active debris remediation
mission, employs a standardized SysML architectural framework and is designed for compar-
ative analysis against a mission built using an existing, non-digital supportive process. The
outcomes generated from these mission implementations are then scrutinized, oﬀering anal-
ysis for each and drawing comparisons with established literature. Further, the eﬀectiveness
of the developed framework is evaluated, employing both qualitative metricsas deﬁned by
the Systems Engineering Research Center (SERC)and quantitative metrics, augmenting the
research’s validity. Case studies are also examined to provide further insights.
Concluding the thesis, Section 5 encapsulates the research work, discussing its implica-
tions and potential future avenues.

2. BACKGROUND
2.1 Digital Engineering
Digital engineering is an integrated digital approach that leverages a uniﬁed source of
data and models that are pulled from various disciplines to support lifecycle activities from
conception through disposal [ 17 ]. This digital approach combines advanced technologies,
model-based techniques, and computational tools to enable optimized solutions through
a digital engineering ecosystem [ 14 ]. The digital engineering ecosystem encompasses the
interconnected infrastructure, environment, and methodology employed to store, access, an-
alyze, and visualize the evolving data and models of systems. It provides a comprehensive
framework comprising processes, methods, and tools that cater to the needs of stakeholders,
creating an end-to-end digital enterprise [ 23 ]
Within the digital engineering ecosystem

methods, and tools that cater to the needs of stakeholders,
creating an end-to-end digital enterprise [ 23 ]
Within the digital engineering ecosystem, digital artifacts are generated, which serve as
the tangible outputs derived from the ecosystem. Digital artifacts provide data that sup-
ports alternative perspectives for visualizing, communicating, and delivering information,
data, and knowledge to stakeholders. They play a role in conveying accurate and rele-
vant information throughout the system lifecycle. One of the most crucial requirements in
establishing a digital engineering ecosystem is an Authoritative Source of Truth (ASOT).
ASOT serves as an authority that proclaims a digital artifact is valid and originates from
a legitimate and trustworthy source, ensuring the credibility and reliability of the informa-
tion provided. In the context of a digital engineering ecosystem, these authoritative sources
are digital repositories that possess expertise, judgment, and established

he context of a digital engineering ecosystem, these authoritative sources
are digital repositories that possess expertise, judgment, and established rules to store and
ensure the integrity and validity of digital artifacts [ 24 ].
Digital engineering has great promise to improve the eﬃciency and productivity of en-
gineering activities through technological innovation, particularly for complex engineering
systems [ 5 ]. It is a multidisciplinary approach that allows engineers and stakeholders to
create, analyze, and modify digital models of complex systems. This enables eﬃcient collab-
oration and decision-making throughout the design process. Digital engineering is incredibly
useful as it enhances productivity, connects people, processes, data, and capabilities. It
also reforms business practices, reduces cost, shortens development cycles, and improves
17

ty, connects people, processes, data, and capabilities. It
also reforms business practices, reduces cost, shortens development cycles, and improves
17

the overall quality of products and systems [ 14 ]. The United States Department of De-
fense (DoD) has become increasingly interested in digital engineering and its application
to mission engineering and is one of the leading organizations conducting research, along
with many collaborators and universities, on the implementation and advancement of digital
engineering. A digital engineering strategy was released by the DoD in 2018, and there have
been multiple eﬀorts since then to successfully implement a wide-scale digital transformation
across their enterprise [ 25 ].
In the aerospace industry, digital engineering plays a crucial role in advancing research
and development eﬀorts. For instance, digital engineering tools and methodology are used to
plan, design, and simulate cislunar and orbital trajectories. This enables well-documente

tance, digital engineering tools and methodology are used to
plan, design, and simulate cislunar and orbital trajectories. This enables well-documented,
eﬃcient, and precise calculations for orbital maneuvers, space exploration, and military
missions.
Two studies demonstrate the application of digital engineering in space domain awareness
mission engineering. Knister integrated MATLAB and STK to simulate and analyze basic
satellite conﬁgurations in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) and Geostationary Orbit (GEO) for a
space mission [ 26 ]. With STK, Knister studied how objects move in space and calculated
when they have limited access due to Earth blocking their view or certain angles preventing
sensors from detecting them. This information, along with other parameters, was then
automatically sent to MATLAB to calculate the Signal-to-Noise Ratios (SNRs) for each
sensor and assess their ability to detect and track the target. By using this digital tool
combination, Knister was able to speed up and a

s) for each
sensor and assess their ability to detect and track the target. By using this digital tool
combination, Knister was able to speed up and automate the process of gathering information
needed to evaluate the performance of satellite constellations in LEO and GEO. In another
study, Williams synthesized a methodology that combines digital engineering and mission
engineering to showcase the value of automated modeling, simulation, and analysis workﬂows
[ 6 ]. The study highlights how digital engineering can aid in meeting the DoD vision of digital
transformation and expedite delivery within the rapidly changing space environment.
The implementation of digital engineering in aerospace applications and beyond presents
several challenges and limitations. Researchers, such as Williams and others, have experi-
enced diﬃculties in programming and integrating multiple digital tools, potentially causing
delays in research and implementation processes. These delays can be attributed to a

mming and integrating multiple digital tools, potentially causing
delays in research and implementation processes. These delays can be attributed to a lack of
18

familiarity and experience with these tools, but their impact can decrease with time [ 6 ], [ 27 ].
Furthermore, the adoption of digital engineering in academia and industry remains limited,
impeding the pace of digital transformation. Additionally, digital engineering is still in its
early stages and has yet to be widely embraced as a new work culture [ 6 ].
Furthermore, it is important to note that digital engineering is a relatively new and
evolving ﬁeld, and its widespread adoption is still underway. Consequently, there are fewer
established research studies and publications in comparison to more established disciplines.
The rapid pace of technological advancements in digital engineering presents a challenge
for academic research to keep up and publish ﬁndings before they become outdated. Addi-
tionally, due to the compet

l engineering presents a challenge
for academic research to keep up and publish ﬁndings before they become outdated. Addi-
tionally, due to the competitive nature of the industry, digital engineering providers often
prioritize safeguarding their proprietary knowledge and techniques, limiting the dissemina-
tion of research through scholarly channels. These challenges and limitations raise concerns
about the readiness of digital engineering for integration into existing systems, programs,
and missions, prompting frequent discussions among experts in mission and systems engi-
neering. However, extensive research is being conducted to further advance and develop
digital engineering throughout all stages of the engineering lifecycle, making it a signiﬁcant
and actively explored topic [ 28 ].
2.2 Mission Engineering
Digital engineering principles and implementation possibilities provide the basis for trans-
forming the planning, analysis, organization, and integration of support and emergin

les and implementation possibilities provide the basis for trans-
forming the planning, analysis, organization, and integration of support and emerging oper-
ational system capabilities to achieve speciﬁc desired eﬀects. This process, known as mission
engineering, encompasses an analytical and data-driven approach to examine the various
aspects of a mission and make informed trade-oﬀs. Mission engineering analysis enables
the generation of new ideas, systems, technologies, or tactics to enhance future military
operations. To facilitate quantitative analysis and evaluate proposed approaches, it is vital
to thoroughly document and understand the mission deﬁnition, assumptions, constraints,
success metrics, and input data. Mission engineering involves designing multiple alternative
missions, identifying mission drivers, measuring, and comparing eﬀectiveness, and conduct-
19

sion engineering involves designing multiple alternative
missions, identifying mission drivers, measuring, and comparing eﬀectiveness, and conduct-
19

ing sensitivity analysis on speciﬁc parameters, such as the relationship between weapon speed
and mission success. However, mission engineering, with its principles and concepts, tran-
scends these boundaries and ﬁnds relevance in diverse domains that involve mission-oriented
endeavors, such as space exploration and other mission-driven activities. In the context of
mission engineering, digital engineering plays a critical role by enabling the sustainment of
mission threads (MTs) and architectures, integrated analytical capabilities, common mission
representations, and a scalable set of tools [ 13 ].
Missions typically involve the collaborative eﬀorts of multiple systems working together
and exchanging information. These collaborative systems are known as mission-oriented
system-of-systems (SoS), which aim to eﬃciently create and deploy

nd exchanging information. These collaborative systems are known as mission-oriented
system-of-systems (SoS), which aim to eﬃciently create and deploy SoS with a desired set
of functions and goals. The objective is to facilitate the rapid conception, assembly, and
deployment of mission-oriented SoS, enabling eﬀective solutions for immediate challenges
[ 13 ], [ 21 ]. The mission engineering process, in line with the concept of mission and its
goals, generally encompasses six main phases, as deﬁned by the Under Secretary of Defense
for Engineering in the Mission Engineering Guidebook [ 13 ]. It is mostly catered towards
military missions; however, the methodology is broad enough for it to be mostly applicable
to any type of mission such as space exploration missions. It provides a structured approach
for conducting mission engineering activities and ensuring mission success. The six phases
are summarized in Table 2.1 and deﬁned as follows:
Figure 2.1. Mission Engineering Phases as deﬁne

vities and ensuring mission success. The six phases
are summarized in Table 2.1 and deﬁned as follows:
Figure 2.1. Mission Engineering Phases as deﬁned by the Under Secretary
of Defense for Engineering: Mission Engineering Guide [ 13 ].

d as follows:
Figure 2.1. Mission Engineering Phases as deﬁned by the Under Secretary

20

1. Problem Statement Phase: This involves clearly deﬁning the problem or challenge
that the mission aims to address. It includes identifying the operational needs, under-
standing the mission objectives, and establishing the context and constraints of the
mission.
2. Mission Characterization Phase: The mission is characterized by deﬁning the desired
mission sequence and capabilities, operational concepts, and the system-of-systems
architecture. It involves identifying the requirements and deﬁning the mission’s func-
tional and performance attributes.
3. Mission Metrics Phase: The mission metrics phase focuses on deﬁning the metrics
that will be used to evaluate the success of the mission. These metrics should align
with the mission objectives and provide measurable criteria for assessing the success,
eﬀectiveness, and performance of the

These metrics should align
with the mission objectives and provide measurable criteria for assessing the success,
eﬀectiveness, and performance of the mission.
4. Design of Analysis Phase: This phase involves designing the analysis approach to
evaluate mission alternatives, assess risks, and optimize the mission design. It includes
selecting appropriate modeling and simulation tools, deﬁning analysis scenarios, and
establishing criteria for evaluating diﬀerent mission options.
5. Modeling and Analysis Phase: The mission is then analyzed using various modeling
and simulation techniques deﬁned in the earlier phase. This includes performing trade
studies, sensitivity analysis, and performance evaluations to assess the impact of dif-
ferent factors on mission outcomes. The results of the analysis inform decision-making
and help identify the most eﬀective mission design.
6. Documentation Phase: The ﬁnal phase focuses on documenting the mission engineering
process and its outcomes. This incl

ost eﬀective mission design.
6. Documentation Phase: The ﬁnal phase focuses on documenting the mission engineering
process and its outcomes. This includes capturing the mission requirements, analysis
results, design decisions, and recommendations in a formal document. The documenta-
tion serves as a record of the mission engineering activities, facilitates communication
among stakeholders, and provides a foundation for future mission iterations and im-
provements.
21

n engineering activities, facilitates communication
among stakeholders, and provides a foundation for future mission iterations and im-
provements.
21

These phases provide a systematic framework for mission engineering using mission-
centric ontology, ensuring that key concepts of the mission are known and addressed, and that
decisions are based on analysis and evaluation. The ME process allows for the identiﬁcation
of trade-oﬀs, the optimization of mission designs, and the mitigation of risks. By following
these phases, mission engineers can eﬀectively plan, design, and execute missions that align
with stakeholder needs, meet mission objectives, and achieve mission success.
There are other resources and documentation that are similar and can be useful for the
mission engineering process which includes the NASA Systems Engineering Handbook [ 20 ],
System-of-system modeling and design [ 29 ], and the Space Mission Analysis and Design [ 30 ].

The NASA Systems Engineering Handbook serves as a resource for the mission engi-
neering process. It provides comprehensive guidance on systems engineering principles and
practices, oﬀering insights into system analysis, requirements development, risk manage-
ment, veriﬁcation and validation, and other key areas relevant to mission engineering. By
leveraging the knowledge and best practices outlined in the handbook, mission engineers can
ensure the systematic and disciplined approach necessary for successful mission execution.
The handbook’s emphasis on a holistic systems perspective aligns well with the mission
engineering methodology, as it promotes t

ul mission execution.
The handbook’s emphasis on a holistic systems perspective aligns well with the mission
engineering methodology, as it promotes the understanding of the interdependencies and in-
teractions among system elements, stakeholders, and mission objectives. Overall, the NASA
Systems Engineering Handbook provides mission engineers with a reference and guide to
eﬀectively navigate the complexities of mission engineering and deliver mission success [ 20 ].
Similarly, the book "System of Systems Modeling and Analysis" by DeLaurentis et al.
oﬀers guidance that can be beneﬁcial for the mission engineering process. It provides a com-
prehensive understanding of Systems of Systems (SoS) engineering principles and methodolo-
gies, which are relevant for eﬀectively managing and integrating multiple systems in mission-
oriented contexts. By exploring the three main phases of Deﬁnition, Abstraction, and Im-
plementation of an SoS, the book equips mission engineers with the knowledge

s. By exploring the three main phases of Deﬁnition, Abstraction, and Im-
plementation of an SoS, the book equips mission engineers with the knowledge and tools to
analyze complex interactions and trade-oﬀs within an interconnected system. It also oﬀers

principles and their application to mission engineering. Overall, the book serves as a valuable
resource for mission engineers seeking to navigate the challenges and complexities involved
in the engineering of a mission-oriented SoS [ 29 ].
Focusing on space missions, the book "Space Mission Analysis and Design" (SMAD) pro-
vides a comprehensive overview of the phases involved in space mission analysis and design.
The key phases covered in the book include mission statement and requirements deﬁnition,
concept exploration, system-level design, spacecraft subsystem design, launch system selec-
tion and design, mission operations, and mission management. These phases align with
the general methodology of mission engineering by emphasizing the systemat

design, mission operations, and mission management. These phases align with
the general methodology of mission engineering by emphasizing the systematic approach to
analyze mission requirements, explore alternative concepts, design and integrate systems,
and manage mission operations. The SMAD book is particularly helpful for mission engi-
neering as it oﬀers detailed insights into the speciﬁc considerations and challenges related
to space missions. It provides practical methods, tools, and techniques to evaluate mission
requirements, analyze mission performance, and assess the feasibility and eﬀectiveness of
diﬀerent design options. By following the SMAD approach, mission engineers can system-
atically deﬁne mission objectives, establish mission architectures, evaluate trade-oﬀs, and
optimize mission performance. Furthermore, the SMAD book emphasizes the importance of
interdisciplinary collaboration and system-level thinking, which are key aspects of mission
engineering. It highlights

ok emphasizes the importance of

engineering. It highlights the integration of various subsystems, operational aspects, and
management considerations to ensure mission success. The book’s comprehensive nature
and practical examples make it a valuable resource for mission engineers, helping them nav-
igate the complexities of space mission analysis and design while aligning with the broader
principles of mission engineering [ 30 ], [ 31 ].
To summarize, sources such as the NASA Systems Engineering Handbook, the "System

ysis and Design" (SMAD) all provide methodologies and techniques that can be used in

DIGITAL ENGINEERING WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT: CHALLENGES, BEST PRACTICES, AND RECOMMENDATIONS
 4
Executive Summary 
There has been a resurgence of interest in digital engineering modernization in the past several years as companies 
and governments try to increase their competitiveness in the defense and industrial aerospace sectors. Why the 
renewed interest? Advances in computational power combined with the emergence of artificial intelligence heralds 
a new era for the complex digital ecosystem of aerospace engineering. The application of these technologies to 
the design and analysis of complex aerospace vehicles portends significant opportunities to decrease the time to 
market for new products and reduce the cost and risk for developmental opportunities. However, will the workforce 
of the future be prepared to develop and take advan

roducts and reduce the cost and risk for developmental opportunities. However, will the workforce 
of the future be prepared to develop and take advantage of these improved capabilities? This paper, authored by the 
AIAA Digital Engineering Integration Committee (DEIC), delves into the transformative impacts digital engineering 
tools and methods have and will have on the aerospace industry and examines the multifaceted landscape of digital 
engineering workforce development. The authors articulate the pressing need for a skilled digital engineering 
workforce and provide an in-depth analysis of the challenges, opportunities, and necessary strategies to cultivate a 
skilled workforce adept at leveraging these modern tools and methodologies.
This paper charts the evolution of digital engineering, from the introduction of CAD systems in the 1970s to 
sophisticated three-dimensional modeling, PLM tools, digital threads, and digital twins that define the contemporary 
landscape. These tech

1970s to 
sophisticated three-dimensional modeling, PLM tools, digital threads, and digital twins that define the contemporary 
landscape. These technologies have revolutionized design, development, and manufacturing processes, enhancing 
quality, efficiency, and reducing the need for iterative changes. More importantly, technology fosters an integrated 
and data-driven engineering environment that cuts across organizational silos to enhance decision-making and 
process transparency and efficiency across the project life cycle.
Addressing workforce dynamics, this work underscores a dichotomy between the emergent, digitally adept 
professionals and the more seasoned personnel accustomed to traditional methodologies. It emphasizes the pivotal 
role that leadership and culture play in bridging these divides, highlights the rapidly evolving nature of the skill sets 
required, and advocates for a collaborative approach to workforce development, where academia, industry, and 
government ali

nature of the skill sets 
required, and advocates for a collaborative approach to workforce development, where academia, industry, and 
government align their efforts to meet the fast-evolving technological demands.
In addressing education and training, the authors call for an update of existing curricula and argue for the integration 
of digital engineering components such as systems engineering, model-based systems engineering (MBSE), 
cybersecurity, data analysis, design engineering, test and evaluation, data analytics, manufacturing, deployment and 
real-time visualization technologies into undergraduate programs to not only prepare students for the industry’s 
current demands, but also equip them with the agility to adapt to future technological advances.
Additionally, the paper introduces a pioneering digital ecosystem roles-based taxonomy aimed to clarify roles and 
delineate the digital competencies required across different organizational levels. This taxonomy also aims to sup

axonomy aimed to clarify roles and 
delineate the digital competencies required across different organizational levels. This taxonomy also aims to support 
the effective implementation of digital engineering practices and assist organizations in developing precise training 
and development programs that are tailored to meet specific role-based needs.
Through a series of success stories across academia, industry, and government, the authors report on strategies and 
initiatives that have been successful in cultivating the required skills and competencies.
Finally, a proposal to accelerate the development of a digital engineering workforce through a series of 
recommendations is included.

DIGITAL ENGINEERING WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT: CHALLENGES, BEST PRACTICES, AND RECOMMENDATIONS
 5
The field of digital engineering is a cross-disciplinary 
evolution of many other discipline-specific fields of STEM 
(science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) 
that leverages the holistic application of modern digital 
tools and processes for the design, development, and 
production of solutions spanning the life cycle of 
the effort. This can include a program, project, and/
or product, with the holistic emphasis aiming to 
improve process efficiency, inform timely data-driven 
decision making, and reduce risk. Digital engineering 
is characterized by cross-disciplinary collaboration, 
modern digital tools, and interconnected, scalable 
processes. As such digital engineering represents 
the greatest force of change within the engine

modern digital tools, and interconnected, scalable 
processes. As such digital engineering represents 
the greatest force of change within the engineering 
community, impacting both the organizational structure 
of enterprises and the way engineers practice their art. 
Digital engineering was initiated with computer-aided 
design (CAD) systems in the 1970s, which produced 
two-dimensional (2D) drawings and eliminated the full-
sized drawing boards used for the first 50 years of the 
aerospace industry. Two-dimensional computer-aided 
design was followed by the emergence of three-
dimensional (3D) modeling software and product life 
cycle management (PLM) tools in the 1980s and 1990s. 
The use of 3D models for aerospace programs dramatically 
improved initial engineering and manufacturing 
quality, reduced changes, and facilitated advanced 
manufacturing technologies including automation, 
robotics, additive manufacturing, augmented reality, 
and advanced metrology. Hence, digital engi

d 
manufacturing technologies including automation, 
robotics, additive manufacturing, augmented reality, 
and advanced metrology. Hence, digital engineering 
should not be confused with digitization, which is the 
act of converting analog information to digital form.
The DoD Digital Engineering Strategy [1] defines digital 
engineering as “an integrated digital approach that uses 
authoritative sources of systems’ data and models as 
a continuum across disciplines to support life cycle 
activities from concept through disposal.” As such digital 
engineering is not limited to the description of physics-
based elements and their interfaces. It leverages 
advancements in computing, modeling (including 
system modeling), data analytics, visualization, and 
artificial Intelligence/machine learning (AI/ML) to reduce 
new product development costs, improve initial development 
maturity, enable simulation-based verification to reduce 
physical testing, and support systems deployment and 
sust

sts, improve initial development 
maturity, enable simulation-based verification to reduce 
physical testing, and support systems deployment and 
sustainment in the face of evolving mission needs [2]. 
Digital Engineering Is Not Just 
Model-Based Engineering
Digital engineering extends beyond model-based 
engineering (MBE). It builds on systems engineering 
(SE) principles and the rigorous intentionality of model-
based systems engineering (MBSE) practices. By 
architecting system and system-of-system processes, 
interfaces, and flows, the project life cycle can be 
seamlessly integrated across the data, models, and 
analysis. Unlike MBE and computer-aided engineering 
(CAE), digital engineering integrates disparate domains, 
source systems, and life cycle stages into a cohesive 
digital ecosystem. It employs digital twin and digital 
thread technology to provide continuous, real-time 
insights and updates, supporting end-to-end life cycle 
management from design to disposal [3].
Digit

ead technology to provide continuous, real-time 
insights and updates, supporting end-to-end life cycle 
management from design to disposal [3].
Digital Engineering Is 
Not Just about Engineering
Digital Engineering is driving the integration of classic 
engineering tools like PLM and CAD with manufacturing 
execution systems (MES), finance and supply chain 
tools like enterprise resource planning (ERP), and finally 
sustainment systems, which support customer product 
usage in the field. Today these tools are traditionally 
highly siloed and structured around the processes, tools, 
and philosophies of the “owning” function – for example 
engineering historically owns PLM and CAD tools and 
capabilities, and manufacturing owns MES tools. The 
PLM system and functional capabilities will need to 
evolve to incorporate model-based system engineering; 
unique digital twin engineering characteristics; and 
the complex management of data, information, and 
knowledge associated with digital t

ineering; 
unique digital twin engineering characteristics; and 
the complex management of data, information, and 
knowledge associated with digital threads [4].
SECTION 1 
Introduction and Context 

DIGITAL ENGINEERING WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT: CHALLENGES, BEST PRACTICES, AND RECOMMENDATIONS
 6
As these tools become more integrated, enterprises 
will benefit from greater insight and predictability of 
processes [5] as well as the ability to automate data 
analysis, metrics, and standard reports [3]. Digital engineering 
will also allow employees to quickly produce customized 
reports using low-code or no-code applications [4]. 
Digital engineering is a driver for integration across 
all aspects of an aerospace enterprise’s business and 
technical systems and therefore will be a valuable 
component in reducing cost and span time risks 
and lead to more efficient and successful program 
prosecutions. DE acts as a non-engineering force 
multiplier by establishing the framework for business

ead to more efficient and successful program 
prosecutions. DE acts as a non-engineering force 
multiplier by establishing the framework for business 
(e.g., cost, schedule,), safety (e.g., risk, hazards), etc., to 
all be interconnected, such that a step forward in one 
area is a step forward in the realization/establishment of 
the digital ecosystem. The improved digital ecosystem 
is intended to reduce the cost and schedule risks we 
have seen on large historical programs by providing a 
more mature product at the start of the detailed design 
phase of commercial and military programs as well as 
better connecting products with their digital twins to 
support the operation of these products throughout 
the life cycle. As important as tool integration is to 
enterprise digital transformation, it is equally important 
to reevaluate the functional relationships. All job 
functions (customers and contractors) are or will be 
asked to reevaluate their job functions in the context 
of dig

unctional relationships. All job 
functions (customers and contractors) are or will be 
asked to reevaluate their job functions in the context 
of digital product development. The functional areas 
outlined above often have very rigid policies and 
procedures in place (contracting for example) that may 
be the long pole in the tent for a digital transformation. 
A foundational digital engineering taxonomy is needed 
that helps the DE community better set context for how 
digital engineering fits within the broader functions of the 
digital ecosystem across the life cycle and how other 
functional areas such as program management, logistics, 
financial management, contracting, information technology, 
etc., are integrated. This digital engineering taxonomy 
not only facilitates the effective implementation 
of digital engineering practices, but also provides a 
framework for developing the future workforce that will 
carry out these transformative processes. 
As discussed later in this

, but also provides a 
framework for developing the future workforce that will 
carry out these transformative processes. 
As discussed later in this paper, the transition toward 
digital is also challenging existing expertise and skills, 
forcing a seasoned workforce to embrace new mental 
models and develop new skills and competencies [6]. 
DE is also significantly impacting the roles that tomorrow’s 
workforce will fulfill and consequently the way this 
digital engineering workforce of the future shall be 
educated and trained [7]. This shift necessitates a critical 
focus on organizational culture, also discussed later, in 
which continuous adaptation, innovation, and a commitment 
to leveraging technology is embraced by all. 
The need to strengthen digital engineering and related 
capabilities is one of the priorities set forth by the U.S. 
DoD [8, 9] as well as industry players [4, 10, 11]. Hence, as 
the aerospace industry aims to accelerate and benefit 
from the practice of dig

e U.S. 
DoD [8, 9] as well as industry players [4, 10, 11]. Hence, as 
the aerospace industry aims to accelerate and benefit 
from the practice of digital engineering, there is an 
urgent need to close the digital competence gap and 
support the development and training of a skilled 
workforce capable of using digital tools, processes, and 
methodologies effectively [1, 2, 4, 7, 8, 12, 13].
This paper first discusses the competencies required 
for a digital engineering workforce. It then presents the 
many challenges that impede the development of such 
a workforce, and discusses the roles that academia, 
industry, and government can play in accelerating 
the development and training of a workforce that can 
successfully leverage digital engineering technologies. 
This paper then discusses how to effectively assess, 
plan, integrate, and manage emerging and maturing 
technologies as a means to enhance both organizational 
and technical capabilities. Because digital engineering 
permeat

manage emerging and maturing 
technologies as a means to enhance both organizational 
and technical capabilities. Because digital engineering 
permeates all levels of the digital ecosystem (from 
leadership to management and engineering teams, 
to stakeholders and end users), this paper also 
proposes a digital ecosystem roles-based taxonomy 
aimed at efficiently describing roles within a digital 
ecosystem and identifying the digital skills needed 
across organizational roles. Finally, this document 
presents a set of best practices, lessons learned, and 
recommendations to help recruit, develop, and retain

Successful adoption of digital engineering practices will 
require that traditional culture, knowledge, and methods 
develop complementary aptitude facility with digital 
models and computational methods (including data 
science and machine learning/AI/ML). Unfortunately, 
even flawless performance by technical staff will fail 
to transform if executive decision-makers remain 
insufficiently confident in model-based methods.
Developing executive confidence requires proficiency 
in comprehension of digital models and methods to 
understand results informing decisions. This includes 
comprehension of model limitations, sources of error, 
sensitivities, assumptions, and the means to address 
any such shortcomings. Correspondingly, technical 
staff

f model limitations, sources of error, 
sensitivities, assumptions, and the means to address 
any such shortcomings. Correspondingly, technical 
staff must develop aptitude in composition of models, 
simulations, and data analytics that communicate results 
that are explicit, specific, concise, complete, consistent, 
as well as adequately qualified and quantified. This 
comprehension and composition form the familiar 
notion of “literacy,” a key element of collaborative 
problem-solving that underlies the value and impact of 
digital engineering.
In striving to ensure institutional growth and vitality, 
organizations must continually develop the capabilities 
and potential of their members to contribute. However, 
the knowledge, skills, and behaviors will differ from new 
entrant to executive roles. One model frames career 
contexts into four stages [14], defining a primary role and 
description for each stage.
1. Learning (contributing dependently): build 
individual capability and cr

four stages [14], defining a primary role and 
description for each stage.
1. Learning (contributing dependently): build 
individual capability and credibility.
2. Doing (contributing independently): responsibly 
apply established expertise.
3. Guiding (contributing through others): develop 
individuals, groups, and interconnections.
4. Shaping (contributing strategically): prioritize 
resources and opportunities toward impact.
An entire career may remain in stage-2, or a promotion 
may result in beginning again in stage-1 in a new role. 
The structure need not simply overlay an organizational 
hierarchy. However, it may be useful to apply in 
distinguishing between responsibilities and growth 
opportunities for transformation (digital, model-based, 
or otherwise).

nt – Efficient and cost-effective data 
management is becoming increasingly essential in 
digital engineering, where vast volumes of data are 
generated and utilized across product development and

asset for companies, government bodies, and academia 
alike, with every interaction in our environment producing 
large quantities of data in diverse structures and often 
at high frequency. Activities such as data collection, 
storage, organization, filtering, and analysis require a 
skilled workforce capable of handling these demands. 
One of the key challenges in cultivating this workforce 
is ensuring that engineering graduates possess 
foundational knowledge and skills to manage, store, 
and retrieve data effectively. This includes principles 
of data governance, data quality management, data 
structuring, and establishing robust databases and data 
lakes for cloud environments to handle both structured 
and unstructured data.

computer engineering or targeted fields.
By incorporating essential data management courses 
and practical applications into undergraduate 
engineering curricula, academic institutions can better 
prepare students for the complexities of data-driven 
digital engineering environments. Such courses should 
emphasize data handling fundamentals, data ethics, and 
regulatory compliance while introducing students to 
industry-standard tools and platforms. This approach 
will facilitate a smoother transition for graduates 
entering professional roles in both industry and 
government sectors.

DevOps is a process which, at its core, is about pushing 
small updates and changes to production very quickly. 
DevSecOps is essentially the same idea except security 
is kept at the forefront of all efforts. Agile, when boiled 
down, is the concept of fixing resources on a project 
and allowing scope and directions to change as needed. 
This is in contrast to more waterfall-style approaches, 
where the scope and direction are agreed at project/
program initiation and resources and timelines are 
adjusted. The adoption of Agile and DevOps style 
working practices in more regulated industries outside 
of tech, as well as teams working on more than software 
for the web has begun.
Additionally, the need for teams that can work at the 
intersect

side 
of tech, as well as teams working on more than software 
for the web has begun.
Additionally, the need for teams that can work at the 
intersection of traditional engineering and modern 
(Agile) software engineering is another emerging trend. 
When more traditional engineers can take the time to 
learn about modern software practices and perhaps 
integrate tech-trained software engineers into their 
teams, a synergy is developed leading to vastly better 
outcomes. The Agile and DevOps practitioners ensure 
no over-planning early in the life cycle and keep work 
pieces small. Other stakeholders will ensure governance 
and compliance needs are met and bring the industry-
specific knowledge necessary to support these trends. 
This cohesive model can truly bring some of the 
amazing work the tech world has accomplished into 
more traditional regulated industries.

 12
The challenges to develop a workforce capable of 
using digital engineering technologies effectively are 
numerous, ranging from deficits in education and 
training, to technological advances, to cultural divides. 
Each domain has its own distinct problems and equally 
diverse methods need to be explored to solve these 
challenges. In enumerating the challenges that exist, 
only the top perceived issues are included, which is not 
to imply that there are not more challenges. However, 
one issue that repeatedly appeared in each challenge 
was the lack of alignment between industry, academia, 
and government. That alignment is addressed and points 
to an overarching need to improve communication and 
collaboration to solve many obstacles in digi

government. That alignment is addressed and points 
to an overarching need to improve communication and 
collaboration to solve many obstacles in digital engineering.
A current issue facing industry is a growing need for 
engineers. The Bureau of Labor predicts a continued 
need for engineers, with a reported 6.9% growth 
expected through 2032. However, as of now, engineering 
programs are not recruiting, retaining, and graduating 
enough students to fill this need. Coupled with the 
current hiring practices and traditional salary restrictions, 
which also lacks the critical ongoing adaptation to need, 
engineering in general faces real difficulty. “There are 
issues with current hiring practices in evaluating skills 
within the hiring process and the discrepancy between 
job descriptions and actual job requirements” [20, 21]. 
Given this ambiguity, career paths in digital engineering 
are not well-defined or as well-understood as other 
career paths or lack formal recognition altogeth

ambiguity, career paths in digital engineering 
are not well-defined or as well-understood as other 
career paths or lack formal recognition altogether [22]. 
This issue will continue to exacerbate the poor recruitment, 
retention, and overall management of a DE workforce. 
Education and Training
The workforce of today and the needed workforce 
of tomorrow face a tremendous task of not only 
bridging the skill gap, but of first identifying the skill 
requirements [23]. The pace of change and technological 
innovation, coupled with the varied requirements 
across many platforms and careers, mean the current 
and future workforce will need to embrace continuous 
learning and adapt to the changes. 
Evolving Skill Requirements
In higher education settings, the traditional focus on 
the professional engineer with the same curriculum and 
requirements from 50 years ago needs to adapt, keeping 
pace with industry. Engineers joining the workforce 
today may have been exposed to 3D CAD, variou

irements from 50 years ago needs to adapt, keeping 
pace with industry. Engineers joining the workforce 
today may have been exposed to 3D CAD, various 
mathematical analysis techniques, modeling tools, 
and some computer programming literacy, but often 
theoretical with little hands-on experience. Experiential 
learning in artificial intelligence (AI), modeling, and 
simulation are often reserved for graduate programs, 
since physical equipment, computing resources, and 
basic curriculum space at the undergraduate level are 
often limited. In the current environment, changes 
are needed to support the next wave of digital 
transformation, which as indicated in the Digital 
Engineering Workforce Plan [12], is focused on model-
based systems engineering (MBSE), data integration, 
downstream consumption [23], and the modeling 
and simulation of environments combined with the 
validation of simulations to support test reduction.

the evolving skill requirements in digital engineering

of multiple stakeholders:
FACULTY AND ADMINISTRATION
Faculty that maintains and perpetuates the traditional 
structures of lecture-based learning and an adherence 
to the traditional engineering programming can 
miss out on the innovation in modern teaching and 
learning. These same faculty members make up the 
deciding bodies of higher education administrative 
functions, like course and program creation and 
maintenance, often taking a traditional stance and 
failing to realize the need to adapt and incorporate 
new technology and integrate new disciplines. Slow 
and cumbersome curriculum review boards and a 
theoretical foundation that lacks modern competencies 
make meeting digital requirements of the workforce 
difficult. It is also valuable to seek staff with aerospace 
industry experience to bring real world techniques and 
requirements to the students.
ACCREDITING BO

It is also valuable to seek staff with aerospace 
industry experience to bring real world techniques and 
requirements to the students.
ACCREDITING BODIES
Important to the success and continued operation 
of academic programming, accrediting bodies 
maintain the level of rigor across programs. Program 
accreditation, an important component of successful 
academic programs, sometimes creates rigid structure 
and reinforces historical standards for teaching and 
learning. The process of accreditation does not always 
encourage or reward innovation and creativity, which 
can create complacency. Undergraduate programs 
continue to struggle with balancing between necessary 
foundational curriculum in engineering and the need 
to modernize, while trying to limit the required number 
of credit hours of a Bachelor of Science degree. In 
large engineering departments in institutions of higher 
education, there is often disagreement in the ‘right’ 
approach to this struggle, overshadowed by the

ineering departments in institutions of higher 
education, there is often disagreement in the ‘right’ 
approach to this struggle, overshadowed by the fear of 
a poor accreditation cycle result. For fields undergoing 
rapid change, a more agile and responsive approach 
to accreditation is essential to remain relevant and 
effective. Hence, while not advocating for the complete 
overhaul of accreditation standards, greater pace of 
adaptation and the inclusion of modern technologies 
such as MBSE and visualization into curricula, along with 
improved support for cross disciplinary flexibility, will 
better prepare students for the modern workplace.
INDUSTRY
Industry participation and communication require 
devoting time and resources to sharing industry needs 
and critically reviewing the program content. Multiple 
frameworks make it harder for these employers to 
establish clear signals for demand and creates difficulty 
for educators offering training and support in programs

competencies across the enterprise, for government 
and industry employers. This leads to a lack of available 
certifications and learning programs for experienced 
staff and managers to stay current and relevant, limiting

Educational Program Structure and Content
The demands of engineering undergraduate programs 
can intimidate new college students and challenging 
programs often find pride in ‘weeding out’ those 
unprepared, leading to low recruitment and retention. 
Most critically, the United States needs to increase 
overall engineering graduates, as well as increase the 
recruitment and support for women and minority 
graduates in STEM majors. As the cost of college 
education in the United States has dramatically 
increased over the past 20 years, STEM programs, 
especially engineering, with rigorous and demanding 
schedules, may shift students away from STEM majors 
based on the considerable risk in assuming educational 
loans. For the future digital wor

anding 
schedules, may shift students away from STEM majors 
based on the considerable risk in assuming educational 
loans. For the future digital workforce, middle school, 
high school, and junior colleges fall short in the 
preparation for math and science. These students 
need early exposure to engineering and manufacturing 
careers including shop, computer, and industrial 
programs aimed at preparing them to enter aerospace 
and related manufacturing fields.

Upskilling
Advanced visualization technologies have a proven 
history of delivering drastic, transformational changes 
to the speed at which new skills can be learned and the 
amount of learning that is required to become proficient 
in them.
Virtual reality (VR) training has proven so effective 
at increasing both the speed at which students learn 
and how well that learning is retained that it is rapidly 
penetrating into every industry from fast food to paper 
products to aerospace. It

combines the benefits of “learning by doing” an actual 
task on an actual object with the lack of constraint of 
a digital world, allowing for the conveyance of a depth 
of information not possible in the real world due to 
physical or safety constraints. Students can quickly 
disassemble products that are too heavy to interact with 
in the real world, disassemble and interact with products 
in operation, and highlight and isolate the operation of 
different subsystems in real time.

or just quality app design can guide a user through

Regulatory Framework
Frustrating many stakeholders is the antiquated 
regulatory framework that governs modern IT 
solutions. One only needs to observe the current 
strategic undertaking for artificial intelligence currently 
under debate in the U.S. and Europe to find a lack 
of agreement and understanding. Decisions guiding 
the development and sustainment of technological 
fields are taking years to decide, often with continued 
disagreement and development. Many continue to 
weigh in, even as technology outpaces the proposed 
solutions, causing a continued delay in guidance.

Organizational Specific Solutions
The technical challenges involved with digital 
engineering have gained sufficient visibility that the 
industry is naturally pivoting to address the gaps and 
deficiencies. However, the best technical solutions 
for each organization will be dependent on what 
is attempting to be accomplished [7]. As regulatory 
frameworks and technology continue to develop, it 
should be noted that the solutions and guidance may 
not work for every company. Differences in culture, 
management, funding, strategy, and any number of 
other variables mean that solutions should be tailored 
based on those characteristics important to the 
company and development. This creates a new layer of 
work to be done, which may often be pushed aside for 
more important or emergent problems.

Keeping Pace with Technology 
From an industry and government perspective, having 
relevant, modern platforms which are both secure and 
accessible to the workforce is a considerable challenge 
considering how quickly technology is changing and 
the requirements for security. The cost to keep pace 
is prohibitive to all but the top performers bringing in 
large capital investments. Without financial investments, 
refreshing and maintaining top tools becomes a 
secondary goal to survival. Without access to the latest 
tools, the workforce cannot operate at the edge of 
technology, causing a skilled workforce to shift from 
traditional companies to commercial organizations, 
where tools are available to develop skillsets ‘at the 
speed of relevance’ to the larger marketplace. This 
speed matters not only to the individual worker’s 
professional development, but also the larger and urgent 
need to advance technology. Agile practices around 
“start small, think big” have potential, but

ssional development, but also the larger and urgent 
need to advance technology. Agile practices around 
“start small, think big” have potential, but have yet to be 
properly adopted across most accredited industries.

Digital Transformation
It is easy to focus on the technical solutions when 
discussing digital engineering and digital workforce 
development; however, the criticality of human 
factors and leadership cannot be understated for a 
digital transformation to have a realistic likelihood 
of success. The paper “Impact of Organizational 
Culture on Organizational Climate during the Process 
of Change” by Juris Iljins et al. [26] explores how 
organizational culture affects organizational climate 
amid changes. The study confirmed that organizational 
culture plays a crucial role in affecting organizational 
climate during periods of change. Factors such as 
employees’ satisfaction, adaptability, involvement, 
mission, and consistency were identified as critical 
eleme

ORGANIZATIONAL DIGITAL TRANSFORMATION HAS 
HIGH FAILURE RATES 
Various consultancies, including Forbes, McKinsey, 
BCG, KPMG, and Bain & Company, estimate failure for 
organizational digital transformation ranging from 70% 
to 95%, indicating a prevailing issue in the field. John 
Kotter, in his seminal work on leading organizational 
change [28], identifies eight common errors that often 
lead to failure in change initiatives. These errors are 
crucial for understanding why many change efforts do 
not achieve their intended outcomes, and include: 
not establishing a sense of urgency; not creating 
a powerful coalition; lacking a vision or not 
communicating the vision; not removing obstacles to 
success; declaring premature victory; and not anchoring 
in the organization’s culture.

FOCUS ON PEOPLE OVER TECHNOLOGY 
Primary drivers of failure are not driven by technology, 
but rather human factors related to alignment with 
business outcomes (or lack thereof), resistance and 
reluctance to change within organizations (i.e., cultural 
inertia) [29], mismanagement of Agile teams, and failure 
to communicate in non-technical terms with executives. 
This emphasis on human impact indicates a need for soft 
skills, like communication and emotional intelligence, 
not just technical skills for transformation. In addressing 
culture change, Kotter’s anchoring to the culture 
involves including instruction and support and ensuring 
the change to process both works and is superior to the 
old methods. Rogers’ diffusion of innovations theory [30] 
identifies the successive groups to accept change in 
conjunction with market adoption. Relevant to this theory, 
digital transformation has also seen a similar adoption

ept change in 
conjunction with market adoption. Relevant to this theory,

ensure a dynamic workforce that can quickly adjust to 
the needs of the organization. Early career recruitment 
should be an ongoing activity and there should be 
engagement with academic institutions to ensure the 
needed skill sets are identified. A strong talent pipeline 
will help address the challenges with sustaining a high-
performing team. For example, Agile product teams are

The “Silver Tsunami” and the Need for 
Knowledge Management
The demographic shift caused by the wave of 
retirements, particularly among baby boomers, poses 
challenges for many industries as experienced 
workers with specialized knowledge and skills leave 
the workforce. The loss of these workers may result 
in a significant knowledge gap and disrupt wor

rkers with specialized knowledge and skills leave

in a significant knowledge gap and disrupt workforce 
continuity if not addressed properly. In response to 
the anticipated loss in institutional knowledge, many 
companies are increasingly focusing on digital curation 
and knowledge management practices to facilitate 
and accelerate intergenerational knowledge sharing. 
Digital curation involves the active management and 
preservation of digital resources over the life cycle of 
a project, product, or service, and over time in support 
of current and further generations. Digital curation is 
stewardship that provides for the reproducibility and 
reuse of authentic digital data and other digital assets 
[34]. “Knowledge management (KM) is the process 
of identifying, organizing, storing and disseminating 
information within an organization”, according to IBM 
[35]. Knowledge management complements digital 
curation by establishing pl

and disseminating 
information within an organization”, according to IBM 
[35]. Knowledge management complements digital 
curation by establishing platforms and processes to 
best facilitate the accurate and efficient retrieval 
and dissemination of critical information. Focusing 
organizational resources towards digital curation and 
knowledge management can provide for the creation 
of a knowledge-sharing ecosystem [36], which can best 
supplement the growing tech-debt and experience-debt 
of today’s workforce. By embracing these strategies, 
organizations can best leverage the fresh perspectives 
and technological prowess of the younger generation, 
while retaining the invaluable, experience-earned 
insights of their seasoned professionals.
Technical Debt and Intellectual Debt
Over time, projects inevitably accrue technical debt 
(a.k.a., tech debt). “Technical debt arises when systems 
are tweaked hastily, catering to an immediate need 
to save money or implement a new feature, wh

.a., tech debt). “Technical debt arises when systems 
are tweaked hastily, catering to an immediate need 
to save money or implement a new feature, while 
increasing long-term complexity. [...] When something 
stops working, this technical debt often needs to 
be paid down as an aggravating lump sum — likely 
by tearing the components out and rewiring them 
in a more coherent manner” [37]. While not unique to 
digital systems, the ease with which digital assets 
(software, data, configurations) can be changed creates 
susceptibility to accrue tech debt; in fact, that ability to 
quick-fix is rationally taken as a feature. Technical debt 
also occurs during a long-term program where originally 
baselined software is obsolete and not supported by the 
originating tool supplier requiring significant expense to 
upgrade and/or migrate the data and capabilities to new 
IT systems including CAD/PLM/MES. 
Tech debt is not necessarily problematic in itself, so 
long as it is tracked and then a

digital workforce must own stewardship of the tech debt 
balance sheet: accrual, risk assessment, remediation 
plans, prioritization, and pay-down follow through.

Competing Priorities and Employee 
Retention
The traditional engineering and manufacturing industries 
have shown an unwillingness or inability to compete 
financially with more lucrative opportunities or compare 
baseline salary structures against competitors in 
other sectors. More specifically, one of the aerospace 
and defense (A&D) challenges for digital workforce 
development includes the compensation differential 
between A&D companies that hold and certify physical 
assets and facilities, and tech companies that do 
not maintain the same assets. The resulting higher 
margins in tech companies enable them to provide 
more benefits, most notably in compensation, over 
traditional A&D firms. Furthermore, as competence in 
digital and emer

nies enable them to provide 
more benefits, most notably in compensation, over 
traditional A&D firms. Furthermore, as competence in 
digital and emerging technologies are increasingly built 
into the skill set of the traditional engineer, that skill 
set becomes applicable to more and more industries 
outside of traditional engineering and manufacturing. 
Many sought-after digital engineering disciplines have 
crossovers with other industries that can be significantly 
more lucrative for engineers, such as tech, finance, and 
elements of the entertainment sector. Therefore, the 
impact on the workforce navigating career options 
forces a person to choose between the impact and 
value being delivered by A&D or being motivated by 
financial incentives. Problems with retaining high value 
employees is a current concern and will be exacerbated 
as digital engineering becomes more prevalent, making 
it difficult for companies to build a digital culture or 
maintain digital experts and know

Workforce Diversity 
The digital engineering workforce is not a diverse 
landscape. In 2021, the Interagency Working Group on 
Inclusion in STEM (IWGIS) published demographics 
on the federal STEM workforce [39]; the federal STEM 
workforce is 16% of the total federal workforce; women 
in the federal STEM workforce represent 29% of that 
population, and underrepresented racial and ethnic 
groups in the federal STEM workforce are 10% of 
the population. Barriers identified by IWGIS include 
policies, climate, compensation differential, stereotypes, 
and biases, among others. In aerospace, AIA data [40] 
indicates that women in aerospace is around 24% and 
underrepresented communities, Black and Hispanic/
Latino, represent just 6 and 8%, respectively. As 
the United States population is a diverse society, 
engineering and the aerospa

Black and Hispanic/
Latino, represent just 6 and 8%, respectively. As 
the United States population is a diverse society, 
engineering and the aerospace industry needs to 
continue to attract, recruit, and retain a diverse 
workforce to help manage growing industry needs.
Psychological Safety
Recent research has discussed psychological safety 
within a team as the single largest predictor of both 
productivity and overall happiness even across teams in 
different sectors [41]. Psychological safety refers to the 
collective belief within a team that individuals can take 
risks, voice concerns, and admit mistakes, without fear 
of adverse repercussions [42]. This group phenomenon 
leads to more engaged team members, more diverse 
perspectives, and fosters a culture of continuous 
improvement. Using modern tools like blameless 
postmortems [43] when problems are discovered can 
ensure team members feel safe to share their mistakes 
and that everyone learns from them.

Alignment Across Academia, Industry, and 
Government
The formal, classic modes of education alone are 
insufficient to meet employers’ demand for a digital 
workforce [20, 44]. As a result, addressing the pressing 
needs and dynamic concerns for the development of a 
digital workforce will require concerted efforts across 
a variety of stakeholders beyond traditional academic 
institutions [20]. In addition, a holistic approach to 
workforce development is needed to offset the cost and 
risk of investing in digital technologies such as high-
performance computing, quantum technologies, cloud 
solutions, software licenses, etc. 
The following section discusses the alignment that 
academia, industry, government, and other stakeholders 
should seek to accelerate the pace of digital workforce 
development.

Emerging/Maturing Capabilities 
As organizations develop a digital engineering workforce 
it will be critical to effectively assess, plan, integrate 
and manage emerging and maturing technologies. 
These technologies provide an excellent opportunity to 
enable and build a digital workforce but will need to be 
incorporated in a way that will enhance organizational 
capabilities rather than introduce additional burdens. 
Organizations will want to integrate capabilities into 
existing disciplines and functional areas so digital is not 
treated as a ‘separate silo of activity’ but fundamentally 
integrates into ‘the way we work’ going forward.

Once assessment of needs, skill gaps, and technologies 
has been completed, organizations will need to 
begin the planning phase that includes upskilling the 
workforce and onboarding desired technologies and tools. 
Planning for Technology Adoption
Organizations will want to define strategies for upskilling 
the workforce in preparation of adopting emerging and 
maturing technologies. Strategies include:
› Foster a culture of continuous learning and adaptation 
by encouraging employees to embrace new 
technologies and upskill themselves. 
› Champion model and date-driven processes and 
workflows to enable the necessary cultural and 
organizational change needed to adopt emerging 
technologies. 
› Develop training programs that cover both technical 
skills (using the new technologies) and soft skills 
(collaboration, critical thinking, adapt

› Develop training programs that cover both technical 
skills (using the new technologies) and soft skills 
(collaboration, critical thinking, adaptability).
› Combine traditional training methods with online 
courses, workshops, webinars, and interactive 
platforms to cater to different learning styles.
› Provide hands-on experience with the technologies 
through projects, simulations, and real-world 
applications. Learning by doing can accelerate skill 
acquisition.
Integrating and Managing Technology 
With effective plans, organizations will be well-
positioned to integrate emerging and maturing 
technologies, tools, and techniques. Best practices to 
integrate emerging technologies include but are not 
limited to the following activities. 
› Start with small-scale pilot projects to test the 
integration of emerging technologies into your 
workflows. Gather feedback and iterate before 
scaling up. Small-scale pilot projects should be 
timeboxed (i.e., 3-6 months) to demonstrate va

your 
workflows. Gather feedback and iterate before 
scaling up. Small-scale pilot projects should be 
timeboxed (i.e., 3-6 months) to demonstrate value 
before additional investment is provided. As the value 
proposition is more clearly understood, organizations 
can continue to scale up the capability in a controlled 
way with investment reviews at specific milestones 
(i.e., 12 months). An incremental approach will 
reduce the risk of organizations investing heavily 
in technologies that ultimately do not provide the 
needed capabilities at scale.

Measuring Return on Investment (ROI)
There are many challenges with identifying the 
ROI of emerging technologies and broader digital 
transformation efforts. Many times, there is a perception 
of sunk or opportunity costs that do not justify the 
investment in these technologies. Organizations may 
provide little seed investment due to the risks and 
u

opportunity costs that do not justify the 
investment in these technologies. Organizations may 
provide little seed investment due to the risks and 
uncertainty. However, there is high value realized to 
the organization through workforce development 
and cultural change. One method that can help an 
organization measure the value proposition is to identify 
objectives and key results (OKR). By setting short-term 
and measurable OKR, the organization will incrementally 
identify the value metrics to enable optimal investment 
and technology decision making.
Successfully integrating emerging technologies into the 
digital workforce is not just about the technology itself; 
it is about fostering a culture of learning, adaptation, 
and collaboration. By addressing both the technical 
and human aspects, one can create a workforce that is 
well-equipped to leverage these technologies for digital 
engineering success.

The digital engineering sector, in both private and public 
domains, is proactively addressing the demand for a 
skilled workforce. The Future of Jobs Report 2023 by the 
World Economic Forum (WEF) [48] predicts that “60% of 
employees will need reskilling by 2027 (a 10% increase 
over the 2020 report), with 44% of current worker’s core 
skills expected to be disrupted in the next 5 years.” To 
effectively tackle this challenge, it is crucial to establish a 
clear definition of ‘competency.’
Competency, in this context, refers to collections 
of skills, knowledge, attitudes, and abilities enabling 
individuals to perform job roles [49]. Another perspective 
defines competencies as behaviors indicative of success 
in a discipline, allowing self

g 
individuals to perform job roles [49]. Another perspective 
defines competencies as behaviors indicative of success 
in a discipline, allowing self-assessment and targeted 
improvement through training and education [50].
To address this, a competency model is developed 
by identifying and organizing relevant behaviors into 
a traceable format. This model can be enhanced by 
mapping behavior-enabling technical and soft skills.
Existing Competency Models 
A standardized framework for defining digital skills 
is essential to assess digital competencies across 
industries. However, as of this white paper’s writing, 
there is no singular standardized framework that has 
been generally accepted by the aerospace industry. 
Instead, various relevant models have been meticulously 
developed and made publicly available, with numerous 
others actively undergoing development. This section 
aims to examine the evolving landscape of digital 
engineering competency models, shedding light on 
curr

aims to examine the evolving landscape of digital 
engineering competency models, shedding light on 
current frameworks and acknowledging ongoing efforts 
to enhance this critical aspect of the industry.

is influenced by implicit and explicit emphasis and 
prioritization. Examples include:

management.

Future Digital Engineering Competency 
Model Adoption 
The SERC Digital Engineering Competency Framework 
stands out as one of the more mature digital engineering- 
focused competency frameworks accessible to the 
public. Future initiatives are anticipated to build upon 
this established framework, using it as a foundational 
baseline for further expansion. This expansion will 
specifically target the addressing of identified gaps 
stemming from bias assessments, critical competencies 
within the evolving digital engineering domain (Section 2), 
and emerging/maturing capabilities (Section 4).
Proposed Digital Ecosystem Roles and 
Responsibilities Taxonomy 
This paper leverages the DAU published definition 
for digital engineering ecosystem, wh

posed Digital Ecosystem Roles and 
Responsibilities Taxonomy 
This paper leverages the DAU published definition 
for digital engineering ecosystem, which is “The 
interconnected infrastructure, environment, and 
methodology (process, methods, and tools) used 
to store, access, analyze, and visualize evolving 
systems’ data and models to address the needs of the 
stakeholders.” Supported by this definition, a simplified 
four-level digital ecosystem taxonomy is presented 
to describe a proposed aggregation scheme of 
technologies and processes spanning from the individual 
tool level up to the enterprise digital ecosystem. The 
goal is to improve traceability between workforce 
skills and behaviors outlined in the evolving Digital 
Engineering Competency Framework and the practical 
implementation requirements identified by organizations.

and organizations should be a thorough understanding 
of all tools and processes, encompa

of all tools and processes, encompassing both traditional

foundation for dynamically integrating all tools and processes 
within an interoperable and digitally connected toolchain.

utilization of tools and/or processes originally designed 
for isolated completion of tasks managed sequentially. 
For instance, in a traditional context, designing a system 
might involve using standalone design artifacts (e.g., 
Excel, PowerPoint, Word) to capture relevant information

Level 1: Enabling Technology (ET) 
Enabling Technology (level 1) signifies the intentional 
use of a tool and/or process designed for dynamic 
collaboration in managing tasks asynchronously. This 
level represents the basic implementation, allowing for 
the dynamic integration of a single interoperable and 
digitally connected toolchain.
For instance, in an enabling technology scenario, 
designing a system might involve using domain 
models with variables and attributes (e.g., MagicDraw) 
to capture relevant information related to design, 
behavior, r

em might involve using domain 
models with variables and attributes (e.g., MagicDraw) 
to capture relevant information related to design, 
behavior, requirements, etc. This allows information to 
be dynamically updated across the model, illustrating a 
move beyond traditional siloed approaches toward more 
collaborative and dynamic task management.
Level 2: Enabling Capability (EC) 
Enabling Capability (level 2) involves the thematic grouping 
of multiple enabling technologies intended for accomplishing 
similar tasks. Positioned as the intermediate level of 
implementation, it facilitates the dynamic integration of a 
series of interoperable and digitally connected toolchains.
For example, an enabling capability scenario could 
involve systems modeling to capture traditionally paper-
based products and processes in a model-based and/or 
digital capacity. This represents a step beyond individual 
technologies, grouping them thematically to enhance 
collaboration and connectivity across

digital capacity. This represents a step beyond individual 
technologies, grouping them thematically to enhance 
collaboration and connectivity across various tools and 
processes within an organization or project.
Level 3: Digital Ecosystem (DEc) 
A digital ecosystem constitutes the aggregation of 
all enabling capabilities within the environment of an 
enterprise and/or project life cycle. Positioned as the 
advanced level of implementation, it involves multiple 
sets of enabling capabilities that align with and span 
organizational business practices.
For instance, envision designing a vehicle by integrating 
multiple enabling capabilities like systems modeling, 
computer-aided design (CAD), and product Life 
cycle management (PLM) using a digital thread (itself 
an enabling capability) hosted on the cloud (also 
an enabling capability). An illustrative example of 
this thread of enabling technologies could involve 
connecting tools like MagicDraw, Creo, and Windchill 
through a pla

). An illustrative example of 
this thread of enabling technologies could involve 
connecting tools like MagicDraw, Creo, and Windchill 
through a platform like Syndeia, hosted on a cloud 
service such as Amazon Web Services. This scenario 
showcases a sophisticated integration of capabilities 
across the entire digital ecosystem, enhancing 
collaboration and connectivity in a comprehensive manner.

variable associations through a modified RACI Matrix, 
explained below: 
› R (Responsible): The individual(s) or team(s) responsible 
for completing the task or deliverable. They are the 
“doers” who carry out the work and ensure it is completed.
› A (Accountable): The person who has ultimate ownership 
of the task or deliverable. They ensure that the task is 
done correctly and on time. There is

A (Accountable): The person who has ultimate ownership 
of the task or deliverable. They ensure that the task is 
done correctly and on time. There is typically only one

person accountable for each task to avoid confusion.
› C (Consulted): These are the people who need to be 
consulted or provide input before a task is completed. 
They are subject matter experts or stakeholders 
whose feedback is necessary for decision-making or 
work progression.
› I (Informed): Individuals or groups who need to be 
kept informed of the progress or outcome of the task. 
They do not have to provide input or make decisions 
but need to be aware of developments. Note that 
this role CAN provide actionable inputs, but does not 
HAVE TO for progress to be made. 
› N/A (Not Applicable)
