2.2 MBSE adoption and benefits survey
The MBSE Maturity Benchmark Survey was developed through the
combined efforts of the International Council on Systems Engineer-
ing (INCOSE), the National Defense Industrial Association (NDIA), and
the Systems Engineering Research Center (SERC).21 The intent of con-
ducting this survey was to establish a current profile of MBSE use
and expectations in the industry. Two critical aspects of the survey
include: assessing the observed and expected value of MBSE, and col-
lecting r

se
and expectations in the industry. Two critical aspects of the survey
include: assessing the observed and expected value of MBSE, and col-
lecting reports of enablers and barriers to MBSE adoption. These were
both accomplished through the analysis of over 100 textual responses
regarding benefits, adoption enablers, and barriers to adoption.
The responses to the benefit-related questions were coded using
the 48 benefits that were found in the previously mentioned literature
review. The results of the survey aligned very well with those found
from the literature review, further validating those results.
The responses to the adoption-related questions were coded induc-
tively. The factors found were either related to the adoption of
MBSE, or the benefits of MBSE. Furthermore, a factor could be either
an enabler, an obstacle, or both. For example, one of the factors
was customer/stakeholder buy-in/engagement. This was presented in
the responses as an obstacle if it was lacking, and an en

xample, one of the factors
was customer/stakeholder buy-in/engagement. This was presented in
the responses as an obstacle if it was lacking, and an enabler if it
was present. Thirty-seven factors were found to be enablers and/or
obstacles to adoption. The top enablers and obstacles are shown in

2.3 DE metrics study
DE is a subset of the larger aspects of enterprise digital transformation.
Gartner reported four common characteristics for good enterprise-
level digital transformation metrics: adoption, usability, productivity,
and new value.27 The metrics categories in parentheses were derived
as part of this work and are discussed below.
1. Measure people adoption, and enterprise process adoption (adop-
tion)
2. Analyze breadth of usability, and issues with usability (user experi-
ence)
3. Measure productivity indicators (velocity/agility)
4. Generate new value to the enterprise (quality and knowledge
transfer)

agility)
4. Generate new value to the enterprise (quality and knowledge

Digital transformation is a change process heavily rooted in work-
force and culture, as noted by Goal 5 of the DoD DE strategy. The
change process needs to assess both adoption of the methods and
tools into the workforce in terms of number of users, resources, and
so forth, and also the drivers of adoption that are linked to user experi-
ence with the methods and tools. To understand productivity indicators
and areas of new value, the previous SERC study, Enterprise System-of-
Systems Model for Digital Thread Enabled Acquisition, was used as the
base digital enterprise transformation model.28 This study linked digi-
tal enterprise transformation to outcomes related to improved quality,
improved velocity/agility, and better knowledge transfer. Knowledge
transfer is a unique value of DE/MBSE that can be distinguished from
other digital enterprise transformation metrics, as a

wledge transfer. Knowledge
transfer is a unique value of DE/MBSE that can be distinguished from
other digital enterprise transformation metrics, as a primary goal of
MBSE and the ASOT is communication, sharing, and management of
data, information, and knowledge.
From this background research, a general categorization was cre-
ated of DE/MBSE organizational change metrics linked toquality,
velocity/agility, user experience, knowledge transfer,and adoption.
These categories are shown in Figure2. The benefits found in the
previous literature review study were then sorted into these five cat-
egories. Table2 includes a sample of this categorization, with a few
adoption factors included under theadoption category. For a full list
of categorized benefits, see Table4.
3 CAUSAL MAP DEVELOPMENT
One of the key challenges of designing a performance measurement
system (PMS) is selecting which measures to track.29 Organizations
should try to align metrics with strategies or goals that they have. Th

measurement
system (PMS) is selecting which measures to track.29 Organizations
should try to align metrics with strategies or goals that they have. This
means selecting measures that are the true drivers of desirable out-
comes (i.e., lower cost, higher quality, etc.).30 For example, if a goal
of an organization is to have happy customers, customer satisfaction
would be an effective metric to track that goal. Not finding these funda-
mental drivers of performance can lead to having too many measures,
which makes it difficult to know which measures are valuable or just
noise.31

3.1 Methodology
There are two main components of the causal map that need to be
determined: the nodes and the causal links between them. Causal maps
are used in a variety of different contexts and as such have different
methods used to create them.37 The methodology we have used to
determine these two components is described below:
1. Select nodes
2. Develop causal links

had at least four links moving into the node (in-degree) or leaving the
node (out-degree). Nodes that have a high out-degree have a large
influence on nodes further down the causal chain. Nodes that have a
high in-degree have a large number of nodes contributing to their exis-
tence. Almost all of the key nodes already identified also fall in this
selection of nodes.
Further quantitative analysis was conducted on the entire causal
model. Eigenvector centrality and PageRank are two different meth-
ods of measuring the influence or importance of a node on the map.
The top-ranked nodes from each of these methods are shown in Table8.
These measures take into account a node’s location in the causal chain
as well as the number of inputs/outputs. The two methods place dif-
ferent weights on these factors so it is worth examining both, although
there is notable overlap.

4 CASE STUDY VALIDATION
The initial validation efforts of the causal model (discussed in Sec-
tion 3) were a valuable way to capture the perspectives of SMEs
who have worked in this field. In order to improve the quality of the
validation effort, however, it is important to also use more concrete
examples/data. The difficulty with this, as mentioned previously, is that
there is very little data available. So, the data-based validation for this
model is based on the analysis of one program’s experience applying
MBSE.
The Submarine Warfare Federated Tactical Systems (SWFTS) pro-
gram has been transitioning from a document-centric SE process
to a model-based one over the past decade. A report from 2021
has reported on this effort and quantified a positive ROI from this
transition.26 SWFTS is a common set of mission hardware and software
that has been fielded across multiple submarine classes and

sitive ROI from this
transition.26 SWFTS is a common set of mission hardware and software
that has been fielded across multiple submarine classes and multiple
baselines since 1998. To date, the program reported 18 total baseline
releases to 104 total submarines. The program moved to a common
requirements model in 2009 with baseline 10 and to a full MBSE model
in 2011 with baseline 12. The report discusses the baseline change
process and the realized quantitative benefits of the full MBSE pro-
cess over the equivalent requirements-only process. Since moving to
the MBSE process, the paper reported a 37% decrease in fielded prod-
uct trouble reports, a 9% decrease in overall problem reports, an 18%
increase in “saves” or problems discovered in earlier phases, and an

The SWFTS case study was selected because the authors effec-
tively reported on the experience of adopting MBSE, and were able to
capture quantitative measures showing the value of MBSE. The vali-
dation analysis was conducted by analyzing the paper, which reported
on this case study. Causal relationships that were explicitly and implic-
itly stated were recorded and compared to the existing causal model.
Since this data was interpreted from the author’s presentation, there is
a risk that the relationships gleaned were not intentionally presented
by the authors. We consider this threat to validity negligible for three
reasons. First, the authors of the SWFTS case study paper present
many of their findin

thors. We consider this threat to validity negligible for three
reasons. First, the authors of the SWFTS case study paper present
many of their findings with quantifiable evidence, which negates the
need for interpretation. Second, the causal model is based on percep-
tions/beliefs and is not (at this point) intended to exactly represent
reality. Finally, this case study is not intended to serve as a complete
validation of the model. A full validation will include multiple sources
that can corroborate each other.
Examining the findings from the case study in the context of the
causal model can provide a deeper understanding of those observa-
tions. For example, a causal relationship described in the paper was:
workforce knowledge/skills improving lead to a lower average cost of
processing a baseline change request. This point is able to fit within
the existing causal model, but is not a direct connection. The trace from
cost to workforce knowledge/skills is shown in Figure9.

the existing causal model, but is not a direct connection. The trace from
cost to workforce knowledge/skills is shown in Figure9.
These causal links elucidate key factors that influence the observed
relationship. For instance, a program that is looking to implement
MBSE should not expect workforce knowledge/skills to reduce cost if
their people are not willing to use the tools. This factor may not have
been a consideration otherwise.

5 DISCUSSIONS
5.1 Causal map analysis
This causal analysis helps us to infer several outcomes with respect
to metrics design. First, there are three core factors for increased
DE/MBSE stakeholder involvement that are central to adoption:
DE/MBSE tools, DE/MBSE methods and processes, and people willing
to use DE/MBSE tools. Many of the other benefits of a DE/MBSE trans-
formation will be lost if artifacts have to be produced and activities
have to be conducted outside of the digital environment and related
models. Additionally, enterprise and program terminologies/ontologies
and associated digital libraries are essential to creating and adopting

5.2 Validating case study contributions
The authors of the SWFTS case study make several conclusions about
MBSE based on the metrics they took/calculated.26 First, MBSE was
more efficient than the legacy process, specifically with regard to the
effort needed to modify and configuration-manage interface require-
ments. Second, interface defects were discovered earlier, when it is
typically less expensive to fix. Third, MBSE produced a higher quality
product, in terms of total number of defects found. Finally, the authors
determined that a positive ROI was achieved from the investment to
use MBSE. The authors also note additiona

er of defects found. Finally, the authors
determined that a positive ROI was achieved from the investment to
use MBSE. The authors also note additional qualitative and observed
benefits throughout.
When examining the validated links, it is apparent that the major-
ity of the validation includes more easily quantifiable benefits such as
reduce errors/defects, reduce rework, reduce time, and reduce cost.
This program appeared to have used metrics that were already being
captured, such as labor hours, number of changed interface require-
ments (effort), interface defects found over time, and average cost per
baseline change request.
One of the requirements in their tool is that the model needs to be
internally consistent. Because the relationships between elements are
better captured in models, more defects were discovered in the legacy
SE products (which were used to build the model). This is one example
of howImproved traceabilitycan lead toReduced errors(defects).
Another one of the me

roducts (which were used to build the model). This is one example
of howImproved traceabilitycan lead toReduced errors(defects).
Another one of the metrics calculated in this study was efficiency.
The program compared the number of labor hours to how many inter-
face requirements were updated. They found in the legacy process,
the number of SE hours per requirement was 12.1, which reduced to
9.9 h/requirement using MBSE. Using the causal model, you can trace
the origins that contribute to this change in efficiency (see Figure11).
The key contributors toeffort and time are: Reduce SE burden, Reduce
rework,a n dEasy to make changes. This is essentially caused by two main
factors. First is a system that is easier to manage and make changes.
Second is the reduction of errors and defects that need to be addressed
and fixed.
Another metric that was tracked was when defects were discovered.
The program found that defects were found earlier in testing and inte-
gration phases using MBSE. Speci

The SWFTS case study sheds light on the importance ofReduce
errors/defects to the quantitative proof of value they found. A metric
such as defects is one that most programs are already using. Utilizing
defects as a metric means that a program does not have to go through
an additional effort to develop new measurement practices. Further-
more, it means that there will be historical data that can be used for
comparison. A difficulty in trying to measure the value of MBSE is hav-
ing a baseline to compare it to. If new metrics are introduced, this
could be a challenge. Programs would either have to calculate or esti-
mate the historical values of the metrics. Otherwise, there is no way
to show if the results with MBSE are an improvement or not. As the
authors of this paper point out, this case study is only a single point of
measurement. These results need to be supported by

provement or not. As the
authors of this paper point out, this case study is only a single point of
measurement. These results need to be supported by other programs
that are tracking the same type of metrics. Prioritizing existing met-
rics could be a beneficial way to more quickly get support for the value
of MBSE.
6 METRIC CANDIDATE RECOMMENDATIONS
Based on the analyses described in this paper, we can recommend a
set of metrics that should be the focus of initial measurement efforts.
Table 10 shows the measures that we have determined to be impor-
tant to show the value of DE/MBSE. The metric set covers all five DE
transformation success areas.
An initial effort to develop specific metrics for the recommended set
was conducted using the Goal–Question–Metric (GQM) approach.40
The GQM approach starts with a goal that identifies a desirable out-
come that will be tracked using measurement. Each goal is broken down
into questions that state different issues related to that goal. Finally

le out-
come that will be tracked using measurement. Each goal is broken down
into questions that state different issues related to that goal. Finally,
potential metrics are identified that could be used to answer those
questions. This approach provides an additional means to organize the
potential measures/metrics discussed in this study. The recommended
metrics from Table10 served as the goals. The information needs and
questions developed in the DE Metric Working Group were sorted
based on which goal they would help address. Additionally, the poten-
tial metrics that were brainstormed were also sorted based on which
questions they would help answer. Questions and metrics could be
used in multiple goals, as per the GQM approach.
Table 11 shows an example of the GQM approach for developing
metrics. A summary of all the GQM tables is depicted in Table12.
The metric candidates in the adoption category were not developed
into GQM tables. Both of these metrics are essentially measuring if

cted in Table12.
The metric candidates in the adoption category were not developed
into GQM tables. Both of these metrics are essentially measuring if
DE/MBSE tools, methods, processes, and so forth are actually being
used by employees. Since these aspects are unique to each program,
metrics will need to be tailored to the different programs.
7 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
This and prior research indicate that the SE community is gaining a
much greater understanding of the opportunity to quantify DE/MBSE
measures, but actual implementation, lessons learned, and experi-
ence remain in the early stages of practice. The DE/MBSE community
continues to search for a starting point for measures. The extensive col-
lection of literature and survey data produced a broad framework for
DE/MBSE metrics across key digital transformation attributes of qual-
ity, velocity/agility, user experience, adoption, and knowledge transfer.
The value of this framework is a comprehensive list of potential metric

ual-
ity, velocity/agility, user experience, adoption, and knowledge transfer.
The value of this framework is a comprehensive list of potential metrics
spanning the domain of individual processes up to full enterprise trans-
formation. The causal analysis created a more detailed understanding
of the most central measures related to DE/MBSE, while still retain-
ing the understanding of enterprise and detailed process relationships.
This research to categorize MBSE benefits and the resultant causal
model, as well as the initial draft DE measurement framework, will pro-
vide a baseline for programs to begin focused efforts on measurement
and quantification of benefits. The digital transformation and shift from
document-based to model-based artifacts offer a great opportunity to
quantify and expand the application of SE to complex projects.
As the DE/MBSE field grows in maturity, the measurement capabil-
ities will ideally also increase in maturity. This will allow for continued
validation

s the DE/MBSE field grows in maturity, the measurement capabil-
ities will ideally also increase in maturity. This will allow for continued
validation and refinement of the causal model, and ultimately the anal-
ysis of the individual relationships between the factors identified for
the causal model and program success. Eric Honour’s work on SE
Return on Investment23 shows that statistically significant relation-
ships between SE activities and program success can be determined
with the right measurements and data. Once this analysis can be done
for DE/MBSE, the value of DE/MBSE will be able to be quantified
systematically.

Kaitlin Henderson has a PhD in Indus-
trial and Systems Engineering with a con-
centration in Management Systems from
Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, Virginia. She
also earned her Bachelor’s and Master’s
degrees in Industrial and Systems Engi-
neering at Virginia Tech. Kaitlin has con-
tributed to the fields of Model-Based Sys-
tems Engineering (MBSE) and Digital Engineering (DE) with her
works on MBSE adoption, MBSE domain maturity, and MBSE/DE
performance measurement. Kaitlin won the Best Presentation
Award at the SERC Doctoral Student Forum in 2020 and has
been recognized for her 2021 publication inSystems Engineering.
Her research interests include organizational design, technology
adoption, and performance measurement.

6.6 Cyber oriented digital engineering
Summary: A 2024 paper on cyber-focused digital engineering. Link: Wiley Link
626

Received: 15 December 2021 Revised: 5 May 2023 Accepted: 23 June 2023
DOI: 10.1002/sys.21710
REGULAR ARTICLE
Cyber oriented digital engineering
Joseph Mitola III Mark Prys
ENSCO, Cocoa Beach, Florida, USA
Correspondence
Joseph Mitola, ENSCO, Cocoa Beach, FL, USA.
Email: mitola.joe@ensco.com
Abstract
The purpose of cyber oriented digital engineering (CODE) is to provide a repeatable
systems-engineering process for systems to resist Stuxnet-class advanced persistent
threat (APT) cyberattacks. CODE integrates cyber thinking with systems thinking.
CODE accomplishes this by extending the US Department of Defense (DoD) digital
engineering (DE) framework with functional mission analysis for cyber (FMA-C), hybrid
cloud architecture, zero trust (ZT) principles, threat analysis, and hardware cyber hard-
ening (HCH). The lack of success of red tea

(FMA-C), hybrid
cloud architecture, zero trust (ZT) principles, threat analysis, and hardware cyber hard-
ening (HCH). The lack of success of red team attacks conducted in our laboratory
against an exemplar system demonstrates how following the CODE systems engineer-
ing process actually does “bake cybersecurity into the system”, making the resulting
systems architecture and implementations more resilient. In a recent Pilot Project,
CODE enhanced the systems requirements document of the top left side of the sys-
tems engineering Vee. CODE Pilot requirements embodied ZT principles, including
machine to machine (M2M) credential exchanges and internal self-checking. We antic-
ipate working with International Council on Systems Engineering (INCOSE), the object
management group (OMG,) and others towards standardizing CODE’s cyber-systems
engineering processes for broader use of the global systems engineering community.

This paper shows how CODE systems engineering processes result
in cybersecurity that is “baked into” today’s increasingly software-
defined systems. It also offers the CODE Guidebook for collab-
oration, ultimately towards INCOSE-class standardization. Systems
engineering includes cybersecurity.1 The INCOSE Systems Engineer-
ing Handbook1 refers to Stuxnet,2 noting that “The lesson of this
case study is that systems engineers need to understand the threats
towards their system(s), be cognizant that threats can and will occur,
and be proactive in protecting their system(s).” This paper there-
fore contributes a technical overview of the cyber oriented digital

2 BACKGROUND
In an illustrative US Department of Defense (DoD) installation, there
are over 10,000 electronic line replacement units (LRUs) still in use that
either are at end of life (EOL) or at end of service and supp

lation, there
are over 10,000 electronic line replacement units (LRUs) still in use that
either are at end of life (EOL) or at end of service and supportability
(EOS). Extrapolate that to DoD writ large for millions of deprecated
components, potentially vulnerable to cyberattacks, leading to denial
of service, data exfiltration, or mission compromise. Critical civilian
infrastructure such as water treatment and electric power systems
also include millions of LRUs at end of life. The astronomical num-
ber of obsolescent parts in use is key to understanding the complex
technological challenges facing today’s systems engineers. Legacy
technology can be unsupportable, creating system vulnerabilities that
can be exploited by adversaries and criminals. Digitizing6 provides
a systems-engineering environment within which CODE structures
cyber security thinking. CODE is more than an opportunity: it’s an
imperative because of the rapid pace at which criminals are exploit-
ing globally networked

urity thinking. CODE is more than an opportunity: it’s an
imperative because of the rapid pace at which criminals are exploit-
ing globally networked computing (aka cyberspace) for cyberphysical
effects such as the Colonial Pipeline disaster.7 At the same time, cyber
adversaries are working to negate US capabilities to defend ourselves
and our allies.
3 PROBLEM STATEMENT
Much of the legacy computing hardware, that is, central process-
ing units (CPUs), operating systems (OS), networks, and application
software in use in mission critical systems also can no longer be
supported. Legacy systems and infrastructure (by definition) were
based on logic circuits, interfaces, switches, and computers that can
no longer be purchased from the original equipment manufacturer
(OEM). Thus, governments and commercial companies expend exor-
bitant amounts of operations and maintenance (O&M) resources to
migrate legacy systems to new computing devices, often at significantly
increased cyber risk, suppor

of operations and maintenance (O&M) resources to
migrate legacy systems to new computing devices, often at significantly
increased cyber risk, support costs, and mission risk. The problem is
to establish systems engineering processes that overcome these chal-
lenges by integrating cyber thinking into systems thinking. This is the
fundamental problem that CODE seeks to address.
4 CODE BACKGROUND
This section provides highlights of technical areas that CODE inte-
grates. The CODE Guidebook6 brings the next level of detail of these
aspects of systems-level cyber thinking together in a single docu-
ment. This brief treatment introduces these cyber deep dives to the
degree necessary to understand the CODE technical overview that
follows.
4.1 Functional mission analysis for cyber (FMA-C)
CODE incorporates systems theoretic process analysis (STPA). 8
Systems-theoretic accident model and processes (STAMP) is a hazard
analysis technique developed by Nancy G. Leveson and John P. Thomas
of MIT8;

PA). 8
Systems-theoretic accident model and processes (STAMP) is a hazard
analysis technique developed by Nancy G. Leveson and John P. Thomas
of MIT8; STPA (STAMP-based process analysis) leverages the concepts
of post-facto STAMP to reduce the a-priori potential for hazards in
complex systems. A branch of STPA called FMA-C9 is taught by the
Air Force Cyber College.10 FMA-C combines STPA and the DoD Joint
Publication 5-0 concepts of Operational Design and Mission Analysis
to bridge the gaps among systems engineering, cybersecurity, and mis-
sion design for network-centric (aka cyberspace) operations. FMA-C
identifies control laws that are implicit in a mission statement, in a spec-
ification, or in a system that has been a part of a catastrophic failure
(loss of life). CODE adapts FMA-C by incorporating ZT, clouds, HCH
and Stuxnet-class threats via Murphy’s Chaos Monkey into the FMA-C
workflow of Figure1.
FMA-C processes of Figure1 structure critical thinking for systems
analysis by rig

reats via Murphy’s Chaos Monkey into the FMA-C
workflow of Figure1.
FMA-C processes of Figure1 structure critical thinking for systems
analysis by rigorous inquiry into an existing (or envisioned) system’s
function to specify mission assurance requirements. FMA-C extracts
the implicit (hardware, software, and human) persona, control laws
and entities controlled into a three-tier control model. CODE extends
FMA-C analysis of hazardous control actions (HCA) to impart ZT and
HCH constraints to defeat Stuxnet-class attacks. The resulting cyber-
oriented CODE constraint sets limit degrees of freedom in systems
architecture and design.
4.2 Cyber best practices
The systems engineering Vee includes cybersecurity.1 Specifically, the
INCOSE Systems Engineering Handbook incorporates the Stuxnet use
case, noting that “The lesson of this case study is that systems engi-
neers need to understand the threats towards their system(s), be
cognizant that threats can and will occur, and be proactive in pr

that systems engi-
neers need to understand the threats towards their system(s), be
cognizant that threats can and will occur, and be proactive in pro-
tecting their system(s). Robust and dynamic systems security needs
full engagement of SE.” The INCOSE Handbook also identifies infor-
mation assurance and anti-tamper provisions as aspects of security,
page 60 appropriately characterizing these aspects of system security
as non-functional in Section 4.3.2.4, page 6. In Section 5.6 Informa-
tion Management Process, pages 128–130 and Section 10.11, System
Security Engineering, pages 234–237, the Handbook invokes many
well-known information security mandates and summarizes best prac-
tices. Integrating cyber best practices into systems engineering in this
way ensures that systems engineers endorse what is known as “basic
cyber hygiene”. Such cyber best practices, however, do not address the
larger systems engineering issues at the intersection of cyber security
and systems engineering.

4.3 Cyber risk management framework controls
For example, the INCOSE Handbook does not recognize systems engi-
neering within a RMF. The Handbook refers to the NIST national
vulnerabilities database, op cit., NIST, page 45, but does not consider
the RMF of NIST SP 800-53.3 There are about 2000 cyber controls
in RMF cyber security processes. In best commercial practice, RMF
cyber subject matter experts (SMEs) evaluate each control against the
general requirements of system security for Confidentiality, Integrity,
and Availability (the “CIA” of the cyber domain). The general CIA
requirements may lack systems context.
CODE complements the Handbook by showing how the systems
engineer can consider RMF controls in systems engineering processes.
Risks applicable to different HCA are surfaced systematically in the
CODE workflow (an adaptation of Figure1). For example, invoking
a specific control action (CA) too early or too late in the oper

systematically in the
CODE workflow (an adaptation of Figure1). For example, invoking
a specific control action (CA) too early or too late in the opera-
tion of the system would likely comprise that CA, resulting in an
HCA. One or more RMF controls applied to that CA then helps
enforce required systems behavior. For example, an RMF control may
limit access of people and machines (e.g., microservices) to timing
parameters. Only those entities offering ZT certificates and that are
trusted for accurate systems behavior timelines can access timing
parameters. CODE therefore extends FMA-C by integrating the con-
sideration of RMF cyber controls directly into the systems engineering
workflow. Followed rigorously, RMF controls asserted in CODE sys-
tems contexts ensure the resilience of systems requirements, spec-
ifications, implementation, and updates despite the myriad possible
cyberattacks.
4.4 Zero trust
The foundational tenet of ZT11,12 is that no actor, system, net-
work, or service op

updates despite the myriad possible
cyberattacks.
4.4 Zero trust
The foundational tenet of ZT11,12 is that no actor, system, net-
work, or service operating outside or within the security perimeter
is trusted. ZT has seven principles (pillars) that are embodied into
the CODE processes. These ZT principles involve (1) User, (2) Device,
(3) Network/Environment, (4) Application and Workload, (5) Data, (6)
Visibility and Analytics, and (7) Automation and Orchestration. ZT

each of which must have an identity to which access credentials are

of other NPEs for an appropriately brief period. In a ZT architecture,
credentials are protected from (insider) replay attacks and therefore
incorporate cryptographic hashes with nonces (numbers or reference
data that are “used-once”). ZT entails continuous monitoring of sys-
tems processes, which can become combinatorially explosive and thus
impractical without CODE systems architecture analysis that identi-

4.5 Systems function constraints as cyber
countermeasures
CODE also extends the INCOSE Handbook by defining functional
constraints on systems architecture and implementations that com-
prise cyber countermeasures. For example, CODE control logic iden-
tifies points where identity, credentialing, and access management
(ICAM) must occur to adhere to ZT principles. This CODE process
elevates cyber thinking into systems thinking to establish hard-
ware implementation characteristics that provide countermeasures
to cyberattacks. As a result, logic in the hardware may cross-check
systems behavior characteristics to protect control laws. Applying
the Stuxnet use case: if the Iranian centrifuges had had hardware
acoustic vibration sensors on or near their centrifuges, then those
sensors would have indicated revolution speed t

anian centrifuges had had hardware
acoustic vibration sensors on or near their centrifuges, then those
sensors would have indicated revolution speed that exceeded what
was being reported by the compromised Step7 control system that
was presenting false data to the systems operators. While insert-
ing compromising malware into Step7 would have had its challenges,
simultaneous compromise of physically separate hard-wired acous-
tic vibration sensors of an enhanced system would have been nearly
impossible. Thus, HCH based on logic that cross-checks systems behav-
ior is an inherently functional aspect of CODE-based cyber systems
engineering.
4.6 Digital engineering (DE)
Emerging DE processes13 define the generation and use of digital
artifacts that include models that are developed within model based
systems engineering (MBSE). CODE incorporates DE artifacts from
specialized tools like Matlab (signal processing),14 Analytica (cause
and effect modeling),15 and STK (satellites)16 along with

ates DE artifacts from
specialized tools like Matlab (signal processing),14 Analytica (cause
and effect modeling),15 and STK (satellites)16 along with more general
tools like Excel. CODE integrates such MBSE artifacts with models that
establish cloud alignment, ZT principles, and HCH characteristics in
an integrated DE framework. This advances systems-engineering into
resilient designs and top-level cyber-oriented systems requirements in
hardware, firmware, and software.
5 CODE TECHNICAL OVERVIEW
This section follows the CODE process for an exemplar network node,
with pointers to the larger CODE processes applied in the Pilot Project
and documented in the CODE Guidebook.
5.1 What is the CODE systems engineering
process?
The CODE process generates DE artifacts, including model-based sys-
tems engineering (MBSE) models of an existing or envisioned system.
CODE DE artifacts may begin with a mission need that generates a
systems concept. The CODE context diagram then isolates the scope
of

isioned system.
CODE DE artifacts may begin with a mission need that generates a
systems concept. The CODE context diagram then isolates the scope
of systems engineering and cyber concerns. Cyber concerns include
systems interfaces to the outside world. The system is modeled as a
black box with capabilities formulated to realize the key tasks (KT)
of the system functions. CODE then develops and documents the
elements of cyber security concern. Cyber concerns include hybrid
cloud architectures that distribute functions into computing that is
owned by a third party. Cyber concerns also include threats established
by common vulnerabilities and exposures (CVE)17 and ATT&CK18
models. Stuxnet-class threats postulated by Murphy’s Chaos Monkey
extend CVE and ATT&CK models, tied to the systems engineer-
ing Vee as illustrated in the CODE systems engineering process of

The SPIU functional model of Figure4 establishes the KT that the
SPIU must perform on the RS433 and IP Packets. The seven KTs of
the SPIU from the Guidebook include KT1: Convert Serial Data to IP
Packet Format. The first CA of KT1 is to initiate the movement of
serial data. Other KTs Convert authenticated IP Packet Data to Serial
Format, Route Formatted Data per authenticated NOC directives,
support remote reconfiguration, handle transmission and re-transmit
requests, handle the IP address resolution protocol (ARP), and handle
errors.
5.5 The CODE processes mitigate APTs
The CODE process incorporates the results of an enhanced FMA-
C analysis into the design effort early, thereby minimizing attack
vectors by APT organiza

e CODE process incorporates the results of an enhanced FMA-
C analysis into the design effort early, thereby minimizing attack
vectors by APT organizations such as those that developed and
deployed Stuxnet as summarized in the INCOSE Systems Engineer-
ing Handbook.1 CODE incorporates APT-mitigating cyber principles
into the system requirements, design, integration, testing and oper-
ations support processes, enabled by DE artifacts, to yield cyber
resilient hardware, software, and networking that can complete its
mission while under stress. CODE augments and streamlines the
stand-alone deep Vee systems development processes with concur-
rent DE threads that characterize and implement hardware platforms,
software-defined systems, rapid prototypes, DevSecOps, and early
multi-pronged field-testing.
CODE frames SPIU key tasks (KTs) with the flow of control actions
(CAs) from the NOC persona of Figure5 down to the logical steps
within the SPIU and thence down to physical actions suggested i

low of control actions
(CAs) from the NOC persona of Figure5 down to the logical steps
within the SPIU and thence down to physical actions suggested in of
Figure 5. Key task 1 (KT1) of the SPIU starts with the CA to Initiate
Serial to Packet Conversion to initiate the flow of RS422 bits on the
serial link. This CA may not be provided, which would define the first
HCA of Figure6.
For each CA there are up to five HCAs that are arranged across
the top of Figure6. HCA’s result from not performing a CA, from per-
forming it too much or too often, performing it too early or too late, or
performing it for a duration that is too short or too long.
Initiating the flow of RS422 bits too early or too late would be
HCA3 in Figure6. The SPIU persona model analyzed above defines
the formal CODE black-box model of the SPIU under the control
of the NOC with its KT, CA and HCA that need to be mitigated by
constraints and controls as illustrated above. NOC to SPIU linkage
therefore must incorporate a se

ith its KT, CA and HCA that need to be mitigated by
constraints and controls as illustrated above. NOC to SPIU linkage
therefore must incorporate a secure network with secure inter-
faces so that assignment of KTs by the NOC is accurate (no replay
attacks).

5.6 The threat: Murphy’s Chaos monkey
Even with FMA-C and a related threat-intelligence oriented STPA pro-
cess called MRAP-C,20 it is impossible to fully characterize all possible
threats to a given syste

nd a related threat-intelligence oriented STPA pro-
cess called MRAP-C,20 it is impossible to fully characterize all possible
threats to a given system. Resources like MITRE common vulnerabili-
ties and exposures (CVE)21 and AT&CK22 provide insights but are not
complete (and never will be).
CODE therefore introduces the concept of Murphy’s Chaos Mon-
key. Chaos Monkeys23 have become industry standard best practice
for enhancing software resilience by breaking things in random ways
to generate unexpected behaviors during software development and
deployment processes. Murphy’s law says that if a bad thing can hap-
pen then it will. So, CODE constructed Murphy’s Chaos Monkey to
postulate that malicious entities not only are inside the system on a
regular basis (the ZT model) but also can employ arbitrary malicious
insider actions and arbitrary Zero Day flaws needed to inflict harm on
the system.
Murphy’s Chaos Monkey generates notional cyberattacks within
the system being formulated and a

ry Zero Day flaws needed to inflict harm on
the system.
Murphy’s Chaos Monkey generates notional cyberattacks within
the system being formulated and analyzed by CODE. Sometimes a
design flaw opens an attack surface. For example, the failure to check
number of bytes in a keep-alive message turned a security-preserving
heartbeat into a security eroding Heartbleed24 attack. Murphy’s Chaos
Monkey postulates Heartbleed data leaks without requiring detailed
knowledge of how a Heartbleed threat would be formulated, deployed,
or operated. Therefore, highly classified threat knowledge of MRAP-
C is replaced with a team of designers’ imaginations of the worst
things that could go wrong, leveraging ATT&CK and other unclassified
compendia of threat knowledge. Within the functional architecture,
Murphy’s Chaos Monkey identifies HCA that could occur, extending
FMA-C. The result is that CODE helps the systems engineer to “gets
inside the heads” of the threat actors seeking to attack the SPIU. These

5.7 Employing hardware cyber hardening (HCH)
HCH provides methods for hardening CAs in hardware. The CODE
analysis process sketched above reduces uncertainty and identi-
fies unknowns to isolate the most critical data and functions more
effectively than ad-hoc approaches. CODE translates mission needs
expressed as unacceptable outcomes into discrete requirements that
have a clear control structure. This clarity is illustrated in the differ-
ence between the ad-hoc functional architecture of Figure4 and the
CODE persona-based architecture of Figure5. CODE constraints of
Figure 6 guide implementations. CODE processes further verify and
validate implementations via penetration testing that is informed by
KTs, CAs, and HCAs, bringing systems

entations. CODE processes further verify and
validate implementations via penetration testing that is informed by
KTs, CAs, and HCAs, bringing systems thinking into the cyber activity
of penetration testing.
As illustrated with the SPIU, implementing functions in an isolated
FPGA provides a degree of HCH. DoD has developed chipsets like T-
CORE25 that encrypt data in RAM and that limit execution privileges
to functions that present appropriate credentials in hard real time. In
addition, the trusted platform module (TPM) provides hardware-based
support for credentialing.26 Modern chip sets like Intel i9 provide a
hardware root of trust in secure boot. Therefore, software that has
been certified will run effectively initially. However, there are well-
known proofs in theory of computing that general purpose (Turing-
equivalent) software is “undecidable27” and therefore subject to the
insertion of malware regardless of how much software-based protec-
tion is provided. Therefore, mission c

“undecidable27” and therefore subject to the
insertion of malware regardless of how much software-based protec-
tion is provided. Therefore, mission critical controls are afforded HCH
to reduce Turing-equivalence to render software attacks infeasible.
5.8 The SPIU as built and tested
Continuing with the SPIU example, the CODE processes described
above guided the SPIU specification, implementation, and testing.
CODE (especially Murphy’s Chaos Monkey) identified the corrup-
tion of internal routing tables by ARP poisoning as a threat that
would prevent the SPIU from completing its mission. Hence cer-
tain ARP responses were identified as HCA. Therefore, the FPGA
firmware was designed to prevent those actions. The SPIU FPGA
used in the penetration testing research laboratory is shown in
Figure 7.
Penetration testing of the SPIU was performed by ENSCO’s cyber
security penetration testing (Pentest) team. They first attempted to
ARP poison the SPIU network. The Pentest team was able to poiso

by ENSCO’s cyber
security penetration testing (Pentest) team. They first attempted to
ARP poison the SPIU network. The Pentest team was able to poison the
network switch, denying access to the SPIU. However, when the net-
work switch was taken out of the configuration, the Pentest team could
not affect the operations of the SPIU in its handling of address resolu-
tion requests. This initial Pentest of the SPIU was successful. Related
CODE-based development and testing continues.
HCH via FPGAs was appropriate for the SPIU but is not needed
for every aspect of every system. The CODE systems engineering
processes identify those mission critical functions where hardware-
based cyber hardening yields significant levels of protection to the
mission, particularly for critical infrastructure and life-critical systems.
The larger CODE processes assist one in leveraging cloud-native and
hybrid cloud architectures while applying the principles of ZT with the
analytical rigor of CODE STPA FMA-C.

ssist one in leveraging cloud-native and
hybrid cloud architectures while applying the principles of ZT with the
analytical rigor of CODE STPA FMA-C.
6 CODE OUTCOMES
In the example developed above, CODE was applied to legacy net-
work nodes to synthesize a more secure node that was validated by
red team attacks. Following the CODE processes, the secure replace-
ment node was implemented in a FPGA, implementing a network node
that has no OS, no protocol stacks, and no apparent remote attack
surfaces. Implemented with the “less is more” cyber principle, this
exemplar node demonstrates that an FPGA board can hardware-cyber-
harden a data transport function to achieve CPU-less communication
with significantly reduced remote attack surfaces. In penetration test-
ing (Pentest), the attackers were able to poison the ARP response
of a Commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) switch, but even when oper-
ating on the local area network (LAN) the attackers were unable
to ARP-poison the FPGA that conformed

off-the-shelf (COTS) switch, but even when oper-
ating on the local area network (LAN) the attackers were unable
to ARP-poison the FPGA that conformed to CODE HCH design
constraints.
Self-checking enhances resilience and mitigates postulated APTs
more effectively than systems without self-checking. Integrating cyber
thinking into systems thinking yields selective behavioral self-checking
as a significant systems-engineering outcome of CODE.
On the other hand, less critical systems functions may not need
to be HCH, but might be hosted on a public cloud, a secure cloud, a
local data center, or on-premises (on-prem) equipment. CODE defines
quantitative tradeoffs among risks versus cost of enhanced cyber
protection, realizing high quality systems engineering tradeoffs within
the context of the most vicious of APT landscapes.
A Pilot Project conducted in June through September of 2022 eval-
uated CODE’s contributions to the systems requirements document
and statement of work used in acquiri

onducted in June through September of 2022 eval-
uated CODE’s contributions to the systems requirements document
and statement of work used in acquiring a US national security system
with estimated acquisition cost in the tens of millions of dollars. The
Government report of CODE contributions was very positive.
6.1 Cloud native outcomes
Cloud native analysis maps the functional architecture to collections of
specific functions (local or on premises) interacting with cloud-based
data stores. The SPIU functions could be hosted in a cloud, but the
myriad security vulnerabilities of clouds and virtual machines that have
been catalogued in the CVE database28 may preclude hosting mission
critical control functions in a cloud even though several clouds support
sensitive and classified data and computing.

Large, multi-faceted systems like urban water infrastructure may
host certain user facing functions in clouds without much risk, pro-
vided the cloud supports security best practices and the developer
configures cloud security appropriately. However, mission critical con-
trol functions such as those that turn valves on and off by access to
programmable logic controllers (PLCs) should be hardware cyber hard-
ened and therefore hosted locally versus in the cloud. Drawing on the
SPIU example, critical controls needed to be implemented in an FPGA
with partial reconfigurability turned off so that the FPGA cannot be
uploaded remotely with an FPGA personality tha

eeded to be implemented in an FPGA
with partial reconfigurability turned off so that the FPGA cannot be
uploaded remotely with an FPGA personality that contains malicious
FPGA code (e.g., in VHDL). Thus, CODE does not preclude clouds and
other cost-effective hosts, but the CODE analysis identifies system
functions that present sufficiently low risk of unacceptable CAs that
cloud hosting does not risk the mission. CODE identifies which sys-
tem functions require additional protection, cross-checking, and HCH
hosted on-prem.
6.2 CODE zero trust (ZT) shapes systems
architectures and designs
Low-capacity networks may not readily support the overhead of
repeated credential checking of a complete implementation of ZT
approaches. Therefore, the CODE process can group limited functional
primitives (microservices) into larger functions (with fewer total func-
tions per system) so that credential checking may be performed on
these higher-level functions and therefore less frequently and with les

total func-
tions per system) so that credential checking may be performed on
these higher-level functions and therefore less frequently and with less
network overhead.
In the SPIU example, ZT credential checking occurs between the
SPIU and the NOC, but not between the configured IOLAN and the
configured TEMAC because neither can reconfigure the other (they
both are in the data plane). Since the NOC can configure the SPIU, it
“cannot be trusted” in the ZT sense. By weaving the seven ZT principles
into the process that generates the architecture (embodied in DE arti-
facts as defined in the CODE Guidebook) CODE maps requirements
to functions to components, to elements and then integrates them per
the Vee or per DevSecOps. CODE thus helps the systems engineer
to obtain a secure system architecture, functions, components, and
design rules via a repeatable CODE ZT systems-engineering process.
CODE therefore complements the INCOSE SE Handbook by spec-
ifying repeatable processes for achiev

ia a repeatable CODE ZT systems-engineering process.
CODE therefore complements the INCOSE SE Handbook by spec-
ifying repeatable processes for achieving the high levels of system
security needed to address today’s cyber threat landscape to mini-
mize risk (or to optimize the cost of risk avoidance) within the industry
standard NIST RMF. CODE provides a repeatable systems-engineering
process by which to realize systems architectures and designs that are
inherently resistant to Stuxnet-class APTs that incorporate multiple
zero-day attacks that evade firewalls and monitors based on cyber best
practices (that have “good cyber hygiene”). CODE systems engineering
builds on and extends cyber hygiene to achieve cyber security that is
“baked into” the resulting systems.
7 LOOKING TO THE FUTURE
Although the process is slower than ideal, the CODE Team are work-
ing to bring CODE to the object management group (OMG). We would
like to integrate OMG’s unified modeling framework (UMF) into CODE
incl

eam are work-
ing to bring CODE to the object management group (OMG). We would
like to integrate OMG’s unified modeling framework (UMF) into CODE
including the left shoulder of the Deep Vee. The detailed use cases and
other products generated in UMF are starting points for CODE related
systems theoretic process analyses (STPA) that will bring an enhanced
CODE process into one or more standards bodies. CODE is a useful
step in our larger digitally enabled cyber systems engineering journey.
We hope that you will join us in leveraging CODE from your unique
perspective and helping us to define the follow-on standardization
activities and cyber secure DE environments of the future.

Abstract
Engineered solutions are becoming more complex and multi-disciplinary in nature. This
evolution requires new techniques to enhance design and analysis tasks that incor-
porate data integration and interoperability across various engineering tool suites
spanning multiple domains at different abstraction levels. Semantic web technologies
(SWT) offer data integration and interoperability benefits as well as other opportuni-
ties to enhance reasoning across knowledge represented in multiple disparate models.
This paper introduces the digital engineering framework for integration and interoper-
ability (DEFII) for incorporating SWT into engineering design and analysis tasks. The
framework includes three notional interfaces for interacting with ontology-aligned
data. It also introduces a novel model interface specification diagram (MI

rk includes three notional interfaces for interacting with ontology-aligned
data. It also introduces a novel model interface specification diagram (MISD) that pro-
vides a tool-agnostic model representation enabled by SWT that exposes data stored
for use by external users through standards-based interfaces. Use of the framework
results in a tool-agnostic authoritative source of truth spanning the entire project,
system, or mission.
KEYWORDS
digital engineering, SEE24 model-based systems engineering (MBSE), SEE26 modeling and
simulation, SEE29 other systems engineering enablers, semantic web and ontologies
1 INTRODUCTION
Increasing complexity in the design and development of modern
cyber-physical systems requires a high level of collaboration across
disciplines. To maintain high standards of quality and reasonable time
frames, computer assisted collaboration is increasingly necessary. Data
integration that enables cross-domain reasoning and collaboration at
the model level is key to ena

isted collaboration is increasingly necessary. Data
integration that enables cross-domain reasoning and collaboration at
the model level is key to enabling and enhancing computer assisted
engineering and design across multiple abstraction levels, domains, and
disciplines.

medium, provided the original work is properly cited and is not used for commercial purposes.

Digital engineering (DE) is an umbrella domain that seeks to inte-
grate the model based systems engineering (MBSE) and domain spe-
cific model based engineering (MBE) domains. Defense Acquisition
University defines DE as “an integrated digital approach that uses
authoritative sources of systems” data and models as a continuum
across disciplines to support lifecycle activities from concept throug

oach that uses
authoritative sources of systems” data and models as a continuum
across disciplines to support lifecycle activities from concept through
disposal.’’1 In order to do this, it relies heavily on the concepts of
authoritative source of truth (AST) and digital thread (DT). The AST
serves as a central data registry where all tools associated with the
project must go to access system data. Thus, multiple tools can access
Systems Engineering.2023;26:365–378. wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/sys 365

the
project must go to access system data. Thus, multiple tools can access
Systems Engineering.2023;26:365–378. wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/sys 365

366 DUNBAR ET AL.
the same datapoint and have certainty that they are working from the
same reference baseline. Researchers have used various structures to
form the AST, including system models,2 databases,3 and various graph
data structures.4–7 The DT digitally connects different models used in
system design and analysis across domain and software boundaries.8
This requires a robust data integration plan to enable the needed model
level connections.
Integration of various models is traditionally done through tool-to-
tool integration. Custom interfaces designed to connect tool A to tool
B have been used for years to accommodate data integration needs
in cross domain analysis. However, tool-to-tool integration is brittle in
nature,4 and the number of tool-to-tool integrations needed to fully
connect the design and analysis system grows

l-to-tool integration is brittle in
nature,4 and the number of tool-to-tool integrations needed to fully
connect the design and analysis system grows exponentially as tools
are added.9 In other words, tool-to-tool integration is prone to error,
difficult to maintain, and hard to scale.
A database approach, which allows for a central hub of data, that
is, accessed by multiple tools, is a better fit as a DE AST. Particu-
larly, a graph data structure that captures system specific data and
connects it to domain knowledge presents an interesting foundation
for a potential solution. Graph data structures capture relationships
between nodes and can take advantage of both relational and graph
based algorithms.10
Computer based ontologies and associated technologies collec-
tively known as semantic web technologies (SWT) provide a techno-
logical base to build out a graph data structure as an AST in the DE
context. SWT comprises a suite of technologies to tag graph data with
semantically meani

base to build out a graph data structure as an AST in the DE
context. SWT comprises a suite of technologies to tag graph data with
semantically meaningful labels, to store and retrieve that data, and to
automatically reason upon it based upon the logical framework under-
pinning the tags. Ontologies provide the markup schema used to tag
the graph and a logical formalization in the form of a taxonomy of
terms, relations, and machine-readable logical expressions using them.
Data repositories called triplestores provide storage and endpoints for
semantic queries, which are used to retrieve and interact with graph
data. Automated reasoners afford the ability to deduce new relations
within tagged data based upon logical inferencing, and to enhance
query results with that inferred information.
While graph data structures have been used in DE and systems
engineering domains with positive results,4–7 to date there is not a
robust framework for guiding engineers to integrate SWT into a DE
envi

nd systems
engineering domains with positive results,4–7 to date there is not a
robust framework for guiding engineers to integrate SWT into a DE
environment.
This paper presents the digital engineering framework for integra-
tion and interoperability (DEFII), an ontology-based framework for
solving integration and interoperability concerns inherent to the DE
domain space. It uses a graph data structure as the DE AST and estab-
lishes three notional interfaces to allow interaction with the ontology
aligned data: the Direct Interface, the Mapping Interface, and the Spec-
ified Model Interface. Additionally, the paper introduces a novel model
interface specification diagram (MISD) to specify ontologically relevant
interfaces without deep understanding of the underlying ontologies.
A successful framework for integrating SWT into DE must move
beyond theory and enable practice that realizes these benefits. For a
framework to reach that threshold, this paper holds that it must:
Significance

beyond theory and enable practice that realizes these benefits. For a
framework to reach that threshold, this paper holds that it must:
Significance and Practitioner Points
This paper develops the use of ontologies and semantic web
technologies for Digital Engineering by introducing the digi-
tal engineering framework for integration and interoperabil-
ity (DEFII). The DEFII framework establishes three notional
interfaces for populating, interacting with, and enhancing
ontology-aligned data. It provides the ability to establish
tool-agnostic interfaces for data contained in a system design
with the novel model interface specification diagram (MISD).
The MISD uses the SysML language as a descriptive model
of the analysis system and co-mingles this with the system
model, giving modelers the ability to specify interfaces used
for analysis in a context dependent manner. This allows for
models to be defined to include data from disparate sources
within the system and exposed in a way that

n a context dependent manner. This allows for
models to be defined to include data from disparate sources
within the system and exposed in a way that gives external
tools, from industry established design and analysis soft-
ware to in-house visualization tools, access to an established,
authoritative source of truth. This approach to interoperabil-
ity allows practitioners to continue using tools that suit their
needs and preferences while taking advantage of enhanced
interoperability between disciplines and creating a knowl-
edge base that can be expanded in the future to allow for
further integration of artificial and augmented intelligence
applications.
1. Provide clear avenues for mapping data from engineering design
and analysis models to an ontology-aligned data store.
2. Allow access to contained data in a flexible, tool-agnostic manner.
3. Allow for the transformation and enhancement of data using
various semantic technologies.
These three success criteria address current data

anner.
3. Allow for the transformation and enhancement of data using
various semantic technologies.
These three success criteria address current data integration needs
in DE and prepare for future capability by taking advantage of an
ontology-based AST that provides a holistic view of the systems under
design. This paper shows the DEFII framework satisfies all three
criteria.
Section 2 looks at related work and identifies a gap identified in
existing literature the DEFII framework fills. Section 3 details the DEFII
framework and related interface types. Section 4 introduces a case
study from the Information Technology (IT) cyber security domain that
uses DEFII to produce results that can be analyzed. It then instantiates
the notional interfaces to address the specific use case and describes
the results of usage of the DEFII framework. Section 5 analyzes the
results to validate DEFII against the success criteria defined above,
discusses limitations of the research and opportunities to e

tion 5 analyzes the
results to validate DEFII against the success criteria defined above,
discusses limitations of the research and opportunities to extend the
research, and interprets the results for the larger DE context. Section 6
provides a conclusion to the paper.

2 | RELATED WORK
Ontologies have long been proposed as a medium for knowledge rep-
resentation in engineering. Theoretical benefits include the potential
for reuse, automated inferencing, and knowledge sharing.11–13 These
theoretical benefits have led to research on how to build solutions that
make use of SWT to enhance engineering efforts. A first step in this
research is the use of SWT directly.
A significant body of past research has focused on demonstrating
engineering capabilities that are enabled by SWT. Most prior work
focuses narrowly on either pure ontology definition for the engineering
domain or the capabilities afforded by ontology aligned data. Coelho
et al. use direct invocation of the SWT stack in their proposal of the
“Data-Ontology-Rule footing” as a mechanism for building ontology
integration into the

use direct invocation of the SWT stack in their proposal of the
“Data-Ontology-Rule footing” as a mechanism for building ontology
integration into the design and analysis workflow. Mechanisms for
pulling system data into ontologies beyond direct manipulation of the
ontological data using semantic tools are not discussed.14 Eddy et al.
describe a framework for design alternative development based on
the use of modular ontologies of the engineering design domain and
various reasoning capabilities.15 Similarly, Hagedorn et al. use SWT to
enable design and ideation in the Additive Manufacturing domain16
based upon semantic querying and rule-based inferences. Daun et al.
use ontologies to describe contexts in concurrent engineering.17 While
these works demonstrate possible benefits of SWT in engineering
context, they lack defined techniques for populating ontology-aligned
data instances and interacting with engineering models or tools. Thus
the benefits demonstrated in these and similar wor

r populating ontology-aligned
data instances and interacting with engineering models or tools. Thus
the benefits demonstrated in these and similar works remain largely
hypothetical.6
Several works have attempted to bridge this gap between tools and
SWT using a process of data mapping. Termed “data ingestion” by com-
mercial tools,18 mapping is a process by which data from outside the
SWT stack is parsed into SWT formats and aligned to ontology-tagged
graph patterns. El Kadiri and Kiritsis discuss mapping for ontology use
in the Product Lifecycle Management (PLM) domain.19 Several other
publications discuss mapping both specifically and generically in ref-
erence to systems engineering domain.10,18,20–23 Mapping tool and
model information to ontology-aligned data allows the use of SWT
in more realistic engineering workflows using real or realistic data.
Examples of this include NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) use of
Computer Aided Engineering for Spacecraft Architectures Tool Sui

ealistic data.
Examples of this include NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) use of
Computer Aided Engineering for Spacecraft Architectures Tool Suite
(CAESAR) to establish logical consistency and build reports using cus-
tom queries.24 Lu et al.’s use of custom querying,21 DL reasoning by
Petnga et al.,23 and data exploration by Hagedorn et al.18
Multiple frameworks have been introduced that make use of direct
mappings from tools to enable SWT applications in engineering con-
texts. JPL introduced CEASAR as a type of framework to aid in MBSE
analyses. CAESAR uses the Ontological Modeling Language (OML)
to capture models in a controlled vocabulary and a number of tool
adapters to incorporate different external design and analysis tools
into the ontology-based approach.24 Moser has proposed the Engi-
neering Knowledge Base (EKB) as a framework for integrating SWT in
multidisciplinary engineering environments.9 This framework focuses
on the use of custom tool mappings to interface with

mework for integrating SWT in
multidisciplinary engineering environments.9 This framework focuses
on the use of custom tool mappings to interface with the under-
lying graph data structure.9,25 Moser contrasts this approach with
a common repository approach. In a common repository approach,
schema must be predetermined and are tool specific, which makes
them more fragile and harder to maintain. In the EKB approach, tool
data are mapped to common engineering concepts, which enables a
more robust representation of the data and semi-automatic transfor-
mation of data from one tool to another.9 Both the CAESAR and EKB
frameworks use an ontology-based AST and enable aspects of the
DT. Mapping is often used alongside descriptive models such as those
defined using the Systems Modeling Language (SysML). JPL,5,26 Bone
et al.,7 and Blackburn et al.27 all populate SWT tools with ontologically
aligned information using SysML that use stereotypes to inject onto-
logical tags. In all these cases, st

27 all populate SWT tools with ontologically
aligned information using SysML that use stereotypes to inject onto-
logical tags. In all these cases, stereotypes serve to guide a tool-specific
mapping process.
Across all of these efforts, mapping provides a mechanism for con-
necting engineering tools with ontology-aligned data and the broader
SWT stack. However, it does so through a rigid, often tool-specific, con-
nection point. As a result, it may be difficult or labor intensive to add
new tools to a workflow. It also limits accessibility of the data to those
with knowledge of how to use SWT tools. Broader access, through a
more flexible input and output mechanism would enable more design
and analysis functionality. SysML v2 begins to provide more flexible
access to system data through the use of a standards based Appli-
cation Programming Interface (API).28,29 However, SysML v2 uses
this flexible input/output mechanism to access the system model, not
an ontology-aligned representatio

ng Interface (API).28,29 However, SysML v2 uses
this flexible input/output mechanism to access the system model, not
an ontology-aligned representation of the information stored in the
system model.
DTs require the interaction of multiple tools external to an AST. Flex-
ibility in how tools can interact with data in the AST enables more
opportunity for this interaction and increases the usability of a DE solu-
tion. While the SWT stack and mapping provide capability for a DT
and are being used in current engineering research, there is space for
additional types of interfaces to enable more diverse access to the AST.
3 METHODS
The DEFII framework (Figure1) assigns the role of the AST to ontolo-
gies and data aligned to those ontologies. This forms the foundation of
the framework. It then uses automated reasoning capabilities of SWT
to enrich the ontology-aligned data through the use of rules and rela-
tionships defined in the ontologies. Finally, it provides clear categories
of interfac

ch the ontology-aligned data through the use of rules and rela-
tionships defined in the ontologies. Finally, it provides clear categories
of interfaces that users can use to access, modify, and populate the AST.
3.1 Ontology aligned data
Ontology-aligned data is the foundation of the framework. It enables
the use of a graph data structure to act as the AST. Using a triplestore
as a graph repository, the ontological knowledge base uses controlled
vocabulary defined by ontology class data to characterize system data
as instances of assigned classes. Representation of system data as
ontology-aligned data in a graph data structure has following four
primary benefits:

FIGURE 1 The DEFII framework for use of SWT in DE contexts.
1. Interoperability
Gruber argues for the use of ontologies for both reusability and
interoperability between domains.11,12 The framework specifies the
use of a top-level ontology and shared development principles to drive
co-development terminology across disparate knowledge domains. A
top-level ontology provides a high-level philosophical basis and devel-
opment guidance, that is, shared by all aligned ontologies within an
ecosystem. Subsequent, domain specific ontologies simply extend this
high-level understanding to ever more specific knowledge domains.
2. Tool agnostic
Because ontologies model domains of knowledge, rather than spe-
cific tools or datasets, data aligned to ontologies is tool agnostic. The
use of a standar

use ontologies model domains of knowledge, rather than spe-
cific tools or datasets, data aligned to ontologies is tool agnostic. The
use of a standards-based open formats, such as the Resource Descrip-
tion Framework (RDF) syntax and the Web Ontology Language (OWL)
enhances this tool agnostic representation of system data. This makes
the data portable and offers greater flexibility and freedom with tool
access to the data.
3. Domain agnostic
Not only does the graph data structure promote tool agnostic access
to data, it also promotes a domain agnostic approach. As noted by
Mordecai et al.,10 the use of graph data structures extracts the system
representation from the MBSE toolset and presents it in more general
terms. As DE serves as an umbrella domain to connect many different
domains,30 representation of data in a way that separates it from any
specific domain, including the systems engineering domain, offers more
equitable access to it.
4. Access to SWT stack
The SWT stack offers m

from any
specific domain, including the systems engineering domain, offers more
equitable access to it.
4. Access to SWT stack
The SWT stack offers many functions based on the formal nature of
ontology-aligned data and the triple format of the stored data. Access
to powerful querying, reasoning, and validation is enabled by the foun-
dational decision of the framework to use ontology-aligned data and
will be detailed in subsequent sections of the paper.
3.2 Reasoning layer
The reasoning layer uses some of the automated reasoning capabili-
ties included in the SWT stack. Since ontologies make use of axioms
and relationships to characterize classes within them, these axioms
can be used to further enrich the data beyond what has been explic-
itly defined. For example, if a child’s mother and the mother’s mother
are defined explicitly in a graph repository and definitions and rela-
tions are encoded in the ontology (i.e., a grandmother is a role filled by a
parent’s mother for that parent

raph repository and definitions and rela-
tions are encoded in the ontology (i.e., a grandmother is a role filled by a
parent’s mother for that parent’s child), then the relationship between
the child and the grandmother can be made through automated rea-
soning, bypassing the need to explicitly declare all knowledge in the
graph repository. In characterizing engineering knowledge applied to
a system, the ability to infer knowledge based on a heterogenous data
store opens the possibility of discovering insights to how design ele-
ments originating in separate tools relate to each other. This capability
uses mathematical logic, specifically description logics (DL), to enable
DL reasoners as part of the SWT stack to automatically enrich the data
without any extra involvement by external users.
3.3 Notional interfaces
The characterization of the system data in the AST is established,
updated, viewed, and analyzed through interfaces to external sources.
DEFII specifies three types of notio

the system data in the AST is established,
updated, viewed, and analyzed through interfaces to external sources.
DEFII specifies three types of notional interfaces: the Direct Inter-
face, the Mapping Interface, and the Specified Model Interface. The
Specified Model Interface is further refined by the introduction of
the Model Interface Specification Diagram (MISD). With these three
types of interfaces and the MISD, the framework provides a structured
approach to access and analyze ontology-aligned data.
The Direct Interface enables the use of the SWT stack directly on
stored data. Data stored as ontology-aligned data enables the use of
SWT tools to extract specific knowledge, apply constraint checking,
and more using a growing set of tools in the SWT suite. This interface
acknowledges this reality and codifies it within the framework’s view
of interfaces. While implementation of subsequent interface types
will inevitably use SWT tools to enable them, this interface type is
distinguis

view
of interfaces. While implementation of subsequent interface types
will inevitably use SWT tools to enable them, this interface type is
distinguished by its direct invocation of those tools.
The Mapping Interface transforms model data into ontology-aligned
data by accessing data stored in a model or tool and mapping it to
ontological classes in the controlled vocabulary. Beginning with exter-
nal model data and establishing a connection to an ontology limits this
interface type to a tool or model specific implementation per instance
of the interface connected. Primarily, this interface addresses MBSE
models and maps system models to ontology-aligned data. System
models are broad in scope and capture design criteria for multiple
domains. Thus, tagging data with relevant ontological terms and map-
ping that data to an ontology-aligned graph provides flexibility for the
system model to be built to describe the relevant domains instead of

elated to interfaces. Instead of a grow-

and ontology-aligned data, these add functionality to the AST by giving

The Specified Model interface characterizes models of interest
within the broader system model. A model of interest is defined here
as an aggregation of parameters present in the system model, that
is, needed for external tools and application purposes. In contrast
with the Mapping Interface, the Specified Model Interface begins with
ontology-aligned data and exposes this data towards tool interfaces.
This reverse of direction enables the interface to be tool agnostic. Even
if an instantiation of the Specified Model Interface is designed with a
particular tool in mind, the di

nables the interface to be tool agnostic. Even
if an instantiation of the Specified Model Interface is designed with a
particular tool in mind, the direction of the interface creation enables
other tools to access the same information via the same interface.
This interface primarily addresses MBE models and exposes data in a
structured way to be analyzed, visualized, etc.
3.4 Model interface specification diagram
The MISD is a reusable, graphical specification for the Specified Model
Interface. The MISD makes use of SysML parametric diagrams to
describe a model of interest and define connections to parameters
established elsewhere in the system model (Figure3). The MISD acts
as a graphical specification of data that will be provided to a given tool
when requested. This extends Cilli’s concept of an Assessment Flow
Diagram.31

Once mapped into the ontological layer, this specification can be

tic technologies or the underlying ontologies used by the framework
to request and update ontology-aligned data captured by the sys-
tem model. It provides the means for tool-agnostic Specified Model
Interfaces to be created and accessed by broader user group and
toolset.

4.2 Framework implementation
To produce results, a DT is established (Figure7) that uses all the inter-
faces to realize the defined use case. The first step is a mapping of
the SysML system model from a tool specific implementation to an
ontology aligned, tool-agnostic representation stored in a triplestore.
Second, the Direct Interface is used to directly query the graph repos-
itory, via a SPARQL query, to discover a specific vu

stored in a triplestore.
Second, the Direct Interface is used to directly query the graph repos-
itory, via a SPARQL query, to discover a specific vulnerability. After
the vulnerability is discovered, the third step is a MATLAB analysis
program pulling data specified by an MISD from the triplestore via a
REST API GET call. Fourth, after the analysis is complete, the triple-
store is updated with new values produced by the analysis. Fifth, the
same REST API endpoint that was used by the MATLAB analysis pro-
gram is reused by a web application dashboard to display the results
of the analysis. In this dataflow, all major elements of the framework
are instantiated, and the reusability of the notional Specified Model
Interface is highlighted.
A functional analysis of the three success criteria identified in the
introduction must be performed to determine in the DEFII framework
fulfills its purpose.

These rules address aspects of the SysML model representation as pre-

the “VersionNumber” ontology class is performed. While this specific
result relates to the cyber case study described in the Section 3, the
mapping rules discussed are more general and can be applied to any
SysML model stored in a TWC instance. Thus, the mapping interface
is tool-specific, but it is domain-agnostic and can be used across many
different models and domains.
